    You say "#226:20 #271:5 #1:6"
    > say lwho(,,1)
    You say "#226:662752801 #271:662992921 #1:662728521"
    > say lwho(1,,1)
    You say "#226:662752801|20 #271:662992921|5 #1:662728521|6"
  
  See Also: WHO, DOING, conn(), idle()
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



LXNOR()
  Function: lxnor(<list of numbers>[,<delim>])
   
  Takes two or more booleans, and returns true(1) if both values are
  true(1) or false(0) and returns false(0) if any one value is
  false(0) but the other(s) are true(1).  You may specify an optional
  delimiter.
  
  Example:
    > say lxnor(1 1 1 1 1 0)
    You say "0"
    > say lxnor(1@1@1@1@1@0,@)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: lor(), lnor(), land(), lxor()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



LXOR()
  Function: lxor(<list of numbers>[,<delim>])
  
  Takes two or more booleans, and returns 1 if an odd number of them are
  equivalent to true(1).  You may specify an optional delimiter.
  
  Example:
    > say lxor(0 1 0 1 0 1)
    You say "1"
    > say lxor(0@1@0@1@0@1,@)
    You say "1"
     
  See Also: lor(), lnor(), land(), lxnor()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



LZONE()
  Function: lzone(<object> [,<key>] [,<objid>])
  
  Returns the zone list for an object. If the object is a zonemaster,
  the list contains the objects within the zone controlled by the 
  zonemaster. If the object is not a zonemaster, the list contains
  all of the zonemasters that the object belongs to.  This is _not_
  database intensive.
  
  You may optionally specify <objid> as '1' to return the objid's 
  of the target instead of the dbref#'s.
   
  The following optional keys are available:
    0 - list all zones (or zonemasters) of the target (default)
    n - List 'n'th 400 zones (or zonesmasters) of the target. 
        NOTE: 'n' will be any number from 1 to however many 'pages'
              So '1' would be first 400, '2' would be second 400, etc.
    l - List total pages and total zones (or zonemasters) of target.
    ~ - [~#1-#2] list zones starting at #1 until count of #2.
     
  Example:
    > @set here=zonemaster
    > @zone here=#0
    > @zone here=#534
    > say lzone(here)         
    You say "#0 #534"
    > say lzone(here,,1)         
    You say "#0:8185828502 #534:8258128282"
    > say lzone(here,l)
    You say "1 2"
 
  See Also: @zone, ZONES, inzone(), zwho(), zonecmd()
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail
  Command: mail [@]<player-list>=<subject> (with BRANDY_MAIL toggle)
           mail [@]<player-list>=[<subj>/]<body> (with PENN_MAIL toggle)
           mail [@]<player-list>=[<subj>//]<body> (with no toggle)
           mail [<mesg#>|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N]
  
   ---- For the main mail help file please see:  HELP MAIL MAIN ----
  
   Note: For folder help please type 'help folder'
  
   Important topics:
      'HELP MAIL MAIN' for main index.    -- this is very helpful
      'HELP MAIL TOPICS' for topical help.
  
   Important initial help entries:
      'HELP MAIL CMDLIST' for the mail command listing and descriptions
      'HELP FOLDER CMDLIST' for the folder command listing and descriptions
      'HELP MAIL DTUTOR' for a quick tutorial on how to use mail
      'HELP MAIL BTUTOR' for a quick tutorial on the mail editor (optional)
      'HELP MAIL PTUTOR' for a quick tutorial on Penn @mail syntax (optional)
  
  If you are used to the MUX standard of @mail or the softcoded BrandyMail
  you will want to use the BRANDY_MAIL toggle.  
  
  If you are used to the PENN standard of @mail, you will want to use
  the PENN_MAIL toggle.  The BRANDY_MAIL toggle will take presidence.
  
  For using the line editor, you may use the MAIL_STRIPRETURN toggle.  This
  will convert the carriage return between lines to a space when combining.
   
  To set a toggle, you would type: @toggle me=<toggle>.  An example would be:
                        @toggle me=BRANDY_MAIL
 
  Examples:
    > mail me=My Subject//My Body
    Mail: You have new mail from -> <your name>
    Mail: Message sent to -> <your name>
    Mail: Done
  
  See Also: mail main, mail topics, folder
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail +all
  This is a sub-option to 'mail/read' (short for just 'mail').  If you
  specify '+all' at the end, it will read every message that you have
  in your mailbox.  Warning:  This can be spammy.
  
  Example:
    > mail/read +all
    > mail +all
  
  See Also: mail uall, mail nall, mail new, mail unread, mail ball
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail alias
  Command: mail/alias
  
  The alias switch is used to display any global alias you have 
  permission to access and will list all players that are attached
  to that global alias.  Global aliases are maintained by the 
  administration of the mush.  If you have ideas of global aliases,
  suggest it to them and they will add them.
  
  Syntax: mail/alias
  Wizards: wizhelp wmail alias
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail anonymous
  Command: mail/anon player=message
           mail/anon/send player=message
           mail/anon/forward <msg#> player=message
           mail/anon/reply <msg#>=message
  
  The anon[ymous] switch is used in junction with the /send, /forward, or
  /reply switches (or normal sending) to ANONYMOUSLY send the mail message
  to the player.  Wizards are except from receiving anonymous mail due to
  security issues.
  
  Attempting to forward anonymous mail shows the original message being
  'anonymous'.  Attempting to reply to an anonymous mail will reply 
  to the 'anonymous' player, while that player still receives the message.
  
  If you use the line editor, you can use -~ to send anonymously instead of
  -- which would normally send the mail.
   
  See Also: mail send, mail reply, mail forward
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail attributes
  Topic: MAIL ATTRIBUTES
  
  The following attributes have special meaning in the mail system.
    @mailsig     -- The signature that is assigned to any mail sent.
    &mailfilter  -- This is evaluated to auto-filter what folder mail goes to.
    &mailnotify  -- This is evaluated to auto-send notification to senders.
    @mailtime    -- (Wizard only) Sets the auto-delete time on a player.
    @mailsmax    -- (Wizard only) Sets the maximum saved messages on a player.
    MailLock     -- (Internal) This is the lock mail/lock sets
  
  The following wildcard patterns are used for mail:
    mail &foo=text    -- This will check your personal FOO attribute for
                         the player list you want to send to.
                         This is non-evaluated.
    mail ~foo=text    -- This will check your personal FOO attribute for
                         the player list you want to send to.
                         This is evaluated.
  
  See Also: @mailsig, &mailfilter, &mailnotify, mail lock, mail setup_aliases
  For wizards, wizhelp: @mailsmax, @mailtime



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail autofor
  Command: mail/autofor <player-name>
           mail/autofor +off
  
  Autoforwarding is used to autoforward mail that you would normally get
  to another player.  This is handy in the event that you have
  multiple players and wish to have mail all catagorized to a central
  player.  All forwarded mail is sent as from the original sender, 
  not from the player it was forwarded from.
  
  Autoforwarding can only be forwarded on a one-time basis.  It is not
  recursive.  So in otherwords, you can not forward mail forwarded to you.
  
  To remove an autoforwarding use the command:
      mail/autofor +off
  
  Mail that is autoforwarded will show up to the user sending you mail
  where it got autoforwarded to.
  
  See Also: mail lock, mail share
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail autopurges
  Topic: mail autopurging 
  
  The mail system has a built in autopurging system.  To save mail
  from autopurging, it needs to have the SAVE flag set on it.  You
  have a limited number of SAVE flags you can set.  For help on
  the save flag for mail, do 'help mail save'.  Autopurging is
  currently set to three weeks but can be set at any time.  NEW
  and UNREAD mail is not effected.  
  
  Wizards by default are never auto-purged from.
  
  To set the save flag, you would use:
  
     mail/mark/save <arg>
  
  where <arg> is a single message, a list of messages, or a combination.
  
  Note:  By default, players are given 10 save slots for messages.
         This can be increased globally or individually on a case by case
         basis.  Please see 'mail/quota' to see what your current saved
         quota is.
  
  See Also: mail mark, mail save
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail ball
  This is a sub-option to 'mail/read' (short for just 'mail').  If you
  specify 'nall' at the end, it will read ALL the new AND the unread
  mail messages you have in your mailbox.
  
  Example:
    > mail/read ball
    > mail ball
  
  See Also: mail uall, mail nall, mail new, mail unread, mail both
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail basics
  Topic: mail basics
  
  The basic mail sub-commands are:     
     write, send, read, mark, delete, quick, and status.
  
  For more information, check the help on mail and it's sub-commands.
       type in 'help mail' and 'help folder' for the base core commands.
       type in 'help mail <subcommand>' for the mail subcommand.
       type in 'help folder <subcommand>' for the folder subcommand.
  
  To send a message to a player and enter text line by line:
     mail/write <optional text for first line>
     For full help on /write, type in 'help mail write'
  
  To send a message to a player:
     mail[/send] <player> =<message>    (help mail send)
     For example:   mail tinypal=Let's meet tomorrow night.
     Note that '/send' is optional for this command (mail/send).
  
  To read a message:
     mail[/read] #                      (help mail read)
     For example:   mail 3
     Note that '/read' is optional for this command (mail/read).
  
{ To continue, type: help mail basics2 }
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail basics2
  Topic: mail basics (continued)
  To mark a message for deletion:
     mail/mark #                        (help mail mark)
     For example:   mail/mark 12
  
  To save a message (keep it from being purged):
     mail/mark/save #                   (help mail save)
     For example:   mail/mark/save 12
 
  To delete marked messages:
     mail/delete                        (help mail delete)
  
  To get a quick summary of mail (how many new, unread, old, marked, 
  current folder):
     mail[/quick]                       (help mail quick)
     Note that 'quick' is optional for this command (mail/quick).
  
  To see all mail headers and status:
     mail/status                        (help mail status)
  
  For information on setting up folders, type 'help folder'
  For more information on mail, type in 'help mail <command>'
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail both
  This is a sub-option to 'mail/read' (short for just 'mail').  If you
  specify 'both' at the end, it will read the first new OR unread
  mail message you have in your mailbox.
  
  Example:
    > mail/read both
    > mail both
  
  See Also: mail uall, mail nall, mail new, mail unread, mail ball
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail btutor
  Topic: mail btutor (Enhanced Line Editor (Brandy) Interface)
  
  Note: Some RhostMUSH's will have a bunch of @mail aliases to mimic
        the MUX/TM3 (and in some cases the +mail) interfaces.  If
        so please refer to these help files.
  
  Welcome to the mail system tutorial (brandy interface).  This will
  not cover all the commands, but will give you a good heads up on
  how to use the mail interface if you come from a MUX background
  with @mail or a mush background and used the Brandy mailer.
  
  First, let's set ourselves up so we can use the brandy interface.
  Please type this exactly as it shows:
  
    @toggle me=brandy_mail
  
  If you wish to remove the toggle at a later date, you may do this
  by doing @toggle me=!brandy_mail.  Help is available on this toggle
  by 'help brandy_mail toggle'.
  
  Ok, first, write a message to yourself, then we can begin the
  tutorial.  To start a new message, type this exactly as shown:
  
    mail me=test subject
    -test body
    --
  
  To begin your tutorial, please type the following now:
  
    help mail dtutor notes
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail changes
  Topic: changes
  
  There are some changes that you may notice with the new mail system.  These
  changes are the following:
  
    Subjects are included with mail:
        - Subjects are added by separating the body and the subject using 
          '//'.  IE: mail user=subject//body 
          (see: help mail send)
        - Subjects can be added with the mail's line editor.  This is done
          by using the +subject option.  IE: mail/write +subject
          (see: help mail write)
  
    Recalling mail has been greatly modified:
        - You are able to recall any message not read by another player that
          you have sent.  It is displayed in a concise manner.
          (see: help mail recall)
  
{ type: help mail changes2 to continue }
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail changes2
  Topic: changes (continued)
  
    New options for mail/write:
        - When adding new text, you can use the shortcut of '-' to add new
          lines.  This works similar to MUX's @mail does.
          (see: help mail write)
  
    New options for locking mail:
        - You can set a reject message for people you lock your mail out to.
          (see: help mail reject)
   
    Mail signatures:
        - Mail signatures that are automatically included are set by using
          @mailsig attribute.  To set, just type: @mailsig me=<signature>
  
  See Also: mail version, mail basics, mail signature
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail check
  Command: mail/check <target>=<#>
  
  If someone has set up her mailbox to be shared with you, you can use this
  command to read a particular message from the target's mailbox.
   
  Example:
    > mail/check tinyfriend=4    (read tinyfriend's message #4)
   
  See Also: mail read, mail number, mail share
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail cmdlist
  Topic: mail command list of commands (in alphabetical order) [1/3]
  
  mail                       - This is short for 'mail/quick'
  mail/alias                 - This lists all global mail aliases.
  mail/autofor <player>      - This sets an automatic forward of mail to the
                               target player.
  mail/check <player>=<arg>  - This checks the target player's mail allowing
                               you to read it.  That player MUST have their
                               mail set to be shared by you!
  mail/delete                - This purges all marked mail.
  mail/forward <num> [<arg>] <player-list>[=[<subject>//]<optionaltext>] 
                               This forwards the target message to the 
                               specified list of players.
  mail/lock <key>            - This locks your mail from the given  player(s).
  mail/mark[/save] <arg>     - This marks the mail for deletion or if the 
                               optional SAVE switch is used, marks the mail
                               from deleting.  Mail is automatically purged
                               after a set period.  The SAVE flag keeps it
                               safe from this.
  mail/next                  - This automatically reads the next message.
  
  { see help mail cmdlist2 for more }


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail cmdlist2
  Topic: mail quicklist of commands (CONTINUED) [2/3]
  
  mail/number <target>[=<arg>] - This displays the target player's mail.  You
                               must pass that person's sharelock before you
                               can do this.
  mail/page <lines>          - This sets up the number of lines per page you
                               can view. This is relevant only for mail/status
  mail/password <args>       - This allows you to password-lock your mail.
  mail[/quick]               - This gives you a quick status of mail you have.
                               The /quick switch is optional.
  mail/quota                 - This gives you your quota statistics.
  mail[/read] <arg>          - This reads the mail.  /read switch is optional.
                               You may specify 'new' or 'unread' as well for
                               the argument instead of the mail number..
  mail/recall <args>         - This displays mail sent to others, the contents
                               of it, and gives you availability to yank mail
                               that hasn't been read.
  mail/reject [<arg>]        - This sets or resets your reject message.
  mail/reply [<arg>]<message-#>[<arg>]=[<subject>//]<body> - This replies to
                               the given message.
  
  { see help mail cmdlist3 for more }
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail cmdlist3
  Topic: mail quicklist of commands (CONTINUED) [3/3]
  
  mail[/send] [<arg>]<player-list>=[<subject>//]<body> - This sends mail to
                               the targeted player(s).  The /send switch is
                               optional as well as the arguments and subject.
  mail/share <players>       - This sets it up so that you can share mail with
                               other people.  It uses standard @lock keys.
  mail/status [<args>]       - This gives the listing of mail in your box.
  mail/unmark <args>         - This unmarks from deletion or saving the target
                               mail.
  mail/version               - This displays the current version of mail.
  mail/write <string>        - This begins writing a letter using the line
                               editor.  After this command, you may use '-' to
                               continue writing mail.
  mail/zap                   - This deletes your current message and reads the
                               next message (if available).
  
  See Also: mail, folder, folder cmdlist
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail creating
  Please see 'help mail send'

[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail credits
  Topic: mail credits
  
  This mail system was coded by Seawolf.  It is largely based on 
  Ashen-Shugar's mush-coded +mail system.
 
  Help files were written by Wizard@ApexMUSH, Seawolf, and Ashen-Shugar.
 
  Thanks to Lothar for suggesting folder/share.
  
  Thanks to beta-testers:
    Ashen-Shugar, Eingelbert, Seth, Wizard
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail delete
  Command: mail/delete
  
  This command will delete all your marked messages in all your folders.
  
  See Also: mark, unmark, recall, save
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail dtutor
  Topic: mail dtutor (Default Bare-Bone Tutorial)
  
  Welcome to the mail system tutorial.  This will not cover all
  the commands, but it will run you through enough of them to
  get you started with using the mail system.  
  
  The mailsystem has a huge amount of functionality and it is
  our hopes that this will help remove some of the fear and
  confusion you may have.
  
  There will be pages to the tutorial that will allow you
  to interact and try each command at the same time.
  
  Let's make sure you have a mail message to help with
  the tutorial.  Please type this exactly as it shows:
      
    mail me=test subject//test body
  
  We'll explain what that does in the tutorial.
  To begin your tutorial, please type the following now:
  
    help mail dtutor1
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail dtutor notes
  Topic: mail dtutor notes
  
  This is just a quick review of what you can do with the brandy
  mail interface you can't without it.
  
  When toggled, BRANDY_MAIL, you will automatically go into the
  line editor when you do the following commands:
  
    mail <list-of-players>=<subject>                (sending mail)
    mail/send <list-of-players>=<subject>//<body>   (quick sending mail)
    mail/reply <msg#>=<subject>                     (replying to mail)
    mail/forward <msg#> <list-of-players>=<subject> (forwrding mail)
  
  You have a HUGE availability of options in the line editor.  For
  the list, please type:
  
    help mail write cmdlist
  
  Help is available on individual topics therein with:
  
    help mail write <subtopic>
  
  To continue your tutorial, please type the following now:
  
    help mail dtutor1
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail dtutor1
  Topic: Mail Default Tutor (Page 1)
  
  Let's start with checking your mail.  To see if you have
  any mail, please type the following now:
    > mail/quick
  
  You should see the following:
    Mail: You have no current folder
    Mail: 1 Total - 1 new, 0 unread, 0 old, 0 marked, 0 saved mail message(s)
  
  Please note, if you do indeed have extra  mail, you will see something like:
    Mail: You have no current folder
    Mail: 2 Total - 2 new, 0 unread, 0 old, 0 marked, 0 saved mail message(s)
  
  new      : tells you that you have 1 new message.
  unread   : would tell you that you had new messages but disconnected before
             you got to read them
  old      : tells you you have mail you already read
  marked   : tells you you have mail messages marked for deletion
  saved    : tells you you have messages saved from being auto-deleted.
  
  To continue, please type: help mail dtutor2
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail dtutor2
  Topic: Mail Default Tutor (Page 2)
  
  Ok, let's say you do have mail.  To recap, it showed this with mail/quick:
      Mail: You have no current folder
      Mail: 1 Total - 1 new, 0 unread, 0 old, 0 saved mail message(s)
  
  Now, you probably ask, how do you see who the mail is from?  To see who
  the mail is from and the various statistics of it, you would use the command:
    > mail/status
  
  Try it out, you should see mail from yourself.  Output would be like this:
  
  Mail: You have no current folder
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
  [N] ( 1) *From: <Your Name>      <Wed Jul 14 00:22:57 1999> (4 Bytes)
            Subj: test subject
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Mail: Done
  
  You'll notice it has the subject 'test subject' just like you should have
  typed when you read 'help mail dtutor'.  Each message has:
    [N]    - specifies a NEW message.  It can also be 'S'aved, 'U'nread, 'O'ld,
             and 'M'arked (for messages marked for deletion).
             If you disconnected without checking a (N)ew message, it becomes
             an (U)nread message upon your connection.
    ( 1)   - specifies that it is the first message in your mailbox.
    <date> - the date the mail was received.
    Subj:  - the optional subject.  As it's optional it may not be on all mail
    From:  - who sent the mail.
    *      - states if player is connected. (blank if they're not)
  
  To continue, please type: help mail dtutor3
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail dtutor3
  Topic: Mail Default Tutor (Page 3)
  
  Ok, you now know how to view the mail and list what mail you have, but now
  how do you read it?  Well, there's various ways you can do this.
  If you know it is a NEW message you may type this:
    > mail new
  
  This will read the first NEW mail message you have.  You could also specify
  'unread' instead of 'new' for the first unread message you have.
    > mail unread
  
  Unread is different than New messages by defining a message that was New
  but you had disconnected before you could read it.  So Unread mail is mail
  that you just have not read, but is not New for your current connection.
  
  If you know you have new mail, but are not sure if it's new or unread, you
  may use the 'both' qualifier.  This will read the first New OR Unread
  message, whatever is currently next.
    > mail both 
  
  You may also type the number of the message you want to read.  For example:
    > mail 1
  
  This will read the first mail message in your mail box.
  The output should look like this:
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Message #: 1        (Connected)
  Status: NEW         From: <Your Name>
  Date/Time: Wed Jul 14 00:22:57 1999        Size: 4 Bytes
  Subject: test subject
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
  test body
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Mail: Done
  
  To continue, please type: help mail dtutor4
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail dtutor4
  Topic: Mail Default Tutor (Page 4)
  
  Ok, you now have read your message, you may want to know how to delete it.
  First, you need to mark the message.  There are two ways you can do this
  as well.  First, you can tell mail to delete the last read message and read
  the NEXT message in your mailbox with the 'zap' switch.
    > mail/zap
  
  If you don't have any other messages, or feel more comfortable marking them
  individually, you may use the 'mark' switch.
    > mail/mark 1
  
  This tells the mail system to mark your first message in your mailbox for
  deleting.  Let's verify that it was set.  Type:  mail/status
  
  You should see:
  Mail: You have no current folder
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
  [M] ( 1) *From: <Your Name>      <Wed Jul 14 00:22:57 1999> (4 Bytes)
            Subj: test subject
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Mail: Done
  
  Note:  the '*' before the From: states that you are connected. 
  
  To continue, please type: help mail dtutor5
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail dtutor5
  Topic: Mail Default Tutor (Page 5)
  
  Ok, let's say before you delete the message, you want to reply to the 
  mail.  You may use a few methods.  First, to reply to the sender AND
  include the message in the reply, type this:
    > mail/reply 1*=test reply
  
  You should see:
    Mail: You have a new mail from -> <Your name>
    Mail: Message sent to -> <Your name>
    Mail: Done
   
  Note: If you have the BRANDY_MAIL toggle enabled, this puts you in the editor
  
  Now, lets type mail/status to see your status: 
    > mail/status 
  
  You should see the following:
  Mail: You have no current folder
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
  [M] ( 1) *From: <Your Name>      <Wed Jul 14 00:22:57 1999> (4 Bytes)
            Subj: test subject
  [N] ( 2) *From: <Your Name>      <Wed Jul 14 00:34:15 1999> (116 Bytes) Reply
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Mail: Done
  
  You may use 'mail new', 'mail both', or 'mail 2' to read this message.  
  
  To continue, please type: help mail dtutor6
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail dtutor6
  Topic: Mail Default Tutor (Page 6)
  
  Ok, let's say you just wanted to send the player a message separate from
  a reply.  You may send mail one of two ways.  You can send it the quick
  and easy method (which will be shown here), or you may use the built-in
  line editor (which is full of features).  If you prefer to use the
  line editor, please refer to 'help mail write' as it is fairly involved
  with it's features.  You also have the BRANDY_MAIL toggle option.
  
  We'll assume you'll want to do this the easy way for now.  To send a 
  message you would type:  
    > mail <player>=<subject>//<body>
  
  The subject is optional and you don't have to specify it.  Let's send
  a message to yourself.  First, without a subject, then with a subject.
  Without a subject:
    > mail me=a test message
  
  With a subject:
    > mail me=a test subject//a test message
  
  With brandy toggle enabled:
    > mail me=a test subject
    > -a test message
    > --
  
  Depending if you did one or both examples, you should have seen you have
  two new messages.  mail/status will list these.
  
  To continue, please type: help mail dtutor7
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail dtutor7
  Topic: Mail Default Tutor (Page 7)
  
  Ok, let's delete those marked messages we have.  You should only have one
  message marked for deletion (unless you went on your own and marked more).
  Now, to purge out the mail you have marked for deletion, please type:
    > mail/delete  
  
  You should have seen the message as follows:
    Mail: 1 message(s) deleted
    Mail: Done
  
  Hey, guess what?  You now have a working knowledge of how to send, read, and
  delete mail.  Congratulations, you have the basics down.  
  
  The mail system is quite extensive with all that it offers, and if something
  you wanted to learn is not in this tutorial, my apologies.  But you will 
  find the help files show examples and are very informative.  If you want
  a quick listing of all the mail commands and syntax/descriptions, please
  type the following:
    > help mail cmdlist
  
  If you want a list of commands used with writing mail with the line editor
  type the following:
    > help mail write cmdlist
  
  Thank you for using the tutorial.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail folders
  Topic: mail folders
  
  Mail may be stored in different folders.  Your default folder is the
  'Incoming' folder.  This is the folder where mail will be stored if
  you do not move it to another folder.  If you do not wish to deal with
  folders, you may safely ignore all references to folders, as long as
  you do not use the folder command.
   
  Mail folders may be up to 20 characters in length.  The first letter is
  capitalized, and the rest are in lower case (although you can use any case
  when referring to folders).  Incoming is reserved as the default mail
  folder.
   
  For information on the various folder sub-command, check 'help folder'.
  All mail sub-commands which list your mail or require specifying a
  message number (e.g, status, reply) act on your current folder.  This
  is documented in help on the individual relevant mail sub-commands.
  
  See Also: folder
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail forward
  Command: mail/forward <msg #> [@|^]<list> [=[<subject>//]<additional text>]
  
  Forward a mail message to someone.  Note that you do not have to include your
  own message, which is appended to the bottom of the message.  The
  message number and the address list are separated by a space.  For the
  format of the address list, see the help on the send sub-command
  (help mail send).  You can only forward messages in the current folder.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/forward 3 myfriend
    > mail/forward 2 &friendlist=Weird!!!//What do you think of this?
    > mail/forward 12 @friend1 #12345 friend2=Can you believe this?!
  
  Note:  If you have the BRANDY_MAIL @toggle set, the syntax would be this:
    > mail/forward 3 myfriend
    > mail/forward 2 &friendlist=My Subject
    > mail/forward 12 @friend1 #12345 friend2=This is a subject
  
  You'd then use '-' for additional text and '--' to send the mail.
  
  See Also: mail reply, mail send
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail line
  Topic: mail line manipulation
  
  +LIST:
    The +list sub-command includes optional <s#> and <e#> arguments to specify
    the start and end line numbers to list.  Line numbers are always listed,
    but not displayed.
   
  +JUSTIFY:
    Delete line # <#> with the +del sub-command. Justify line <#> as left-
    right-, or center-justified with the +justify sub-command.  Editing a
    line resets the justification to left.  Justification may seem off when
    using +list, as line numbers off-set the lines.
   
  +SPLIT:
    Split line <l#> after <#w> number of words with the +split command.
  
  +JOIN:
    Join line <l#> appended by line <a#> with the +join sub-command.
   
  +INSERT:
    Insert <text> before line <#> with the +insert sub-command.
   
  To see example of line editing, check: help mail line examples
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail line examples
  Topic: mail line examples
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write +list=2,4
    > mail/write +del=5
    > mail/write +justify=1,c
    > mail/write +split=3,15
    > mail/write +join=5,6
    > mail/write +insert=4,I am not sure if you would agree with:
    > -this is another line for my message I'll be sending.
    > mail/write +send=Seawolf
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail lineeditor
  Topic: mail line editing
    
  The mailsystem has a built-in line editor for sending all forms of mail.  
  This includes forwarded mail, replied-to mail, and standard mail and mass 
  mail. To look at sending mail by using a line by line input, check the help 
  for:
  
     mail write   (IE: help mail write)
  
  See Also: mail write, mail send, mail line
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail list_aliases
  Topic: mail aliases
  
  There are two distinctive types of mail aliases.  The first is the
  user defined alias.  To set this, you would set an attribute on
  yourself with the names and/or numbers of the people in the list
  you want to send to.
  
  Example: &FRIENDS me=Nyctasia Seawolf billie sappho
           &EVAL_FRIENDS me=[v(myfriends_list)]
  
  You would use this by inputting on the 'send' option of mail
  the following:
  
  Example: mail[/send] &friends=Hello my friends!
           mail[/send] ~me/eval_friends=Hello my friends! 
  
  As shown, the /send parameter is optional for sending mail.
  
  The second form of aliases are global aliases.  These are 
  established by the administration for the use of everyone on the 
  system.  You would use this by inputting on the 'send' option
  of mail the following: 
  (Let's assume a global alias of 'members')
  (Let's assume a dynamic eval list of 'wizards' for wizards)
  
  
  Example: mail[/send] +members=Welcome fellow guild members!
           mail[/send] $wizards=Welcome eval-wizard list members!
  
  As above, the /send parameter is optional.
  
  See Also: mail send, mail, mail basics, mail alias
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail lock
  Command: mail/lock <key>
  
  You can lock your mailbox so that only certain people can (or cannot)
  send you mail.  The key is the same as for any other lock.  Type:
  
                       'help @lock keys' 
  
  for a list of the keys you may use.  To unlock, use a
  blank key.  IE: mail/lock  (this will unlock your mail lock)
  
  Examples:
    > mail/lock tinyspouse  (this locks to just tinyspouse)
    > mail/lock !tinyjerk   (this locks against tinyjerk)
    > mail/lock             (this removes your mail lock)
   
  The attribute it sets on you is 'MailLock' and is set like a normal lock.
   
  See Also: mail reject, mail recall
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail main
  RhostMush has its own in-game mail system.  The mail command
  takes various switches to perform the various mail sub-commands, as in:
  
      mail/read 1
  
  The following mailer options exist for mail:
      mail basics            mail folders            mail list_aliases
      mail autopurges        mail changes            mail lineeditor
      mail massmail          mail credits            mail send examples
      mail line examples     mail write examples     mail signature
      mail cmdlist           mail technical          mail tutorial
      mail quicklist         mail setup_aliases      mail attributes
  
  help on options can be seen by using the help command with any topic.
  
  to get help on mail sub-commands use: help mail <sub-command>
  where <sub-command> is one of the sub-commands listed below:
   
  alias   anon     autofor   check   delete    forward  mark      lock   
  next    reject   number    page    password  quick    quota     read  
  recall  reply    save      send    share     status   unmark    write 
  zap     version  previous
  
  To see the credits, enter: help mail credits
  
  See help on the BRANDY_MAIL @toggle as well. (help brandy_mail toggle)
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail mark
  Command: mail/mark <#>|all|<*player>
  
  This command allows you to mark messages for deletion.  <#> indicates
  a specific message to be marked.  To delete more than one message by
  message number, separate the message numbers by spaces.  Specify "all"
  to mark all messages.  Specify a person by name or db reference # to
  mark all messages from that player.  You can only mark messages in the
  current folder.
  
  You would add /save as a switch to mark a message for being saved instead
  of marking it for deletion.  See 'help mail save' for more.
    
  Examples:
    > mail/mark 1        (mark message 1 for deletion)
    > mail/mark 1 5 8    (mark messages 1, 5, and 8 for deletion)
    > mail/mark all      (mark all your messages for deletion)
    > mail/mark *tinypal (mark messages from player 'tinypal' for deletion)
    > mail/mark #12345   (mark messages from player #12345 for deletion)
    > mail/mark 1-5 8 9  (mark messages 1 through 5, 8, and 9 for deletion)
   
  See Also: mail unmark, mail delete, mail status, mail save
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail massmail
  Topic: mail mass mailing
  
  Massmailing is done by using the optional /SEND feature of the mail
  system.  You may use commas as the delimiter.  The syntax is as follows:
  
  mail[/send] usr1 usr2 .. +<gls> $<gev> &<pls> ~<eval> = [subject//]message
  
    <gls>  -- represents a global alias seen with mail/alias
    <gev>  -- represents a global evaluated alias seen with mail/alias
    <pls>  -- represents an attribute on yourself containing a list of players
    <eval> -- represents a [<obj>/]<attr> to eval like get_eval()
  
  To display to all people in the mail who the message was sent to, add
  a @ before the first name.  For example:
  
     mail @user1 user2 ... userx=message
  
  The subject, which is optional can be added before the message and 
  separated with two /'s.  For example:
  
     mail user=This is my subject//This is the mail I want to send you.
  
  See Also: mail send forward, mail send reply, mail send
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail nall
  This is a sub-option to 'mail/read' (short for just 'mail').  If you
  specify 'nall' at the end, it will read ALL the new mail messages
  you have in your mailbox.
  
  Example:
    > mail/read nall
    > mail nall
  
  See Also: mail ball, mail uall, mail ball, mail new, mail both
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail new
  This is a sub-option to 'mail/read' (short for just 'mail').  If you
  specify 'new' at the end, it will read the FIRST new mail message in
  your mailbox.
  
  Example:
    > mail/read new
    > mail new
  
  See Also: mail ball, mail uall, mail ball, mail unread, mail both
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail next
  Command:  mail/next
  
  This option will automatically view the next mail message from the one
  you last read.  For example, if you typed:
    mail 1 
  
  you would read mail message #1 (if you had mail)
  If you typed:
    mail/next
  
  you would read mail message #2 (if you had that number of messages)
  
  Note:  If you add a '-' after next (i.e. mail/next -) it will read the
         previous message.
  
  See Also: mail status, mail zap, mail read
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail number
  Command: mail/number <target>=# 
   
  This command is similar to the status command.  If someone has set up 
  his mailbox to be shared with you, you can use this command to see the 
  status of the target's mailbox.
   
  As with the status command, the # here is optional.  If it is given
  (in this case the second argument), it will have the same effect as it
  would on the status command.
   
  Examples:
    > mail/number tinyspouse  (list all of tinyspouses mail [if you pass lock])
    > mail/number tinypal=2   (list just message 2 of tinyspouses mail)
   
  See Also: mail status, mail check, mail page, mail share
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail page
  Command: mail/page <value>
  
  This sub-command sets the length of your pages.  When you specify a
  page number in the status and number sub-commands, the pages are 
  each composed of as many mail message headers as you set with the page
  sub-command.
   
  A value of 0 means to not divide the status and number into separate
  pages (i.e. all message headers are displayed on a single page).
   
  Examples:
    > mail/page 20
    > mail/status p1
    > mail/status p2
   
  See Also: mail status, mail number, mail quick
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail password
  Command: mail/password +set=<password>
           mail/password <password>    
           mail/password +set         
  
  The first version of the password sub-command sets your password for
  mail access.  Once you set your password, you must use the second form
  of the password sub-command every time you connect to this mud in
  order to access your mail.  Note that you only have to enter your mail
  password once per login session.  If you have not set a mail password, you
  do not need to enter a password at all to access your mail.
   
  To clear the password, use the +set format with a blank password.
  Your mail password is separate from your login password.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/password +set=appleorange    (set mail password)
    > mail/password appleorrange        (enter password to access mail)
    > mail/password +set                (remove password)
  
  See Also: mail share, mail lock, mail autofor
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail previous
  Command:  mail/next -
  
  Yes, you put a hyphen after the next.  This will in effect view the 
  previous mail message from the one you last read.  For example, if
  you typed:
       mail 5
  
  You would read mail message #5 (if you had mail)
  
  If you typed:
       mail/next -
  
  You would read mail message #4
  
  See Also: mail next, mail zap
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail ptutor
  Topic: mail ptutor (Penn format handler)
  
  Honestly, there's little that this interface changes from the
  default mail handler.  The important things are as follows:
  
  - This requires the PENN_MAIL @toggle to be set on the player
    (@set me=penn_mail)
  - This will change the format of sending mail from the default
    of:
                 mail player(s)=subject//body
    to:
                 mail player(s)=subject/body
  
    Yes, it only removes the extra / in sending.
  
  For all the other Penn-mail syntax, please check your RhostMUSH for
  a @mail compatible wrapper package (available with all RhostMUSHs)
  
  See Also: penn_mail
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail quick
  Command: mail/quick [<folder>]
 
  Get a quick summary of how many new, unread, old, and marked messages
  in the current folder.  Also reports the current folder.
  
  You may specify an optional folder to get quick a quick summary of that
  particular mail folder.
  
  The /quick switch is optional for this command and you can just type 'mail'
  standalone.  The /quick switch is required if you specify a folder.
  
  See Also: mail status, mail
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail quicklist
  Topic: mail quick list of commands (in alphabetical order)
    mail                       - Short for 'mail/quick' or 'mail/status'.
    mail/alias                 - Shows global aliases.
    mail/autofor               - Sets an autoforward to another user.
    mail/check                 - Reads mail in shared mailbox.
    mail/delete                - Purges marked mail.
    mail/forward               - Forwards a mail message.
    mail/lock                  - Locks mail against user(s).
    mail/mark[/save]           - Marks mail to delete (or save).
    mail/next [-]              - Reads next (or previous) message.
    mail/number                - Lists messages in shared mailbox.
    mail/page                  - Sets lines per page.
    mail/password              - Sets mail password.
    mail/quick                 - Gives quick status of your mailbox.
    mail/quota                 - Gives quick quota of your mail ability.
    mail[/read]                - Reads the message (/read switch optional).
    mail/recall                - Recalls a sent message.
    mail/reject                - Sets message to player failing mail lock.
    mail/reply                 - Replies to a mail message.
    mail[/send]                - Sends message (/send switch optional)
    mail/share                 - Allows you to share your mailbox to others.
    mail/status                - Detail listing of messages in your mailbox.
    mail/version               - Displays mail version number.
    mail/write                 - Invokes the line editor
    mail/zap [-]               - Deletes current message and read next/prev.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail quota
  Command:  mail/quota

  Check how many mail messages are in your mailbox, as well as the maximum
  amount of mail messages you are allowed to store in your mailbox.  It
  will also display the total number of saved messages you are allowed
  and the total number of saved messages you currently have used.
  
  See Also: quick, status
  Wizards: wizhelp wmail size
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail read
  Command: mail[/read] <msg #|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N>
           mail/read/save <msg #|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N>
  
  Read a mail message.  You can specify the message number, or to read the 
  first new or unread mail message.  Check help on the status sub-command 
  (wizhelp mail status)for information on how to see mail headers.  The /READ
  switch is optional.  
  
  The optional /save switch when used in junction with the /read switch will
  output the mail in a standard EMail format (MBOX) which you can then save to 
  file and load in your favorite email program (mutt, pine, elm, outlook,
  thunderbird, and so forth).  You would just import the file as an MBOX
  formatted file.  Please refer to your mail program on how to read in this
  mail format.
  
  Optional arguments to 'mail/read[/save]' is as follows:
      mail[/read] +all   - read ALL your messages (spammy)
      mail[/read] new    - read first new message
      mail[/read] nall   - read ALL new messages
      mail[/read] unread - read first unread message
      mail[/read] uall   - read ALL unread messages
      mail[/read] ball   - read ALL new AND unread messages
      mail[/read] X-Y    - read messages starting at 'X' and until 'Y'
      mail[/read] #      - read specified mail message number
 
  Examples:
    > mail/read 2
    > mail 10
    > mail/read new
    > mail new
    > mail/read unread
    > mail/read 3-7
    > mail 2-8
    > mail unread
  
  See Also: mail status, mail delete, mail mark, mail next, mail zap,
            mail unmark, mail save, mail new, mail unread, mail nall, 
            mail ball, mail uall
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail recall
  Command: mail/recall [ <#>|+all|*<player> [=<player>|+all] ]
           mail/recall <various options>
  
  This command will let you recall (IE: delete) unread, unmarked
  messages that you have sent to other players.  It allows you
  you to either list all messages that you have sent that you can currently
  recall, view a specified message that you sent that can be recalled,
  and optionally recall from a single or multiple users or recall all messages.
  
  To view all messages that you can recall:
    mail/recall
  
  This will display something like this:
    Msg #:   1       To: Seawolf Wizard
    Msg #:   8       To: Wizard George Freddie
    Msg #:  10       To: TwinkMan
    Mail: Done
  
  This will show mail you have sent that can still be recalled.  The Msg# may 
  skip numbers if those messages have been previously read and can no longer 
  be recalled.  *NOTE* You may specify a player with '*playername' to limit
  the search on both 'mail/recall' and 'mail/recall/all'.
  
{ To continue [with examples], please type: help mail recall2 }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail recall2
  Command: mail/recall (continued)
  
  To check a message that you can possibly recall, type in:
    mail/recall # (IE: mail/recall 1)
  
  This will display something like this:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    Recall #: 1
    To: Seawolf Wizard
    Date/Time: Mon Nov 1 04:08:32 1992         Size: 233 Bytes
    Subject: Hey!
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    <the message that you sent them>
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    Mail: Done
   
  If you wish to recall this message from the user, Wizard, you would type:
    mail/recall 1=wizard
  
  If you wish to recall this message from everyone, you would type:
    mail/recall 1=+all
  
  if you want to recall all messages you have sent to everyone, you would type:
    mail/recall +all
  
  This will tell you how many messages were successfully recalled. 
  
{ type help mail recall3 to continue }
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail recall3
  Command: mail/recall (continued)
  
  To check all messages that you have sent (but not necessarily recall) use:
    mail/recall/all
  
  You may specify a search by player with the /recall switch with or without
  the /all switch.  Such would be like:
    mail/recall *TinyPlayer
    mail/recall/all *TinyPlayer
  
  The display will display all messages that you have sent.  The only 
  difference will be that some of the messages (probably most of them) you 
  will be unable to recall.  The other functions (like viewing message and who
  it was sent to) should still work.
  
  See Also: mail save, mail send, mail mark, mail unmark
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail reject
  Command: mail/reject <msg>
           mail/reject +list
           mail/reject
  
  Will set the message sent when a player attempts to send a mail message to 
  someone who has that player locked from mailing them.  This works similar
  to the @reject for pages.  To see the current reject message use the 
  +list option.  To clear the message, do mail/reject without a message.
  Use the /lock switch to mail to establish a mail lock.
   
  Examples:
    > mail/reject I don't want you to mail me anymore.  Nayh!
    > mail/reject
    > mail/reject +list
  
  See Also: mail lock
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail reply
  Command: mail/reply [@|^]<msg #>[*]=[<subject>//]<message>.

  Reply to a mail message with your own message.  The @, ^, and * are optional
  to preface or follow the message number.  You can only reply to messages in
  the current folder.  You may also specify an optional subject.
  
  To reply to all recipients of the mail message, in addition to the sender:
     -preface the message number with @ for all recipients of your reply to
      appear in the 'To' line.
     -preface the message number with ^ for all recipients to see only their
      own name in the 'To' line (i.e. not see who else received the reply).
      This is the default.
  
  To include the original message in your reply:
     -follow the message number with *.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/reply 2=Sure, I'll come to the party.  
    > mail/reply 1*=What did you mean?
    > mail/reply @12=Why don't we all get together tomorrow?
    > mail/reply ^9*=I'm not sure if we should build that.
  
  Note:  If you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL, instead of <message> it would be your
         subject.  Then you'd use '-' for additional text and '--' to send.
  
  See Also: mail forward, mail send
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail save
  Command: mail/mark/save <range>
           mail/unmark <range> (notice, you do not use /save with this)
  
  The save switch is used in junction with the MARK switch.  When used,
  this will mark a mail message as SAVED and any autodeletion will
  not remove the mail.  Please note that there is a maximum number of
  saved messages available that you can use and once reached, you are
  unable to save new ones w/o removing one of your prior ones.  To
  unmark the message you may either use mail/mark (without a save)
  or mail/unmark.  Saved mail shows up with a 'S' by the flag.
  
  See Also: mail mark
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail send brandy
  Topic: brandy +mail system
  
  The brandy mailer 'syntax' uses the mail/write (or -) operation for adding
  new lines.  Please refer to 'HELP MAIL WRITE CMDLIST' for a list of commands
  available for writing using the line editor.
  
  You may use, for ONLY this syntax, '--' to send the mail off.  
  If you choose to use mail/write +send=<player-list>, it will override the
  player list you specified originally.
   
  You need the BRANDY_MAIL toggle (@toggle me=brandy_mail) to use this syntax.
  
  You may also optionally set the MAIL_STRIPRETURN toggle to signal the mailer
  to use spaces to separate lines instead of a carriage return.
   
  This effects the commands:  mail, mail/reply, and mail/forward.
  
  Please note that mail/send will send a mail message 'quickly' and bypass
  the line editor.  You may use mail/send to send a message WHILE WRITING
  another message with the line editor.
     
  See Also: BRANDY_MAIL, mail write, mail send quick, mail send brandy
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail send examples
  Command: mail/send
  
  Examples:
    > mail player=how are you?
    > mail myfriend myotherfriend +social &friendlist=Party!!
    > mail/send player=My Subject//My Text I want to send you.
    > mail/send myfriend=Hi.  Meet me tomorrow at the club.
    > mail/send tinypal #12345=Are you coming to the party?
    > mail/send &allfriends=Come to my club for a party tonight. 
    > mail/send ~evaledattr=Where do you want to meet?
    > mail/send +social=Where do you want to meet for the next party?
    > mail/send @myfriend tinypal otherfriend +social=Let's go to the party!
    > mail/send player1 player2 ... playerX=hi!
    > mail/send player1,this is player2,player3,...,playerX=hi!
  
  For those with limited number of input lines, an alternative
  method for writing mail exists.  For information on this,
  read the help files for 'mail write'.  The /SEND switch for mail is
  optional.
  
  See Also: mail write, mail forward, mail reply, mail recall
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail send quick
  Command:  mail/send [@]<address list>=[<subject>//]<message>
  The address list can contain any number of recipients (up to the mush
  buffer limit) and can be one of the following:
      A player name  
      A player number prefixed by a dbrief# 
      A mail alias attribute located on the player prefixed by a & 
         (this is just an attribute on yourself with a list of players)
      A global mail alias attribute prefixed by a +. 
      A mail alias attribute location on optional target prefixed by a
         ~ character.  This is evaluated like get_eval().
  
  The different elements in the address list need to be separated by spaces. 
  If you include the optional '@', all recipients of a mail message will 
  see the complete list of recipients. (This will show up as a 'CC' list).
  To give an optional subject, enter text you want as a subject then 
  separate that from the rest of the message with two /'s. (IE: // )
     
  There is an exception to the '@'.  Check @list options, if the To: is
  automatically added, the '@' character's behavior is reversed.
  
  You can break up mail with either spaces OR commas and duplicates are
  automatically stripped out.
  
{ help mail send2 for more, or help mail send examples for examples }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail send2
  Command: mail/send (CONTINUED)
  
  To use the alias "&alias", you would need an attribute on yourself
  called "alias".  There are no restrictions on the name of the alias,
  except that if the alias doesn't exist on the player calling the
  command or is a bad mush attribute name, the mailer will not accept
  it.  The attribute referenced by the &<alias> is another address
  list, and can also contain other aliases if desired.  Any recursion
  will stop when the mush long_buffer length is reached.  You may also
  use '~' to evaluate the attribute.
  
  Examples: 
    > &FRIENDS me=Seawolf Ashen-Shugar Thorin
    > mail &friends=Hiya!
    > &ONLINE me=[lwho()]
    > mail ~online=hiya!
  
  To use the global alias '+alias', there would have to be a pre-defined
  global attribute defined.  If the global attribute does not exist,
  the input is ignored as an illegal entry.  To have a global alias
  set, notify the nearest royalty or higher of what you wish to use.  The 
  address list can be separated by either spaces or commas.
  
  Examples: 
    > mail/alias
      Alias: wiz
      Contents: Wizard AdminJudge SlothTheWiz
    > mail +wiz=hello!
  
  This would send to the players 'Wizard, AdminJudge, and SlothTheWiz'  
  
  For examples, see: mail send examples
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail sending
  Topic: mail sending
  
  There are three ways that you can send mail with the mail system.  Depending 
  on which way you prefer, this will point you to the correct help files.
  
  1.  Brandy/Mux style mail.  This is when you do 'mail user-list=subject'
      Look at  :  'help mail send brandy' and 'help mail write cmdlist'
      Needed   :  The BRANDY_MAIL toggle (help brandy_mail) 
                  **NOTE**: @toggle me=brandy_mail to set it.
      Syntax   :  mail user(s)=subject
                  mail/reply <msg#>=subject
                  mail/forward <msg#> <user(s)>=subject
      Note:  Brandy/MUX mail wrappers may be in place on your RhostMUSH.
             If it is, you may be able to use @mail like you're used to.
  
  2.  PennMUSH style mail.  This is used for the PennMUSH style mailing.
      Needed   : The BRANDY_MAIL toggle must be UNSET and PENN_MAIL toggle
                 must be set.  BRANDY_MAIL has precidence.
      Syntax   : mail user(s)=subject/body
      Note:  Penn mail wrappers may be in place on your RhostMUSH.  If it is,
             you may be able to use @mail like you're used to.

  3.  RhostMUSH line editor.  This is when you do 'mail/write <start of text>'
      Look at  :  'help mail write' and 'help mail write cmdlist'
      Syntax   :  mail/write Start Of Message
  
  4.  Mailing quickly.  This is when you do 'mail <user-list>=<subj>//<body>'
      Look at  :  'help mail send quick' and 'help mail cmdlist'
      Needed   :  The BRANDY_MAIL toggle must NOT be set. 
                **NOTE**: @toggle me=!brandy_mail to remove it.
      Syntax   :  mail user(s)=Optional Subject//Body
                  mail user(s)=Body
  
  Please check @list options to see what current global settings are enabled
  for the mail system.  Start a sendlist with a , for player's with spaces.
  
  See Also: PENN_MAIL, BRANDY_MAIL, mail write, mail send quick, 
              mail send brandy
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail setup_aliases
  Command:  1. mail/alias  
            2. wmail/alias[</switches>] [<alias-name>=<list of players>]
            3. &ATTRIB me=<list of players> 
            4. &ATTRIB me=<eval returning list of players>
            5. &ALIAS.NAME <mail_def_object>=<eval returning list of players>
            6. &COMMENT.NAME <mail_def_object>=<label description for alias>
  
  There are various types of aliases you can set up.  Below will be described
  each alias and how to set up each kind and use them.
 
  * Global Aliases
    Global aliases can only be created by a wizard.  You can see what global
    aliases exist with 'mail/alias'.  To use a global alias, you would use
    the '+' prefix.  To create global aliases as a wizard, 
    you use the 'wmail/alias' command.
    Example:  mail +wizards=Hi!
    1.  Option '1' above is how you would see all the current global aliases.
    2.  Option '2' above is how a wizard would set a STATIC global alias.
  
  * Personal Aliases
    Personal aliases are actually nothing more than attributes you store on
    yourself.  If you have friends called 'bob' 'terry' and 'james' you would
    set can set the alias like this:  &friends me=bob terry james
    To use the personal STATIC alias, you would use the '&' prefix.
    To use the personal DYNAMIC (eval) alias, you would use the '~' prefix.
    3.  Option '3' above sets a static list of dbref#'s (or player names)
        that will be used as a personal alias you can then use in sending 
        mail with '&'.
        Example: &FRIENDS me=Moe Larry Curley Shemp Joe
                 mail &friends=Hi!
    4.  Option '4' works similar to option 3, except it is a function
        evaluation that then returns a list of player names or dbref#'s to
        use in a mail.  You  may also specify another target other than
        yourself.
        Example: &EVAL_FRIENDS MyObject=[get(Stooges/player_list)]
                 mail ~MyObject/eval_friends=Hi!
   
  * Global Evaluated Aliases
    Evaluated aliases are similiar to static aliases.  When a wizard sets
    these up, they work by evaluation so can be used to set up global
    dynamic aliases.  These are referenced with a '$' prefix.
    This requires that the @admin config parameter 'mail_def_object' is
    defined.
    5.  Option '5' above sets the actual evaluated alias.
    6.  Option '6' just sets a label/description that is shown when a player
        lists the aliases.
        Example:  mail $wizards=Hi!
    
  See Also: help mail send 
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail share
  Command: mail/share <key>
  
  Share lets you give access to your mailbox for other players who pass
  the lock.  The key is a standard boolean lock expression, as documented
  in 'help @lock keys'.
   
  Any player who passes the lock may do the /number and /check
  sub-commands on your mailbox. If you do not have a share lock set on
  your mail, this is the same as if nobody can pass the share lock. To
  clear the lock, enter a blank expression.
   
  If you set a folder/share, players who pass the mail/share lock can
  only see the folder you specify.
   
  Examples:
    > mail/share *tinyspouse             (allows tinyspouse into your mail)
    > mail/share *tinyspouse | *tinypal  (allows tinyspouse and tinypal)
    > mail/share                         (removes the sharelock)
  
  The attribute is 'ShareLock' on yourself.
  
  See Also: mail number, mail check, mail folders, mail folder, mail share
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail signature
  Command: &MAILSIG me=<string>
   
  mail signatures are done by storing a user-defined attribute on yourself.
  the attribute is called 'MAILSIG'.  To set this attribute, you would do:
      &MAILSIG me=whatever you want as your signature.
  
  Please keep in mind that this attribute is *NOT* evaluated for functions and
  is taken as-is.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail status
  Command: mail/status [[p#] [*player] [#-#] [U/N/B/O/M/S] [/SUBJECT]]
  
  This will print out a list of the message headers in the current
  folder for which the player has mail.  This will also show the current
  folder.  The p# argument (where # is an integer) will print out the
  specified page of message headers if the user has his/her paging value
  set.  The page is determined from the paging value entered with the
  page command which represents the number of messages on a page.  If
  the user has no paging value set, entering a page number on this
  command will have no effect.  If the user has a paging value set and
  enters 0 for the page number, the user will get all message headers
  without any page breaks.  
  
  Check out help on 'mail page' to see how to set your paging value.  
  The '*player' option will show all mail sent to you from the given player, 
  and the #-# is a range of messages you would like to see.  The letters 
  U, N, B, O, M, and S are the special character representations for:
     (U)nread             (N)ew                    (B)oth new and unread
     (O)ld                (M)arked (for deletion)  (S)aved
  
  The /SUBJECT option will do a search for mail matching '/SUBJECT' in the
  subject field.  The string after the '/' tells what to search for.
  
{ To continue with examples, see 'help mail status2' }
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail status2
  Command: mail/status (continued)
  
  Mail status looks like the following:
    > mail/status
    ...
    [N] ( 5)  From: Wizard <Sat Nov 5 14:00:05 1994> (113 bytes)
    [R] ( 6) *From: Seawolf <Fri Nov 4 12:23:02 1994> (200 bytes) Fwd
              Subj: In Reply to your mail.
    ...
  
  The letter in brackets indicates the status (old, new, unread, marked, saved)
  The corresponding letter will show what it is (O, N, U, M, S). The
  number following the status indicates the message number.  The status also
  reports who sent the mail, when the mail was sent, and the size of the 
  message.  It also will show if the mail was forwarded, or replied to and any
  optional subjects that were included on the mail message.  New mail becomes 
  unread if you logout without reading it.  The '*' shows the player connected.
  Examples:
    > mail/status          (shows all your mail in your current folder)
    > mail/status p2       (shows second page of your mail [if page is set])
    > mail/status 10-50    (shows messages 10-50 in your mailbox)
    > mail/status 5        (shows just message 5 in your mailbox)
    > mail/status *Seawolf (shows all mail from player Seawolf)
    > mail/status U        (shows all the unread mail in your mailbox)
    > mail/status B        (shows all the unread and new mail in your mailbox)
    > mail/status /biff    (shows mail with subjects containing the word biff)
    > mail/status @folder  (shows all your mail of the specified folder)
  
  See Also: mail number, mail read, mail mark, mail unmark, mail save, 
            mail page
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail technical
  Topic: technical information about the mail system
  
  The mail system was designed years ago and has gone through modifications
  which help compress it's mail storage architecture.  Some of the technical
  information to the mail system is:
  - Multiple sent mail shares a single message for compactability
  - Mail system uses a separate database separate from the MUSH db.
  - Mail system is totally hard-code.  No dependancy on mush version or objs.
  - Folder system is stored along with the mail db separate from the mush db.
  - Mail database can be dumped on-line for cross-platform backups/recovers.
  - Mail database can be loaded on-line (it *will* delete current mail db)
  - Mail system does not suffer corruption and other instabilities that
    softcoded mailers of similar functionality have. (Example: brandy mailer)
  - Allows some user-configurability for ease of use (to be expanded later)
  - Has full featured database recovery suite and index rebuilding incase of
    corruption by some remote off-chance.
  
  Current version of this writing is 2.1.1   Seawolf @ RhostMUSH
  
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail topics
    Available Mail Topics are:
  
    mail-writing           mail-reading            mail-deleting
    mail-folders           mail-admin              mail-reviewing
    mail-sharing           mail-examples           mail-other
    mail-aliases           mail-filtering          mail-attributes
  
    A tutorial can be seen with:
    mail tutorial
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail tutorial
  Topic: mail tutorial
  
  There are two different type of tutors.  The first is if you wish to use
  the brandy mail interface to the system.
  
  The second is if you wish to just get on your feet with the mail system
  and learn the bare-bone basics (non-brandy interface)
  
  For the brandy interface tutorial (+mail & MUX/TM3 @mail), please type:
  
                       help mail btutor
  
  For the penn interface tutorial (Penn @mail), please type:
  
                       help mail ptutor
  
  For the default bare-bone tutorial, please type:
 
                       help mail dtutor
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail uall
  This is a sub-option to 'mail/read' (short for just 'mail').  If you
  specify 'uall' at the end, it will read ALL the unread mail messages
  you have in your mailbox.
  
  Example:
    > mail/read uall
    > mail uall
  
  See Also: mail ball, mail nall, mail new, mail unread, mail both
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail unmark
  Command: mail/unmark <#>|all   (this works for saved messages as well)
  
  This command is similar to mark except that it unmarks messages.  You
  may use mark and unmark to mark all but specific messages.  You can only
  unmark messages in the current folder.  You would use this to unmark SAVED
  messages as well.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/mark all
    > mail/unmark tinyspouse  (These two commands in this order mark
                               all but tinyspouse's messages.)
    > mail/mark tinypal
    > mail/unmark 2 5         (These two commands in this order mark all
                               of tinypal's messages, except messages 2 and 5).
    > mail/unmark 1-5         (unmark messages 1 through 5) 
  
  See Also: mail mark, mail delete, mail status, mail save
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail unread
  This is a sub-option to 'mail/read' (short for just 'mail').  If you
  specify 'unread' at the end, it will read the FIRST unread mail message 
  in your mailbox.
  
  Example:
    > mail/read unread
    > mail unread
  
  See Also: mail uall, mail nall, mail ball, mail new, mail both
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail version
  Command: mail/version
  
  this command will show the current version of the mailsystem.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write
  Topic: mail writing
  
  Note:  For help on creating new mail, please see 'help mail send'
  
  mail/write gives you the flexability of a line-editor within mail.  There
  are various options with mail/write that you may use.  Help is available
  on each of these topics.
  
  Topics:
    ADDING         FORWARDING        QUICKSENDING  CMDLIST    AUTONOTIFY
    EXAMPLES
  
  Write Functionality:
    -         +edit     +del      +join     +justify   +split
    +insert   +list     +forward  +reply    +subject   +forget
    +send     +fedit    +editall  +feditall +cc        +bcc
    +acc      +proof
  
  Type: help mail write <option> for help on these topics/functionality.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +acc
  Command: mail/write +acc=<player-list>
  
  The '+acc' subcommand is used to modify (add to) the target list of
  players the mail is going out to.  Keep in mind, this ONLY works for
  sending or forwarding.  This does *NOT* work for replies.
  
  This only works when you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL and when you
  start a message with 'mail player-list=subject' (or similiar).
  
  Example:
    > mail/write +acc=player1 player2 &myalias +globalalias
    Mail: New send player list stored.
  
  See Also: mail write +cc, mail write +bcc
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +bcc
  Command: mail/write +bcc=<player-list>
  
  The '+bcc' subcommand is used to modify (add to) the target list 
  and blind target list of players the mail is going out to.  Keep 
  in mind, this ONLY works for sending or forwarding.  This does 
  *NOT* work for replies.  If 'bcc_hidden' is ENABLED, then 
  whoever is in the +bcc list will _NOT_ see who the mail was sent
  to.  If 'bcc_hidden' is DISABLED, then whoever is in the +bcc
  list WILL see who the mail was sent to, but no one outside the
  +bcc list will.  In effect, bcc_hidden toggles the effect.
  
  Please check '@list options mail' for the current configuration.
  
  You may specify '!ALL' to clear the Bcc list without effecting
  the To list.
  
  This only works when you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL and when you
  start a message with 'mail player-list=subject' (or similiar).
   
  Example:
    > mail/write +bcc=player1 player2 &myalias +globalalias
    Mail: New send player list stored.
  
  See Also: mail write +cc, mail write +acc
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +cc
  Command: mail/write +cc=<player-list>
  
  The '+cc' subcommand is used to replace (not modify!) the target list of
  players the mail is going out to.  Keep in mind, this ONLY works for
  sending or forwarding.  This does *NOT* work for replies.
  
  This only works when you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL and when you
  start a message with 'mail player-list=subject' (or similiar).
  
  Example:
    > mail/write +cc=player1 player2 &myalias +globalalias ~evalalias
    Mail: New send player list stored.
  
  See Also: mail write +bcc, mail write +acc
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +del
  Command: mail/write +del=<args>
  
  The '+del' subcommand  to mail/write is used to delete a line of text.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write A line of text
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -Another line of txt
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of text
    2: Another line of txt
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +del=1
    Mail: Write line deleted.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: Another line of txt
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  Note: You can't delete line #1 if that's the only line there is.  
        Use mail/write +forget to remove it.
  
  See Also: mail write +edit, mail write +split, mail write +forget
    


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +edit
  Command: mail/write +edit <line>=<old>,<new>
  
  The '+edit' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit a line of text.
  This only edits the FIRST occurance of text in the line.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write A line of text
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -Another line of txt
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of text
    2: Another line of txt
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +edit 2=txt,text
    Mail: +edit done.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of text
    2: Another line of text
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
   
  See Also: mail write +del, mail write +join, mail write +justify 
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +editall
  Command: mail/write +editall=<old>,<new>
  
  The '+editall' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit ALL lines of text.
  This only edits the FIRST occurance of text in the lines.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write A line of txt txt
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -Another line of txt txt
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of txt
    2: Another line of txt
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +editall=txt,text
    Mail: +editall done (2 lines edited)
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of text txt
    2: Another line of text txt
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +feditall, mail write +edit, mail write +fedit
   


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +fedit
  Command: mail/write +fedit <line>=<old>,<new>
  
  The '+fedit' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit a line of text.
  Unlike the '+edit' subcommand, this edits ALL occurances of the text
  in the line.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write A line of text
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -Another line of txt
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of text
    2: Another line of txt
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +fedit 2=txt,text
    Mail: +fedit done.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of text
    2: Another line of text
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
   
  See Also: mail write +del, mail write +join, mail write +justify,
            mail write +fedit, mail write +editall, mail write +feditall
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +feditall
  Command: mail/write +feditall=<old>,<new>
  
  The '+feditall' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit ALL lines of text.
  This edits ALL occurances of text in ALL the lines.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write A line of txt txt
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -Another line of txt txt
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of txt
    2: Another line of txt
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +feditall=txt,text
    Mail: +feditall done (2 lines edited)
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of text text
    2: Another line of text text
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +editall, mail write +edit, mail write +fedit
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +forget
  Command: mail/write +forget
  
  The '+forget' subcommand to mail/write is used to purge the mail in progress
  effectively deleting all of the mail/write information.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write Start of message
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -another line
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    1: Start of message
    2: another line
    > mail/write +forget
    Mail: Write message forgotten.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: No write in progress.
  
  See Also: mail write +edit, mail write +del
    


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +forward
  Command: mail/write +forward=<message number> <player-list>
  
  The '+forward' subcommand to mail/write is used to forward the mail
  in progress to the player list while including the specified message
  number from your mailbox.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write TinyPlayer sent me this... what do you think?
    Mail: Write message started.
    > mail/status
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    [0] ( 1)  From: TinyPlayer      <Mon Jan  1 01:01:01 2000>  (1095 Bytes)
              Subj: Hey!
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
    Note: if the player 'TinyPlayer' was connected, they'd have a '*' before
          the 'From:'.  i.e.  *From: TinyPlayer
  
    > mail/write +forward=1 MyFriend
    Mail: Message sent to -> MyFriend
  
  See Also: mail write +reply, mail write quicksending, mail forward
            mail status
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +insert
  Command: mail/write +insert=<args>
  
  The '+insert' subcommand to mail/write is used to insert a line before
  the specified line.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write Start of mail
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -Third line
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: Start of mail
    2: Third line
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +insert=2,Second line
    Mail: Line inserted.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: Start of mail
    2: Second line
    3: Third line
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +del, mail write +join
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +join
  Command: mail/write +join=<args>
