  The '+join' subcommand to mail/write is used to join two lines of text.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write This is
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -This is the end of the line.
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > -a test
    Mail: Write line 3 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: This is
    2: This is the end of the line.
    3: a test
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +join=1,3
    Mail: Line joined.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: This is a test
    2: This is the end of the line.
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +del, mail write +split
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +justify
  Command: mail/write +justify=<args>
  
  The '+justify' subcommand to mail/write is used to justify the line.
  Valid options are (l)eft, (c)enter, or (r)ight for justification.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write This is a test
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -This is the end of the line.
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > -ok, I lied.
    Mail: Write line 3 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: This is a test
    2: This is the end of the line.
    3: ok, I lied.
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +justify=1,c
    Mail: Line justified.
    > mail/write +justify=2,r
    Mail: Line justified.
    > mail/write +list
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1:                            This is a test
    2:                                          This is the end of the line.
    3: ok, I lied.
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +join, mail write +del
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +list
  Command: mail/write +list [=<args>]
  
  The '+list' subcommand to mail/write is used to list the lines of your
  write message.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: Line one
    2: Line two
    3: Line three
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +list=2
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    2: Line two
    3: Line three
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +list=1,2
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: Line one
    2: Line two
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +forget, mail write +send
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +proof
  Command: mail/write +proof
  
  The '+proof' subcommand to mail/write is used to give you a 'snapshot' of 
  approximately what the mail will look like when it is sent out.  This does
  not show any text that will be included in forwarded or replied to mail
  if you chose the options to include original text.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write This is some text
    Mail: Write message started.
    > mail/write +proof
    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    Message In Progress
    Status: EDITING     From: You
    To: (empty list)
    Date/Time: Mon May 14 18:50:27 2011        Size: 18 Bytes
    Subject: (None)
    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    This is some text
    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +list, mail write
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +reply
  Command: mail/write +reply=<message number>
  
  The '+reply' subcommand to mail/write is used to reply to the specified
  message with the mail that is in progress.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write Thanks for the mail.
    Mail: Write message started.
    > mail/status
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    [0] ( 1)  From: TinyPlayer      <Mon Jan  1 01:01:01 2000>  (1095 Bytes)
              Subj: Hey!
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    Note: if the player 'TinyPlayer' was connected, they'd have a '*' before
          the 'From:'.  i.e.  *From: TinyPlayer
  
    > mail/write +reply=1
    Mail: Message sent to -> TinyPlayer
  
  See Also: mail write +forward, mail write quicksending, mail reply, 
            mail status
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +send
  Command: mail/write +send=<player list>
  
  The '+send' subcommand to mail/write is used to send the mail in progress to
  a list of players.  You may specify a '@' before the player list to send the
  list of players in a seeable 'CC' list.  Otherwise, it's assumed blank
  carbon copies for everyone in the mail list.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write Start of message
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -second line.
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > -third line.
    Mail: Write line 3 added
    > mail/write +send=@tinyplayer tinywizard
    Mail: Message sent to -> TinyPlayer
    Mail: Message sent to -> TinyWizard
  
  See Also: mail write +reply, mail write +forward, mail send, mail forward,
            mail reply, mail status
    


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +split
  Command: mail/write +split=<args>
  
  The '+split' subcommand to mail/write is used to split a line after the
  specified word.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write Start of mail
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -Second line Third line
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: Start of mail
    2: Second line Third line
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +split=2,2
    Mail: Line split.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: Start of mail
    2: Second line
    3: Third line
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +justify, mail write +join, mail write +del
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write +subject
  Command: mail/write +subject=<subject>
  
  The '+subject' subcommand to mail/write is used to set a subject line for
  your mail message.  You may use this command to also re-set it to something
  else if you so desire.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write Start of message
    Mail: Write message started.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    1: Start of message
    > mail/write +subject=My Subject
    Mail: Write subject set
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    Subject: My Subject
    1: Start of message
    
  See Also: mail write +send, mail write -, mail write +forget
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write -
  Command: mail/write <text>
           -<text>
  
  The '-' subcommand is used to continue lines of text after the initial
  'mail/write' was used to start the mail message.  This is used in
  juncture with sending, forwarding, or replying to mail using the
  line editor.  This command will NOT be recognized as a valid command
  if you did not use mail/write previous to it!
  
  Example:
    > -this is a line of text
    Huh?  (Type 'help' for help.)
    > mail/write I forgot to start the message first!
    Mail: Write message started (37/32758).
    > -this is a line of text
    Mail: Write line 2 added (60/32758)
    > mail/write another line of text
    Mail: Write line 3 added (81/32758)
  
  See Also: mail write cmdlist, mail write adding
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write adding
  Topic: mail write adding text
  
  There are two ways to write mail using the mail/write method.  You can
  use mail/write to save text, or, after using mail/write for the first
  line (to initialize the mail message being written) you may use a '-'
  to continue writing lines of text.
  
    mail/write (used to initialize mail writing and write first line)
    -          (can be used instead of mail/write to write additional lines)
    mail/write +subject=<text> (used to add the subject)
  
  Example:
    > mail/write My first line of the mail
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -My second line of the mail
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +subject=My Subject
    Mail: Write subject set
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    Subject: My Subject
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: My first line of the mail
    2: My second line of the mail
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail send, mail write forwarding
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write autonotify
  Topic: mail write auto notification
  
  If for whatever reason you got disconnected during a mail write, you will
  be notified that you have a mail write in progress.  Just type 
  
    mail/write +list
  
  And you will see what the message you have in progress is.  If you want
  to purge it, just type
  
    mail/write +forget
  
  And the message will be forgotten (purged/tossed).
  
  See Also: mail write cmdlist
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write cmdlist
  Topic: mail write command list
  
  mail/write <message>                           - Start new mail/Add new line
  -                                              - Add new line of text
  mail/write +edit <line #>=<old txt>,<new txt>  - Edit first text on line
  mail/write +fedit <line #>=<old txt>,<new txt> - Edit all text on line
  mail/write +editall=<old text>,<new text>      - Edit first text everywhere
  mail/write +feditall=<old text>,<new text>     - Edit all text everywhere
  mail/write +cc=<player list>                   * resets player list
  mail/write +bcc=<player list>                  * Adds to player and bcc list
  mail/write +acc=<player list>                  * Adds to player list
  mail/write +del=<line #>                       - Delete line
  mail/write +join=<line #>,<line #>             - Join lines
  mail/write +justify=<line #>,[l,r,c]           - Justify the line
  mail/write +split=<line #>,<after word #>      - Split line at character
  mail/write +insert=<line #>,<text>             - Insert text at line
  mail/write +list [=<line #>,<line #>]          - List line(s) (proofs)
  mail/write +proof                              - Displays in 'sent' format.
  mail/write +send=[@]<player list>              - Send mail to players
  mail/write +forward=<mail #> [@] <player list> - Forward mail to players
  mail/write +reply=<mail #>                     - Replys to sender (sends)
  mail/write +subject=<text>                     - Add (change) subject
  mail/write +forget                             - Toss the mail in progress
  
  Topics with '*' only work with the BRANDY_MAIL interface. 
  
  This is the 'editor' way to send, forward, or reply to mail. 
  for descriptions, type: help mail write cmdlist2
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write cmdlist2
  Topic: mail write command list (continued)
  
  The first format (mail/write <message>) will start a new message or append 
  the message to an existing message in the mail editor.  If you have the 
  BRANDY_MAIL toggle set, you may initiate the line editor with 
  'mail player-list=subject'.
  
  To change text, use the +edit sub-command of write to change <old text> to 
  <new text>.  You can't use braces to group the old and new text, but you can 
  use angle brackets (<>) to group the old text. Use +list to check the 
  current status of the message.  See 'help mail line' for information on 
  line editing.
  
  To send the message, or send it as a reply or part of a forwarded message,
  use the +send, +reply, or +forward sub-commands of write.  To cancel
  (erase) the current message in the editor, use the +forget sub-command.
  You can only +reply to and +forward messages in the current folder.
  To add a subject (or remove it) use the +subject option with write.
   
  For examples: help mail write examples.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write examples
  Topic: mail write examples
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write I am sending you a long message.
    > mail/write It just goes on and on.
    > -And I can use the '-' to continue adding lines of text!
    > mail/write +edit 1=long,very long
    > mail/write +list
    > mail/write +subject=Read this!
    > mail/write +send=tinypal tinyfriend
   
  This message would read: 
  I am sending you a very long message.
  It just goes on and on.
  And I can use the '-' to continue adding lines of text!
  
  It would also have a subject of 'Read This!'.
   
  See Also: mail send, mail forward, mail reply
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write forwarding
  Topic: mail write forwarding
  
  To forward mail using the line editor, it takes a bit of reverse logic.
  You must FIRST start writing the message, THEN you specify you want
  to forward it to the player list.
  
    mail/write (used to initialize mail writing and write first line)
    -          (can be used instead of mail/write to write additional lines)
    mail/write +forward=<message #> [@] <player list>
  
  The last line will forward your message to the specified player list and
  include the message# of the message in your mailbox.
  
  See help on mail write +forward for more information on the forward command.
  
  See Also: mail write +forward, mail write +reply, mail write
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail write quicksending
  Topic: mail write quicksending
  
  To send mail quickly, you can use the default behavior of mail.  The
  syntax for a quick message is as follows:
  
    mail/send [@] <player-list> = [optional subject//] Message Body
  
  This fires off the mail without initiating the line editor.
  
  The /send switch is optional, unless you are toggled BRANDY_MAIL, in
  which case, the /send switch is required.
  
  Yes, you can use a quick message to send a mail message while in the
  middle of a line editor in writing a different mail message.
   
  See Also: mail send, mail
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail writing
  Please see 'help mail send'
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail zap
  Command:  mail/zap
  
  This option will automatically mark the present message and view the 
  next message.  For example, if you typed:
    mail 1
  
  you would read mail message #1 (if you had mail)
  If you typed:
    mail/zap
  
  You would mark message #1 for deletion and read message #2
  (if you had two messages, in which it would only mark #1 and return
   that you had no more mail to read)
  
  Note:  If you add a '-' after zap (i.e. mail/zap -) it will read the
         previous message.
  
  See Also: mail status, mail next, mail mark, mail delete, mail read
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail-admin
  See 'wizhelp mail' and 'wizhelp wmail'.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail-aliases
  There are multiple ways to have aliases in RhostMUSH.  The standard method
  is for global mail aliases.  Only wizards may set, modify, or remove global
  mail aliases.  You may see global mail aliases by typing:
  
                               mail/alias
  
  This command will show all the global mail alises, if it's a static mail
  alias or a dynamic mail alias, or if there's any locks that make it so
  you can not use them.  To use a static mail alias, you would prepend a '+'
  before the alias.  Such as:
  
                               mail +wizards=To all Wizards!
  
  For dynamic mail aliases, you would prepend a '$' before the alias.
  
                               mail $wizards=To all Wizards!
  
  You will see with mail/alias if it's a static global (+) or a dynamic
  global ($) mail alias to help avoid confusion.
  
  {see 'help mail-aliases2' for personal mail aliases}
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail-aliases2
  There is a third method for aliases.  These are considered personal mail
  aliases, and anyone may set them.  To set them, you just store an attribute
  on yourself containing a list of players.  This field can not be evaluated.
  An example of a personal mail alias would be:
  
                               &myfriends me=Bob Sarah #456 Julie
                               @set me=myfriends:Bob Sarah #456 Julie
  
  Either sets an alias for Bob, Sarah, player #456, and Julie.  Any non-players
  will automatically be stripped in the sending of the mail (with appropiate
  warning messages).  To use a personal alias, you would use the key field
  '&' to identify to the mail system that it is a personal mail alias.
  
                               mail &myfriends=To all of my friends!
  
  For help on setting attributes, please check help for '&' or '@set'.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail-attributes
  Topic: MAIL ATTRIBUTES
  
  The following attributes have special meaning in the mail system.
    @mailsig     -- The signature that is assigned to any mail sent.
    &mailfilter  -- This is evaluated to auto-filter what folder mail goes to.
    &mailnotify  -- This is evaluated to auto-send notification to senders.
    @mailtime    -- (Wizard only) Sets the auto-delete time on a player.
    @mailsmax    -- (Wizard only) Sets the maximum saved messages on a player.
    MailLock     -- (Internal) This is the lock mail/lock sets
  
  The following wildcard patterns are used for mail:
    mail &foo=text    -- This will check your personal FOO attribute for
                         the player list you want to send to.
                         This is non-evaluated.
    mail ~foo=text    -- This will check your personal FOO attribute for
                         the player list you want to send to.
                         This is evaluated.
  
  See Also: @mailsig, &mailfilter, &mailnotify, mail lock, mail setup_aliases
  For wizards, wizhelp: @mailsmax, @mailtime



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail-deleting
  The following is used to delete mail:
  1) mail/mark <range|message|*player>        [help mail mark]
     - This marks the message(s) for deleting.
  2) mail/mark/save <range|message|*player>   [help mail save]
     - This marks the message(s) for saving from deleting.
  3) mail/unmark <range|message|*player>      [help mail unmark]
     - This removes the mark from the message
  4) mail/unmark <range|message|*player>      [help mail save]
     - This removes the saved mark from the message
  5) mail/delete                              [help mail delete]
     - This purges the mail that was marked.
  6) mail/status
     - This lists your mail (with the marks)
  
  See Also: mail mark, mail save, mail unmark, mail delete, mail status
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail-examples
  See 'help mail write cmdlist', 'help mail cmdlist', 'help mail quicklist',
      'help folder cmdlist'
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail-filtering
  You can specify mail filtering by using the MAILFILTER attribute.  This
  allows you filter incoming mail by either the target player or the subject.
  If the mail was sent anonymously, the player is returned as #-1, otherwise
  the dbref# of the player will be returned.
  
  For detailed help, see help for MAILFILTER
  
  See Also: MAILFILTER
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail-folders
  The folders command are controlled with the 'folder' command.
  
  Please refer to 'help folder cmdlist' for the listing.
  
  See Also: mail main, mail topics, mail cmdlist
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail-other
  See 'help mail cmdlist', 'help mail quicklist', 'help mail write cmdlist', 
      'help folder cmdlist'
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail-reading
  The following commands are used to read the mail:
  1) mail new                    [help mail new]
     - This reads the first new message
  2) mail nall                   [help mail nall]
     - This reads ALL new mail messages (can be spammy).
  3) mail unread                 [help mail unread]
     - This reads the first unread message
  4) mail uall                   [help mail uall]
     - This reads ALL unread mail messages (can be spammy).
  5) mail both                   [help mail both]
     - This reads the first new OR unread message
  6) mail ball                   [help mail ball]
     - This reads BOTH ALL unread AND new mail messages (can be spammy).
  7) mail #                      [help mail read]
     - This reads the specified message #.
  8) mail/status                 [help mail status]
     - This displays all the mail in your mailbox
  9) mail/quick                  [help mail quick]
     - This gives you a quick status of your mailbox.
 10) mail +all
     - This will read all your mail.
 11) mail/read/save 
     - This option will output mail in an MBOX format
  
  See Also: mail quick, mail status, mail read, mail topics, mail main
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail-reviewing
  The following is used for reviewing mail:
  1) mail/status                              [help mail staus]
     - List your mail
  2) mail/quick                               [help mail quick]
     - Gives status report of mailbox
  3) mail/recall                              [help mail recall]
     - Shows listing of all mail you sent that's not been read
  4) mail/recall #                           
     - Views the sent message
  5) mail/recall #=[+all|player(s)]
     - Yanks the specified player(s) (or all) from receiving the mail.
  
  See Also: mail recall, mail quick, mail status
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail-sharing
  The following commands are used to share a mailbox with a friend:
  1) mail/share <key>              [help mail share]
     - You may refer to 'help @lock keys' on how to set this.
  2) folder/share <mailbox>        [help folder share]
     - This identifies what folder(s) you wish to share.  Those who
       pass the mail/share lock above, will be able to see the folders.
  3) mail/number <player>          [help mail number]
     - This lists the message(s) of the player you're sharing mail with.
  4) mail/check <player>=<message> [help mail check]
     - This reads the specified message in player's shared folders
       Note: all folders are combined that you can share.
  
  See Also: mail share, folder share, mail topics, mail main
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail-writing
  The following commands exist for writing new mail messages:
  1) Brandy/@mail
     A) @toggle me=brandy_mail mail_stripreturn       [set up interface]
     B) mail[/forward|reply] <player(s)>=<subj>       [start message]
     C) -<new line of text>                           [add new text]
     D) mail/write +feditall=old,new                  [edit text]
     E) mail/write +forget                            [toss message]
     F) mail/write +subject=<text>                    [reset the subject]
     G) mail/write +acc=<players>                     [append to players]
     H) mail/write +cc=<players>                      [reset the players]
     I-1) --                                          [send off mail] (or)
     I-2) -~                                          [send mail anonymously]
     J) mail/send <player(s)>=<subject>//<body>       [quick-send of mail]
  2) PENN @mail
     A) @toggle me=!brandy_mail penn_mail             [set up interface]
     B) mail <player-list>=<subject>/<body>           [send message]
  3) Seawolf(Rhost) Mail
     A)  mail <player-list>=<subject>//<body>         [send mail - type 1]
     B1) mail/write <start of text>                   [first line of text]
     B2) -<new line of text>                          [add new text]
     B3) mail/write +subject=<subject>                [set subject]
     B4) mail/write [+send|+forward|+reply]=<players> [send message - type 2]
     B5) mail/write/anon [+send|+forward|+reply]=<pl> [send anonymously -tp 3]
  
  See Also: mail main, mail topics, mail cmdlist, mail write cmdlist
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/alias
  Command: mail/alias
  
  The alias switch is used to display any global alias you have 
  permission to access and will list all players that are attached
  to that global alias.  Global aliases are maintained by the 
  administration of the mush.  If you have ideas of global aliases,
  suggest it to them and they will add them.
  
  Syntax: mail/alias
  Wizards: wizhelp wmail alias
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/anonymous
  Command: mail/anon player=message
           mail/anon/send player=message
           mail/anon/forward <msg#> player=message
           mail/anon/reply <msg#>=message
  
  The anon[ymous] switch is used in junction with the /send, /forward, or
  /reply switches (or normal sending) to ANONYMOUSLY send the mail message
  to the player.  Wizards are except from receiving anonymous mail due to
  security issues.
  
  Attempting to forward anonymous mail shows the original message being
  'anonymous'.  Attempting to reply to an anonymous mail will reply 
  to the 'anonymous' player, while that player still receives the message.
  
  If you use the line editor, you can use -~ to send anonymously instead of
  -- which would normally send the mail.
   
  See Also: mail send, mail reply, mail forward
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/autofor
  Command: mail/autofor <player-name>
           mail/autofor +off
  
  Autoforwarding is used to autoforward mail that you would normally get
  to another player.  This is handy in the event that you have
  multiple players and wish to have mail all catagorized to a central
  player.  All forwarded mail is sent as from the original sender, 
  not from the player it was forwarded from.
  
  Autoforwarding can only be forwarded on a one-time basis.  It is not
  recursive.  So in otherwords, you can not forward mail forwarded to you.
  
  To remove an autoforwarding use the command:
      mail/autofor +off
  
  Mail that is autoforwarded will show up to the user sending you mail
  where it got autoforwarded to.
  
  See Also: mail lock, mail share
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/check
  Command: mail/check <target>=<#>
  
  If someone has set up her mailbox to be shared with you, you can use this
  command to read a particular message from the target's mailbox.
   
  Example:
    > mail/check tinyfriend=4    (read tinyfriend's message #4)
   
  See Also: mail read, mail number, mail share
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/delete
  Command: mail/delete
  
  This command will delete all your marked messages in all your folders.
  
  See Also: mark, unmark, recall, save
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/forward
  Command: mail/forward <msg #> [@|^]<list> [=[<subject>//]<additional text>]
  
  Forward a mail message to someone.  Note that you do not have to include your
  own message, which is appended to the bottom of the message.  The
  message number and the address list are separated by a space.  For the
  format of the address list, see the help on the send sub-command
  (help mail send).  You can only forward messages in the current folder.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/forward 3 myfriend
    > mail/forward 2 &friendlist=Weird!!!//What do you think of this?
    > mail/forward 12 @friend1 #12345 friend2=Can you believe this?!
  
  Note:  If you have the BRANDY_MAIL @toggle set, the syntax would be this:
    > mail/forward 3 myfriend
    > mail/forward 2 &friendlist=My Subject
    > mail/forward 12 @friend1 #12345 friend2=This is a subject
  
  You'd then use '-' for additional text and '--' to send the mail.
  
  See Also: mail reply, mail send
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/lock
  Command: mail/lock <key>
  
  You can lock your mailbox so that only certain people can (or cannot)
  send you mail.  The key is the same as for any other lock.  Type:
  
                       'help @lock keys' 
  
  for a list of the keys you may use.  To unlock, use a
  blank key.  IE: mail/lock  (this will unlock your mail lock)
  
  Examples:
    > mail/lock tinyspouse  (this locks to just tinyspouse)
    > mail/lock !tinyjerk   (this locks against tinyjerk)
    > mail/lock             (this removes your mail lock)
   
  The attribute it sets on you is 'MailLock' and is set like a normal lock.
   
  See Also: mail reject, mail recall
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/mark
  Command: mail/mark <#>|all|<*player>
  
  This command allows you to mark messages for deletion.  <#> indicates
  a specific message to be marked.  To delete more than one message by
  message number, separate the message numbers by spaces.  Specify "all"
  to mark all messages.  Specify a person by name or db reference # to
  mark all messages from that player.  You can only mark messages in the
  current folder.
  
  You would add /save as a switch to mark a message for being saved instead
  of marking it for deletion.  See 'help mail save' for more.
    
  Examples:
    > mail/mark 1        (mark message 1 for deletion)
    > mail/mark 1 5 8    (mark messages 1, 5, and 8 for deletion)
    > mail/mark all      (mark all your messages for deletion)
    > mail/mark *tinypal (mark messages from player 'tinypal' for deletion)
    > mail/mark #12345   (mark messages from player #12345 for deletion)
    > mail/mark 1-5 8 9  (mark messages 1 through 5, 8, and 9 for deletion)
   
  See Also: mail unmark, mail delete, mail status, mail save
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/mark/save
  Command: mail/mark/save <range>
           mail/unmark <range> (notice, you do not use /save with this)
  
  The save switch is used in junction with the MARK switch.  When used,
  this will mark a mail message as SAVED and any autodeletion will
  not remove the mail.  Please note that there is a maximum number of
  saved messages available that you can use and once reached, you are
  unable to save new ones w/o removing one of your prior ones.  To
  unmark the message you may either use mail/mark (without a save)
  or mail/unmark.  Saved mail shows up with a 'S' by the flag.
  
  See Also: mail mark
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/next
  Command:  mail/next
  
  This option will automatically view the next mail message from the one
  you last read.  For example, if you typed:
    mail 1 
  
  you would read mail message #1 (if you had mail)
  If you typed:
    mail/next
  
  you would read mail message #2 (if you had that number of messages)
  
  Note:  If you add a '-' after next (i.e. mail/next -) it will read the
         previous message.
  
  See Also: mail status, mail zap, mail read
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/number
  Command: mail/number <target>=# 
   
  This command is similar to the status command.  If someone has set up 
  his mailbox to be shared with you, you can use this command to see the 
  status of the target's mailbox.
   
  As with the status command, the # here is optional.  If it is given
  (in this case the second argument), it will have the same effect as it
  would on the status command.
   
  Examples:
    > mail/number tinyspouse  (list all of tinyspouses mail [if you pass lock])
    > mail/number tinypal=2   (list just message 2 of tinyspouses mail)
   
  See Also: mail status, mail check, mail page, mail share
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/page
  Command: mail/page <value>
  
  This sub-command sets the length of your pages.  When you specify a
  page number in the status and number sub-commands, the pages are 
  each composed of as many mail message headers as you set with the page
  sub-command.
   
  A value of 0 means to not divide the status and number into separate
  pages (i.e. all message headers are displayed on a single page).
   
  Examples:
    > mail/page 20
    > mail/status p1
    > mail/status p2
   
  See Also: mail status, mail number, mail quick
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/password
  Command: mail/password +set=<password>
           mail/password <password>    
           mail/password +set         
  
  The first version of the password sub-command sets your password for
  mail access.  Once you set your password, you must use the second form
  of the password sub-command every time you connect to this mud in
  order to access your mail.  Note that you only have to enter your mail
  password once per login session.  If you have not set a mail password, you
  do not need to enter a password at all to access your mail.
   
  To clear the password, use the +set format with a blank password.
  Your mail password is separate from your login password.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/password +set=appleorange    (set mail password)
    > mail/password appleorrange        (enter password to access mail)
    > mail/password +set                (remove password)
  
  See Also: mail share, mail lock, mail autofor
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/previous
  Command:  mail/next -
  
  Yes, you put a hyphen after the next.  This will in effect view the 
  previous mail message from the one you last read.  For example, if
  you typed:
       mail 5
  
  You would read mail message #5 (if you had mail)
  
  If you typed:
       mail/next -
  
  You would read mail message #4
  
  See Also: mail next, mail zap
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/quick
  Command: mail/quick [<folder>]
 
  Get a quick summary of how many new, unread, old, and marked messages
  in the current folder.  Also reports the current folder.
  
  You may specify an optional folder to get quick a quick summary of that
  particular mail folder.
  
  The /quick switch is optional for this command and you can just type 'mail'
  standalone.  The /quick switch is required if you specify a folder.
  
  See Also: mail status, mail
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/quota
  Command:  mail/quota

  Check how many mail messages are in your mailbox, as well as the maximum
  amount of mail messages you are allowed to store in your mailbox.  It
  will also display the total number of saved messages you are allowed
  and the total number of saved messages you currently have used.
  
  See Also: quick, status
  Wizards: wizhelp wmail size
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/read
  Command: mail[/read] <msg #|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N>
           mail/read/save <msg #|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N>
  
  Read a mail message.  You can specify the message number, or to read the 
  first new or unread mail message.  Check help on the status sub-command 
  (wizhelp mail status)for information on how to see mail headers.  The /READ
  switch is optional.  
  
  The optional /save switch when used in junction with the /read switch will
  output the mail in a standard EMail format (MBOX) which you can then save to 
  file and load in your favorite email program (mutt, pine, elm, outlook,
  thunderbird, and so forth).  You would just import the file as an MBOX
  formatted file.  Please refer to your mail program on how to read in this
  mail format.
  
  Optional arguments to 'mail/read[/save]' is as follows:
      mail[/read] +all   - read ALL your messages (spammy)
      mail[/read] new    - read first new message
      mail[/read] nall   - read ALL new messages
      mail[/read] unread - read first unread message
      mail[/read] uall   - read ALL unread messages
      mail[/read] ball   - read ALL new AND unread messages
      mail[/read] X-Y    - read messages starting at 'X' and until 'Y'
      mail[/read] #      - read specified mail message number
 
  Examples:
    > mail/read 2
    > mail 10
    > mail/read new
    > mail new
    > mail/read unread
    > mail/read 3-7
    > mail 2-8
    > mail unread
  
  See Also: mail status, mail delete, mail mark, mail next, mail zap,
            mail unmark, mail save, mail new, mail unread, mail nall, 
            mail ball, mail uall
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/read/save
  Command: mail[/read] <msg #|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N>
           mail/read/save <msg #|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N>
  
  Read a mail message.  You can specify the message number, or to read the 
  first new or unread mail message.  Check help on the status sub-command 
  (wizhelp mail status)for information on how to see mail headers.  The /READ
  switch is optional.  
  
  The optional /save switch when used in junction with the /read switch will
  output the mail in a standard EMail format (MBOX) which you can then save to 
  file and load in your favorite email program (mutt, pine, elm, outlook,
  thunderbird, and so forth).  You would just import the file as an MBOX
  formatted file.  Please refer to your mail program on how to read in this
  mail format.
  
  Optional arguments to 'mail/read[/save]' is as follows:
      mail[/read] +all   - read ALL your messages (spammy)
      mail[/read] new    - read first new message
      mail[/read] nall   - read ALL new messages
      mail[/read] unread - read first unread message
      mail[/read] uall   - read ALL unread messages
      mail[/read] ball   - read ALL new AND unread messages
      mail[/read] X-Y    - read messages starting at 'X' and until 'Y'
      mail[/read] #      - read specified mail message number
 
  Examples:
    > mail/read 2
    > mail 10
    > mail/read new
    > mail new
    > mail/read unread
    > mail/read 3-7
    > mail 2-8
    > mail unread
  
  See Also: mail status, mail delete, mail mark, mail next, mail zap,
            mail unmark, mail save, mail new, mail unread, mail nall, 
            mail ball, mail uall
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/recall
  Command: mail/recall [ <#>|+all|*<player> [=<player>|+all] ]
           mail/recall <various options>
  
  This command will let you recall (IE: delete) unread, unmarked
  messages that you have sent to other players.  It allows you
  you to either list all messages that you have sent that you can currently
  recall, view a specified message that you sent that can be recalled,
  and optionally recall from a single or multiple users or recall all messages.
  
  To view all messages that you can recall:
    mail/recall
  
  This will display something like this:
    Msg #:   1       To: Seawolf Wizard
    Msg #:   8       To: Wizard George Freddie
    Msg #:  10       To: TwinkMan
    Mail: Done
  
  This will show mail you have sent that can still be recalled.  The Msg# may 
  skip numbers if those messages have been previously read and can no longer 
  be recalled.  *NOTE* You may specify a player with '*playername' to limit
  the search on both 'mail/recall' and 'mail/recall/all'.
  
{ To continue [with examples], please type: help mail recall2 }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/reject
  Command: mail/reject <msg>
           mail/reject +list
           mail/reject
  
  Will set the message sent when a player attempts to send a mail message to 
  someone who has that player locked from mailing them.  This works similar
  to the @reject for pages.  To see the current reject message use the 
  +list option.  To clear the message, do mail/reject without a message.
  Use the /lock switch to mail to establish a mail lock.
   
  Examples:
    > mail/reject I don't want you to mail me anymore.  Nayh!
    > mail/reject
    > mail/reject +list
  
  See Also: mail lock
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/reply
  Command: mail/reply [@|^]<msg #>[*]=[<subject>//]<message>.

  Reply to a mail message with your own message.  The @, ^, and * are optional
  to preface or follow the message number.  You can only reply to messages in
  the current folder.  You may also specify an optional subject.
  
  To reply to all recipients of the mail message, in addition to the sender:
     -preface the message number with @ for all recipients of your reply to
      appear in the 'To' line.
     -preface the message number with ^ for all recipients to see only their
      own name in the 'To' line (i.e. not see who else received the reply).
      This is the default.
  
  To include the original message in your reply:
     -follow the message number with *.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/reply 2=Sure, I'll come to the party.  
    > mail/reply 1*=What did you mean?
    > mail/reply @12=Why don't we all get together tomorrow?
    > mail/reply ^9*=I'm not sure if we should build that.
  
  Note:  If you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL, instead of <message> it would be your
         subject.  Then you'd use '-' for additional text and '--' to send.
  
  See Also: mail forward, mail send
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/save
  Command: mail/mark/save <range>
           mail/unmark <range> (notice, you do not use /save with this)
  
  The save switch is used in junction with the MARK switch.  When used,
  this will mark a mail message as SAVED and any autodeletion will
  not remove the mail.  Please note that there is a maximum number of
  saved messages available that you can use and once reached, you are
  unable to save new ones w/o removing one of your prior ones.  To
  unmark the message you may either use mail/mark (without a save)
  or mail/unmark.  Saved mail shows up with a 'S' by the flag.
  
  See Also: mail mark
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/save/read
  Command: mail[/read] <msg #|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N>
           mail/read/save <msg #|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N>
  
  Read a mail message.  You can specify the message number, or to read the 
  first new or unread mail message.  Check help on the status sub-command 
  (wizhelp mail status)for information on how to see mail headers.  The /READ
  switch is optional.  
  
  The optional /save switch when used in junction with the /read switch will
  output the mail in a standard EMail format (MBOX) which you can then save to 
  file and load in your favorite email program (mutt, pine, elm, outlook,
  thunderbird, and so forth).  You would just import the file as an MBOX
  formatted file.  Please refer to your mail program on how to read in this
  mail format.
  
  Optional arguments to 'mail/read[/save]' is as follows:
      mail[/read] +all   - read ALL your messages (spammy)
      mail[/read] new    - read first new message
      mail[/read] nall   - read ALL new messages
      mail[/read] unread - read first unread message
      mail[/read] uall   - read ALL unread messages
      mail[/read] ball   - read ALL new AND unread messages
      mail[/read] X-Y    - read messages starting at 'X' and until 'Y'
      mail[/read] #      - read specified mail message number
 
  Examples:
    > mail/read 2
    > mail 10
    > mail/read new
    > mail new
    > mail/read unread
    > mail/read 3-7
    > mail 2-8
    > mail unread
  
  See Also: mail status, mail delete, mail mark, mail next, mail zap,
            mail unmark, mail save, mail new, mail unread, mail nall, 
            mail ball, mail uall
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/send
  Command:  mail/send [@]<address list>=[<subject>//]<message>
  The address list can contain any number of recipients (up to the mush
  buffer limit) and can be one of the following:
      A player name  
      A player number prefixed by a dbrief# 
      A mail alias attribute located on the player prefixed by a & 
         (this is just an attribute on yourself with a list of players)
      A global mail alias attribute prefixed by a +. 
      A mail alias attribute location on optional target prefixed by a
         ~ character.  This is evaluated like get_eval().
  
  The different elements in the address list need to be separated by spaces. 
  If you include the optional '@', all recipients of a mail message will 
  see the complete list of recipients. (This will show up as a 'CC' list).
  To give an optional subject, enter text you want as a subject then 
  separate that from the rest of the message with two /'s. (IE: // )
     
  There is an exception to the '@'.  Check @list options, if the To: is
  automatically added, the '@' character's behavior is reversed.
  
  You can break up mail with either spaces OR commas and duplicates are
  automatically stripped out.
  
{ help mail send2 for more, or help mail send examples for examples }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/share
  Command: mail/share <key>
  
  Share lets you give access to your mailbox for other players who pass
  the lock.  The key is a standard boolean lock expression, as documented
  in 'help @lock keys'.
   
  Any player who passes the lock may do the /number and /check
  sub-commands on your mailbox. If you do not have a share lock set on
  your mail, this is the same as if nobody can pass the share lock. To
  clear the lock, enter a blank expression.
   
  If you set a folder/share, players who pass the mail/share lock can
  only see the folder you specify.
   
  Examples:
    > mail/share *tinyspouse             (allows tinyspouse into your mail)
    > mail/share *tinyspouse | *tinypal  (allows tinyspouse and tinypal)
    > mail/share                         (removes the sharelock)
  
  The attribute is 'ShareLock' on yourself.
  
  See Also: mail number, mail check, mail folders, mail folder, mail share
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/status
  Command: mail/status [[p#] [*player] [#-#] [U/N/B/O/M/S] [/SUBJECT]]
  
  This will print out a list of the message headers in the current
  folder for which the player has mail.  This will also show the current
  folder.  The p# argument (where # is an integer) will print out the
  specified page of message headers if the user has his/her paging value
  set.  The page is determined from the paging value entered with the
  page command which represents the number of messages on a page.  If
  the user has no paging value set, entering a page number on this
  command will have no effect.  If the user has a paging value set and
  enters 0 for the page number, the user will get all message headers
  without any page breaks.  
  
  Check out help on 'mail page' to see how to set your paging value.  
  The '*player' option will show all mail sent to you from the given player, 
  and the #-# is a range of messages you would like to see.  The letters 
  U, N, B, O, M, and S are the special character representations for:
     (U)nread             (N)ew                    (B)oth new and unread
     (O)ld                (M)arked (for deletion)  (S)aved
  
  The /SUBJECT option will do a search for mail matching '/SUBJECT' in the
  subject field.  The string after the '/' tells what to search for.
  
{ To continue with examples, see 'help mail status2' }
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/unmark
  Command: mail/unmark <#>|all   (this works for saved messages as well)
  
  This command is similar to mark except that it unmarks messages.  You
  may use mark and unmark to mark all but specific messages.  You can only
  unmark messages in the current folder.  You would use this to unmark SAVED
  messages as well.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/mark all
    > mail/unmark tinyspouse  (These two commands in this order mark
                               all but tinyspouse's messages.)
    > mail/mark tinypal
    > mail/unmark 2 5         (These two commands in this order mark all
                               of tinypal's messages, except messages 2 and 5).
    > mail/unmark 1-5         (unmark messages 1 through 5) 
  
  See Also: mail mark, mail delete, mail status, mail save
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/version
  Command: mail/version
  
  this command will show the current version of the mailsystem.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write
  Topic: mail writing
  
  Note:  For help on creating new mail, please see 'help mail send'
  
  mail/write gives you the flexability of a line-editor within mail.  There
  are various options with mail/write that you may use.  Help is available
  on each of these topics.
  
  Topics:
    ADDING         FORWARDING        QUICKSENDING  CMDLIST    AUTONOTIFY
    EXAMPLES
  
  Write Functionality:
    -         +edit     +del      +join     +justify   +split
    +insert   +list     +forward  +reply    +subject   +forget
    +send     +fedit    +editall  +feditall +cc        +bcc
    +acc      +proof
  
  Type: help mail write <option> for help on these topics/functionality.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +acc
  Command: mail/write +acc=<player-list>
  
  The '+acc' subcommand is used to modify (add to) the target list of
  players the mail is going out to.  Keep in mind, this ONLY works for
  sending or forwarding.  This does *NOT* work for replies.
  
  This only works when you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL and when you
  start a message with 'mail player-list=subject' (or similiar).
  
  Example:
    > mail/write +acc=player1 player2 &myalias +globalalias
    Mail: New send player list stored.
  
  See Also: mail write +cc, mail write +bcc
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +bcc
  Command: mail/write +bcc=<player-list>
  
  The '+bcc' subcommand is used to modify (add to) the target list 
  and blind target list of players the mail is going out to.  Keep 
  in mind, this ONLY works for sending or forwarding.  This does 
  *NOT* work for replies.  If 'bcc_hidden' is ENABLED, then 
  whoever is in the +bcc list will _NOT_ see who the mail was sent
  to.  If 'bcc_hidden' is DISABLED, then whoever is in the +bcc
  list WILL see who the mail was sent to, but no one outside the
  +bcc list will.  In effect, bcc_hidden toggles the effect.
  
  Please check '@list options mail' for the current configuration.
  
  You may specify '!ALL' to clear the Bcc list without effecting
  the To list.
  
  This only works when you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL and when you
  start a message with 'mail player-list=subject' (or similiar).
   
  Example:
    > mail/write +bcc=player1 player2 &myalias +globalalias
    Mail: New send player list stored.
  
  See Also: mail write +cc, mail write +acc
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +cc
  Command: mail/write +cc=<player-list>
  
  The '+cc' subcommand is used to replace (not modify!) the target list of
  players the mail is going out to.  Keep in mind, this ONLY works for
  sending or forwarding.  This does *NOT* work for replies.
  
  This only works when you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL and when you
  start a message with 'mail player-list=subject' (or similiar).
  
  Example:
    > mail/write +cc=player1 player2 &myalias +globalalias ~evalalias
    Mail: New send player list stored.
  
  See Also: mail write +bcc, mail write +acc
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +del
  Command: mail/write +del=<args>
  
  The '+del' subcommand  to mail/write is used to delete a line of text.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write A line of text
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -Another line of txt
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of text
    2: Another line of txt
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +del=1
    Mail: Write line deleted.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: Another line of txt
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  Note: You can't delete line #1 if that's the only line there is.  
        Use mail/write +forget to remove it.
  
  See Also: mail write +edit, mail write +split, mail write +forget
    


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +edit
  Command: mail/write +edit <line>=<old>,<new>
  
  The '+edit' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit a line of text.
  This only edits the FIRST occurance of text in the line.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write A line of text
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -Another line of txt
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of text
    2: Another line of txt
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +edit 2=txt,text
    Mail: +edit done.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of text
    2: Another line of text
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
   
  See Also: mail write +del, mail write +join, mail write +justify 
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +editall
  Command: mail/write +editall=<old>,<new>
  
  The '+editall' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit ALL lines of text.
  This only edits the FIRST occurance of text in the lines.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write A line of txt txt
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -Another line of txt txt
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of txt
    2: Another line of txt
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +editall=txt,text
    Mail: +editall done (2 lines edited)
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of text txt
    2: Another line of text txt
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +feditall, mail write +edit, mail write +fedit
   


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +fedit
  Command: mail/write +fedit <line>=<old>,<new>
  
  The '+fedit' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit a line of text.
  Unlike the '+edit' subcommand, this edits ALL occurances of the text
  in the line.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write A line of text
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -Another line of txt
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of text
    2: Another line of txt
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +fedit 2=txt,text
    Mail: +fedit done.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of text
    2: Another line of text
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
   
  See Also: mail write +del, mail write +join, mail write +justify,
            mail write +fedit, mail write +editall, mail write +feditall
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +feditall
  Command: mail/write +feditall=<old>,<new>
  
  The '+feditall' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit ALL lines of text.
  This edits ALL occurances of text in ALL the lines.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write A line of txt txt
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -Another line of txt txt
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of txt
    2: Another line of txt
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +feditall=txt,text
    Mail: +feditall done (2 lines edited)
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: A line of text text
    2: Another line of text text
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +editall, mail write +edit, mail write +fedit
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +forget
  Command: mail/write +forget
  
  The '+forget' subcommand to mail/write is used to purge the mail in progress
  effectively deleting all of the mail/write information.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write Start of message
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -another line
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    1: Start of message
    2: another line
    > mail/write +forget
    Mail: Write message forgotten.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: No write in progress.
  
  See Also: mail write +edit, mail write +del
    


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +forward
  Command: mail/write +forward=<message number> <player-list>
  
  The '+forward' subcommand to mail/write is used to forward the mail
  in progress to the player list while including the specified message
  number from your mailbox.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write TinyPlayer sent me this... what do you think?
    Mail: Write message started.
    > mail/status
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    [0] ( 1)  From: TinyPlayer      <Mon Jan  1 01:01:01 2000>  (1095 Bytes)
              Subj: Hey!
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
    Note: if the player 'TinyPlayer' was connected, they'd have a '*' before
          the 'From:'.  i.e.  *From: TinyPlayer
  
    > mail/write +forward=1 MyFriend
    Mail: Message sent to -> MyFriend
  
  See Also: mail write +reply, mail write quicksending, mail forward
            mail status
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +insert
  Command: mail/write +insert=<args>
  
  The '+insert' subcommand to mail/write is used to insert a line before
  the specified line.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write Start of mail
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -Third line
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: Start of mail
    2: Third line
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +insert=2,Second line
    Mail: Line inserted.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: Start of mail
    2: Second line
    3: Third line
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +del, mail write +join
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +join
  Command: mail/write +join=<args>
  
  The '+join' subcommand to mail/write is used to join two lines of text.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write This is
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -This is the end of the line.
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > -a test
    Mail: Write line 3 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: This is
    2: This is the end of the line.
    3: a test
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +join=1,3
    Mail: Line joined.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: This is a test
    2: This is the end of the line.
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +del, mail write +split
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +justify
  Command: mail/write +justify=<args>
  
  The '+justify' subcommand to mail/write is used to justify the line.
  Valid options are (l)eft, (c)enter, or (r)ight for justification.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write This is a test
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -This is the end of the line.
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > -ok, I lied.
    Mail: Write line 3 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: This is a test
    2: This is the end of the line.
    3: ok, I lied.
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +justify=1,c
    Mail: Line justified.
    > mail/write +justify=2,r
    Mail: Line justified.
    > mail/write +list
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1:                            This is a test
    2:                                          This is the end of the line.
    3: ok, I lied.
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +join, mail write +del
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +list
  Command: mail/write +list [=<args>]
  
  The '+list' subcommand to mail/write is used to list the lines of your
  write message.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: Line one
    2: Line two
    3: Line three
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +list=2
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    2: Line two
    3: Line three
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +list=1,2
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: Line one
    2: Line two
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +forget, mail write +send
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +proof
  Command: mail/write +proof
  
  The '+proof' subcommand to mail/write is used to give you a 'snapshot' of 
  approximately what the mail will look like when it is sent out.  This does
  not show any text that will be included in forwarded or replied to mail
  if you chose the options to include original text.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write This is some text
    Mail: Write message started.
    > mail/write +proof
    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    Message In Progress
    Status: EDITING     From: You
    To: (empty list)
    Date/Time: Mon May 14 18:50:27 2011        Size: 18 Bytes
    Subject: (None)
    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    This is some text
    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +list, mail write
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +reply
  Command: mail/write +reply=<message number>
  
  The '+reply' subcommand to mail/write is used to reply to the specified
  message with the mail that is in progress.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write Thanks for the mail.
    Mail: Write message started.
    > mail/status
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    [0] ( 1)  From: TinyPlayer      <Mon Jan  1 01:01:01 2000>  (1095 Bytes)
              Subj: Hey!
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    Note: if the player 'TinyPlayer' was connected, they'd have a '*' before
          the 'From:'.  i.e.  *From: TinyPlayer
  
    > mail/write +reply=1
    Mail: Message sent to -> TinyPlayer
  
  See Also: mail write +forward, mail write quicksending, mail reply, 
            mail status
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +send
  Command: mail/write +send=<player list>
  
  The '+send' subcommand to mail/write is used to send the mail in progress to
  a list of players.  You may specify a '@' before the player list to send the
  list of players in a seeable 'CC' list.  Otherwise, it's assumed blank
  carbon copies for everyone in the mail list.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write Start of message
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -second line.
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > -third line.
    Mail: Write line 3 added
    > mail/write +send=@tinyplayer tinywizard
    Mail: Message sent to -> TinyPlayer
    Mail: Message sent to -> TinyWizard
  
  See Also: mail write +reply, mail write +forward, mail send, mail forward,
            mail reply, mail status
    


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +split
  Command: mail/write +split=<args>
  
  The '+split' subcommand to mail/write is used to split a line after the
  specified word.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write Start of mail
    Mail: Write message started.
    > -Second line Third line
    Mail: Write line 2 added
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: Start of mail
    2: Second line Third line
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    > mail/write +split=2,2
    Mail: Line split.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1: Start of mail
    2: Second line
    3: Third line
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  See Also: mail write +justify, mail write +join, mail write +del
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/write +subject
  Command: mail/write +subject=<subject>
  
  The '+subject' subcommand to mail/write is used to set a subject line for
  your mail message.  You may use this command to also re-set it to something
  else if you so desire.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/write Start of message
    Mail: Write message started.
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    1: Start of message
    > mail/write +subject=My Subject
    Mail: Write subject set
    > mail/write +list
    Mail: Your write message is:
    Subject: My Subject
    1: Start of message
    
  See Also: mail write +send, mail write -, mail write +forget
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



mail/zap
  Command:  mail/zap
  
  This option will automatically mark the present message and view the 
  next message.  For example, if you typed:
    mail 1
  
  you would read mail message #1 (if you had mail)
  If you typed:
    mail/zap
  
  You would mark message #1 for deletion and read message #2
  (if you had two messages, in which it would only mark #1 and return
   that you had no more mail to read)
  
  Note:  If you add a '-' after zap (i.e. mail/zap -) it will read the
         previous message.
  
  See Also: mail status, mail next, mail mark, mail delete, mail read
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MAIL_NOPARSE TOGGLE
  Toggle: MAIL_NOPARSE
 
  When this toggle is set, it will surpress the evaluation of
  special characters like %b, %r, or %t when you list out your mail.
  If you want these to be parsed when you list out (proof) your
  mail, then make sure this toggle is not set.
  
  See Also: penn mail toggle, brandy_mail toggle
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MAIL_STRIPRETURN TOGGLE
  Toggle: MAIL_STRIPRETURN
  
  When this toggle is set on the player, whenever that player finishes
  writing mail using the BRANDY_MAIL toggle, all lines are combined
  with spaces instead of carriage returns.  This will mimic more how
  Brandy's +mail or Mux's @mail works.
  
  See Also: penn_mail toggle, brandy_mail toggle
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MAILFILTER
  Attribute: &MAILFILTER
  
  This attribute, when set on a player, will allow that player individual
  control of where the mail will go.  This allows the player to redirect
  incoming mail into pre-existing folders.  The following are passed:
              %0  - the dbref# of the player (or #-1 if anonymous)
              %1  - the subject of the message
              %2  - the body of the message
              %3  - the date/time of the message
  Examples:
    > folder/list
      Mail: You have the following folders ->
      Incoming Testing Junk
    > &MAILFILTER me=[switch(%0,#123,Testing,#234,Junk)]
      Set.
    > think [num(me)] [name(me)]
      #123 Yourself
    > mail me=A Test//A Test
      Mail: You have new mail from -> Yourself [Subj: A Test]
      Mail: Auto-Moved to folder -> Testing
      Mail: Message sent to -> Yourself
    > (recieving mail from Bob, dbref #999)
      Mail: You have new mail from -> Bob [Subj: Hey!]
    > (recieving mail from Tony, dbref #234)
      Mail: You have new mail from -> Tony [Subj: You smell]
      Mail: Auto-Moved to folder -> Junk
  
  See Also: @mailsig, &mailnotify
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MAILNOTIFY
  Attribute: &MAILNOTIFY
  
  This attribute, when set on a player, will send a message to the person
  mailing them depending on the evaluated text in the attribute.
  
  If the message evaluates to an empty string, no message is sent.
  
  The following arguments are passed for evaluation:
              %0  - the dbref# of the player (or #-1 if anonymous)
              %1  - the subject of the message
              %2  - the body of the message
              %3  - the date/time of the message
  
  Examples:
    > &mailnotify me=Hi, [name(%0)]!  You sent me mail!
    Set.
    > think [name(me)]
    Bob
    > mail me=Test!
    Hi, Bob!  You sent me mail!
    Mail: You have new mail from -> Bob
    Mail: Message sent to -> Bob
    Mail: Done
    > think [name(me)]
    Betty
    > mail bob=Test!
    Hi, Betty! You sent me mail!
    Mail: Message sent to -> Bob
    Mail: Done
  
  See Also: @mailsig, &mailfilter



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MAILQUICK()
  Function: mailquick(<player>[[,<folder>][,<type>]])
  
  This function has a number of uses.  If the type is zero (0) (the default)
  then it will return the values that 'mail/quick' returns.  If the value
  for type is a '1', it returns the 3 values that mux's mail() returns.  If
  the value for type is a '2', it returns the total messages you have in your
  box.  '3' gives you a modified version of '1'.  The default folder is 
  your incoming box.
  
  Examples:
    > mail/quick me
    Mail: 4 Total - 1 new, 0 unread, 2 old, 1 marked, 0 saved mail message(s) 
    > say mailquick(me)
    You say "4 1 0 2 1 0"
    > say mailquick(me,,1)
    You say "3 1 1"
    > say mailquick(me,,2)
    You say "4"
  
  See Also: mail cmdlist, mail write cmdlist
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MAILVALIDATE TOGGLE
  Toggle: MAILVALIDATE
  
  This toggle, when set, will do validation of the player lists
  (expanding any aliases) and will not send out any mail if
  ANY target in the mail list is invalid.
  
  The default is it will send mail to all valid players and
  alert you of invalid while continuing through the list.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



map()
  Function: map([<obj>/]<attr>,<list>[[,<delim>][,<sep>][,<arg1>,...,<argN>])
  
  This function is nearly identical to an iter() operating on u() function.
  Each member of <list> is passed to the result of fetching <attr> as %0, and
  the results are used to form a new list, separated by the delimiter
  character.
  
  <delim>iter may be used to specify a delimiter other than space.
  
  <sep>erator may be used to specify an output separator other than a space.
  
  You may specify arguments <arg1> through <argN> that will be passed as %1
  for the first argument (or arg1) all the way through MAX_ARGS 
  (which defaults to 30 total to a function, so 30 - 4 args, or 26 total).
  Any arguments over 9 can be fetched with v(10), v(11), etc.  You may also
  use the shift() function.
  
  Examples: 
  > &ADD_ONE object=add(%0,1)
  > say map(object/add_one,1 2 3 4 5)
  You say "2 3 4 5 6"
  
  See Also: filter(), fold(), iter(), parse(), u(), munge(), citer(), 
            nsiter(), sortlist(), inf()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MARKER0
  Flag: MARKER0([0])  
  
  This flag is a marker flag.  It is a dummy flag for reuse.
  
  By default only #1 may set or unset it.  To change permissions
  of this flag, use the @flagdef command (in wizhelp).
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MARKER1
  Flag: MARKER1([1])  
  
  This flag is a marker flag.  It is a dummy flag for reuse.
  
  By default only #1 may set or unset it.  To change permissions
  of this flag, use the @flagdef command (in wizhelp).
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MARKER2
  Flag: MARKER2([2])
  
  This flag is a marker flag.  It is a dummy flag for reuse.
  
  By default only #1 may set or unset it.  To change permissions
  of this flag, use the @flagdef command (in wizhelp).
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MARKER3
  Flag: MARKER3([3])  
  
  This flag is a marker flag.  It is a dummy flag for reuse.
  
  By default only #1 may set or unset it.  To change permissions
  of this flag, use the @flagdef command (in wizhelp).
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MARKER4
  Flag: MARKER4([4])  
  
  This flag is a marker flag.  It is a dummy flag for reuse.
  
  By default only #1 may set or unset it.  To change permissions
  of this flag, use the @flagdef command (in wizhelp).
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MARKER5
  Flag: MARKER5([5])  
  
  This flag is a marker flag.  It is a dummy flag for reuse.
  
  By default only #1 may set or unset it.  To change permissions
  of this flag, use the @flagdef command (in wizhelp).
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MARKER6
  Flag: MARKER6([6])  
  
  This flag is a marker flag.  It is a dummy flag for reuse.
  
  By default only #1 may set or unset it.  To change permissions
  of this flag, use the @flagdef command (in wizhelp).
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MARKER7
  Flag: MARKER7([7])  
  
  This flag is a marker flag.  It is a dummy flag for reuse.
  
  By default only #1 may set or unset it.  To change permissions
  of this flag, use the @flagdef command (in wizhelp).
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MARKER8
  Flag: MARKER8([8])  
  
  This flag is a marker flag.  It is a dummy flag for reuse.
  
  By default only #1 may set or unset it.  To change permissions
  of this flag, use the @flagdef command (in wizhelp).
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MARKER9
  Flag: MARKER9([9])  
  
  This flag is a marker flag.  It is a dummy flag for reuse.
  
  By default only #1 may set or unset it.  To change permissions
  of this flag, use the @flagdef command (in wizhelp).
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MASK()
  Function: mask(<value>,<value>[,<masktype>])
            mask(<value>,<value>,...,<value>,<masktype>)
  
  This function will apply a specified mask to a value.  This can be
  useful for bitwise anding/oring values together. (for those mathheads)
  The values available for masktype are:
     & -- Bitwise AND 
     | -- Bitwise OR
     ^ -- Bitwise XOR
     ~ -- Bitwise NAND (AND 1's compliment)
     1 -- Bitwise BNOT (1's Compliment)
     2 --              (2's Compliment)
  
  The default masktype is the bitwise AND (&) (but only with 2 arguments).
  
  Please note, if you use more than 2 values, you must specify the masktype,
  otherwise it'll assume the last argument is always the masktype.
  
  Examples:
    > say mask(3,4)
    You say "0"
    > say mask(3,4,|)
    You say "7"
    > say mask(3,4,^)
    You say "7"
  
  See Also: edit(), regedit(), pack(), unpack(), packmath(), shl(), shr(),
            crc32()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MATCH()
  Function: match(<string>, <pattern>[, <delim>])
 
  This function matches <pattern> against each word of <string>, returning
  the number of the first word that matches.  If no words match then 0 is
  returned.  The case of the characters being matched is not significant.
 
  The pattern may contain the wildcards '*' and '?'.  '?' matches any one
  character, while '*' matches any number of characters, including none.
  So 's?x' would match 'sex' or 'six', but not to 'socx', but 's*x' would
  match any of them.
  
  <delim> may be used specified to specify a delimiter other than a space.
  
  Examples:
    > say match(This is a test, test)
    You say "4"
    > say match(This is a test, is)
    You say "2"
    > say match(This is a test, *is*)
    You say "1"
    > say match(This is a test, *not*)
    You say "0"
    > say match(This is a test, is a)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: LISTS, member(), strmatch(), subnetmatch(), nummatch(), totmatch()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MAX ARGS
  Topic: MAX ARGS
  
  Functions:
    The maximum number of arguments you can pass functions, by default, is 30.
    Anything over this tends to no longer be processed.  
  
    You can extend this by strfunc() to essentially turn any function into
    a list function, which then extends the maximum number of arguments
    to functions (that accept 1 to n as arguments) to a maximum of 1000.
  
    Functions that are hard-locked with strict arguments are not affected.
  
  Commands:
    Commands, by default, have 10 arguments you can pass to them.  This is
    hard limited and immutable.
  
  See Also: strfunc(), @list functions, @list commands, commands, functions
    


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



MAX()
  Function: max(<number1>,<number2>[,<numberN]...)
   
  Returns the largest integer from among its arguments.
  Up to 30 arguments may be specified.
  
  Numbers may be floating point numbers, and a floating point result
  is returned.
   
  Examples:
    > say max(2,4)
    You say "4"
    > say max(-100,50,0,25)
    You say "50"
   
  See Also: min(), alphamin(), alphamax()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



max_name_protect
  (CONTINUED)
  Command: @protect[/<switch>] [<player-name>]  
  
  The following wizard @admin parameters exist (see wizhelp for help):
    protect_addenh   -- this is the toggle that enables/disables enhanced adds
    max_name_protect -- this controls total number of names to be protected
  
  Examples:
    > say [name(me)] [num(me)]
    You say "Bob #123"
    > @protect/add
    Your current name has been added to your protect list.
    > @protect/add Simon            (if enhanced mode enabled)
    The name has been added to your protect list.
    > @protect/add Fred             (if enhanced mode enabled)
    The name has been added to your protect list.
    > @protect/del Bob
    You have successfully deleted 'Bob' from your protect list.
    > @protect/alias Simon
    You have successfully activated 'simon' as an alias.
    > @protect/alias Fred
    You have successfully activated 'fred' as an alias.
    > @protect/unalias Fred
    You have successfully de-activated 'fred' as an alias.
    > @protect/list
    +------------------------------+----------------------------------+-------+
    | Player Name Protected        | Dbref#   [ Player Name         ] | Alias |
    +------------------------------+----------------------------------+-------+
    | Simon                        | #123     [ Bob                 ] |   Y   |
    | Fred                         | #123     [ Bob                 ] |   N   |
    +------------------------------+----------------------------------+-------+
    You have 2 out of 10 names protected.
  
  See Also: @name, @alias, listprotection()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ME
  Topic: ME
  The word 'me' refers to yourself. Some things to do when starting out: 
  1) give yourself a description with 
     '@describe me = <description>', then look at yourself with 'look me'.
  2) set your gender, if you wish it known, with
     '@sex me=male' or '@sex me=female'  (or '@sex me=neuter' to be an 'it').
  3) To lock yourself, type: @lock me=me
  
  See Also: HERE
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



member()
  Function: member(<list>, <word>[, <delim>])
 
  Member takes a list and a word, and returns the position of that word
  within the list.  If the word does not occur in the list, then 0 is
  returned.  Unlike match(), member() does not check for wildcarding,
  and the cases of <list> and <word> are significant.  A word is defined as
  a string which has no interior spaces.  So 'hello' would be one word,
  while 'hello there' would be two.  Member, unlike match, is case 
  sensitive.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than a space.
 
  Example:
    > say member(This is a member test, member)
    You say "4"
    > say member(This is a member test, Member)
    You say "0"
    > say member(This is a member test, *e*)   
    You say "0"
    > say member(This is a member test, is a)
