            regeditlit(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[, ... , <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
  
  This function is a version of edit() that uses regular expressions.
  The part of <str> that matches the <regexp> is replaced by the
  evaluated <repl> (replacement), with $<number> in <replacement> expanded to
  the corresponding matching sub-expression of <regexp>, with $0 the entire
  matched section. regediti() only replaces the first match and is
  case sensitive.  The <replacement> argument is evaluated once for 
  each match, allowing for more complex transformations than is possible 
  with straight replacement.
  
  The regeditlit() function works same as regedit() but does not evaluate 
  the replaced values.
  
  Example:
  > say regedit(this test is the best string, (.)est, $1rash)
  You say "this trash is the best string"
  > say regedit(this test is the best string, (.)est, [capstr($1)]rash)
  You say "this Trash is the best string"
  
  See also: edit(), editansi(), regmatch(), regediti(), regeditall(), 
            regeditalli()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEDITALL()
  Function: regeditall(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[,..., <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
            regeditalllit(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[,..., <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
  
  This function is a version of edit() that uses regular expressions.
  The part of <str> that matches the <regexp> is replaced by the
  evaluated <repl> (replacement), with $<number> in <replacement> expanded to 
  the corresponding matching sub-expression of <regexp>, with $0 the entire
  matched section.  regeditall() replaces all matches.  The <replacement> 
  argument is evaluated once for each match, allowing for more complex 
  transformations than is possible with straight replacement.  
  
  The regeditalllit() function works same as regeditall() but does not evaluate
  the replaced values.
  
  Example:
  > say regeditall(this test is the best string, (.)est, $1rash)
  You say "this trash is the brash string"
  > say regeditall(this test is the best string, (.)est, [capstr($1)]rash)
  You say "this Trash is the Brash string"
  
  See also: edit(), editansi() regmatch(), regedit(), regediti(), regeditalli()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEDITALLI()
  Function: regeditalli(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[,...,<regexpN>,<replaceN>])
            regeditallilit(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[,...,<regexpN>,<replaceN>])
  
  This function is a version of edit() that uses regular expressions.
  The part of <str> that matches the <regexp> is replaced by the
  evaluated <repl> (replacement), with $<number> in <replacement> expanded to 
  the corresponding matching sub-expression of <regexp>, with $0 the entire
  matched section.  regeditalli() replaces all matches and is case 
  insensitive. The <replacement> argument is evaluated once for
  each match, allowing for more complex transformations than is
  possible with straight replacement.
  
  The regeditallilit() function works same as regeditalli() but does not 
  evaluate the replaced values.
   
  Example:
  > say regeditalli(this teSt is the best string, (.)est, $1rash)
  You say "this trash is the brash string"
  > say regeditalli(this test is the best string, (.)est, [capstr($1)]rash)
  You say "this Trash is the Brash string"
  
  See also: edit(), editansi(), regmatch(), regedit(), regediti(), 
            regeditall() 



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEDITALLILIT()
  Function: regeditalli(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[,...,<regexpN>,<replaceN>])
            regeditallilit(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[,...,<regexpN>,<replaceN>])
  
  This function is a version of edit() that uses regular expressions.
  The part of <str> that matches the <regexp> is replaced by the
  evaluated <repl> (replacement), with $<number> in <replacement> expanded to 
  the corresponding matching sub-expression of <regexp>, with $0 the entire
  matched section.  regeditalli() replaces all matches and is case 
  insensitive. The <replacement> argument is evaluated once for
  each match, allowing for more complex transformations than is
  possible with straight replacement.
  
  The regeditallilit() function works same as regeditalli() but does not 
  evaluate the replaced values.
   
  Example:
  > say regeditalli(this teSt is the best string, (.)est, $1rash)
  You say "this trash is the brash string"
  > say regeditalli(this test is the best string, (.)est, [capstr($1)]rash)
  You say "this Trash is the Brash string"
  
  See also: edit(), editansi(), regmatch(), regedit(), regediti(), 
            regeditall() 



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEDITALLLIT()
  Function: regeditall(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[,..., <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
            regeditalllit(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[,..., <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
  
  This function is a version of edit() that uses regular expressions.
  The part of <str> that matches the <regexp> is replaced by the
  evaluated <repl> (replacement), with $<number> in <replacement> expanded to 
  the corresponding matching sub-expression of <regexp>, with $0 the entire
  matched section.  regeditall() replaces all matches.  The <replacement> 
  argument is evaluated once for each match, allowing for more complex 
  transformations than is possible with straight replacement.  
  
  The regeditalllit() function works same as regeditall() but does not evaluate
  the replaced values.
  
  Example:
  > say regeditall(this test is the best string, (.)est, $1rash)
  You say "this trash is the brash string"
  > say regeditall(this test is the best string, (.)est, [capstr($1)]rash)
  You say "this Trash is the Brash string"
  
  See also: edit(), editansi() regmatch(), regedit(), regediti(), regeditalli()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEDITI()
  Function: regediti(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[, ... , <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
  Function: regeditilit(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[, ... , <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
   
  This function is a version of edit() that uses regular expressions.
  The part of <str> that matches the <regexp> is replaced by the
  evaluated <repl> (replacement), with $<number> in <replacement> expanded to 
  the corresponding matching sub-expression of <regexp>, with $0 the entire
  matched section. regediti() only replaces the first match and is case
  insensitive.  The <replacement> argument is evaluated once for
  each match, allowing for more complex transformations than is
  possible with straight replacement.
  
  The regeditilit() function works same as regediti() but does not evaluate 
  the replaced values.
  
  Example:
  > say regediti(this teSt is the best string, (.)est, $1rash)
  You say "this trash is the best string"
  > say regediti(this teSt is the best string, (.)est, [capstr($1)]rash)
  You say "this Trash is the best string"
  
  See also: edit(), editansi(), regmatch(), regedit(), regeditall(), 
            regeditalli()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEDITILIT()
  Function: regediti(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[, ... , <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
  Function: regeditilit(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[, ... , <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
   
  This function is a version of edit() that uses regular expressions.
  The part of <str> that matches the <regexp> is replaced by the
  evaluated <repl> (replacement), with $<number> in <replacement> expanded to 
  the corresponding matching sub-expression of <regexp>, with $0 the entire
  matched section. regediti() only replaces the first match and is case
  insensitive.  The <replacement> argument is evaluated once for
  each match, allowing for more complex transformations than is
  possible with straight replacement.
  
  The regeditilit() function works same as regediti() but does not evaluate 
  the replaced values.
  
  Example:
  > say regediti(this teSt is the best string, (.)est, $1rash)
  You say "this trash is the best string"
  > say regediti(this teSt is the best string, (.)est, [capstr($1)]rash)
  You say "this Trash is the best string"
  
  See also: edit(), editansi(), regmatch(), regedit(), regeditall(), 
            regeditalli()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEDITLIT()
  Function: regedit(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[, ... , <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
            regeditlit(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[, ... , <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
  
  This function is a version of edit() that uses regular expressions.
  The part of <str> that matches the <regexp> is replaced by the
  evaluated <repl> (replacement), with $<number> in <replacement> expanded to
  the corresponding matching sub-expression of <regexp>, with $0 the entire
  matched section. regediti() only replaces the first match and is
  case sensitive.  The <replacement> argument is evaluated once for 
  each match, allowing for more complex transformations than is possible 
  with straight replacement.
  
  The regeditlit() function works same as regedit() but does not evaluate 
  the replaced values.
  
  Example:
  > say regedit(this test is the best string, (.)est, $1rash)
  You say "this trash is the best string"
  > say regedit(this test is the best string, (.)est, [capstr($1)]rash)
  You say "this Trash is the best string"
  
  See also: edit(), editansi(), regmatch(), regediti(), regeditall(), 
            regeditalli()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXP CASESENSITIVE
  Topic: REGEXPS2 (continued)
  
  Regular expressions are extremely useful when you want to enforce
  a data type. For example, if you have a command where you want a
  player to enter a string and a number ('+setnum <player>=<number>',
  for example), you might do it like this:
  
  > &DO_NUM Command Object=$^\+setnum (.+)=([0-9]+)$: @va me=Data: %1 = %2
  Set.
  > @set Command Object/DO_NUM = regexp
  Set.
  > +setnum cookie=30
  > ex Command Object/va
  Data: cookies = 30
  > &DO_ZZ Command Object=$^zz:@pemit %#=I am case insensitive.
  > zz
  I am case insensitive.
  > &DO_ZZ Command Object=$^(?-i)zz:@pemit %#=I am case sensitive.
  > zz
  I am case sensitive.
  > ZZ
  Huh?  (Type 'help' for help)
  
  How it works:
  '+setnum cookies=30' would set VA to "Data: cookies = 30".
  This eliminates your having to check to see if the player entered
  a number, since the regular expression matches only numbers.
  Furthermore, the '+' guarantees that there needs to be at least
  one character there, so a player can't enter '+setnum cookies='
  or '+setnum =10' or similarly malformed input.
  
  The '+' sign in the command has to be escaped out, or it is taken as
  a regexp token. Furthermore, the pattern-match has to be anchored
  with ^ and $, or something like 'try +setnum cookies=30 now' would
  also match. Regexps are case-sensitive; wildcard globbing is not.
  
  Regular expression syntax is explained in 'help regexp syntax'.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXP CASESENSITIVITY
  Topic: REGEXPS2 (continued)
  
  Regular expressions are extremely useful when you want to enforce
  a data type. For example, if you have a command where you want a
  player to enter a string and a number ('+setnum <player>=<number>',
  for example), you might do it like this:
  
  > &DO_NUM Command Object=$^\+setnum (.+)=([0-9]+)$: @va me=Data: %1 = %2
  Set.
  > @set Command Object/DO_NUM = regexp
  Set.
  > +setnum cookie=30
  > ex Command Object/va
  Data: cookies = 30
  > &DO_ZZ Command Object=$^zz:@pemit %#=I am case insensitive.
  > zz
  I am case insensitive.
  > &DO_ZZ Command Object=$^(?-i)zz:@pemit %#=I am case sensitive.
  > zz
  I am case sensitive.
  > ZZ
  Huh?  (Type 'help' for help)
  
  How it works:
  '+setnum cookies=30' would set VA to "Data: cookies = 30".
  This eliminates your having to check to see if the player entered
  a number, since the regular expression matches only numbers.
  Furthermore, the '+' guarantees that there needs to be at least
  one character there, so a player can't enter '+setnum cookies='
  or '+setnum =10' or similarly malformed input.
  
  The '+' sign in the command has to be escaped out, or it is taken as
  a regexp token. Furthermore, the pattern-match has to be anchored
  with ^ and $, or something like 'try +setnum cookies=30 now' would
  also match. Regexps are case-sensitive; wildcard globbing is not.
  
  Regular expression syntax is explained in 'help regexp syntax'.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXP CLASSES
  Topic: REGEXP CLASSES
  
  In a character class, you can use a number of additional keywords
  that match certain types of characters. The keywords are enclosed in
  [: and :], within the character class, so the whole thing looks like
  [[:NAME:]].
  
  These keywords can be mixed with other things in the character class,
  like [ab[:digit:]], which will match 'a, 'b', or a digit. [:^NAME:]
  reverses the meaning of NAME - it expands to everything but characters
  that would match [:NAME:].
  
  Some recognized NAMEs:
   digit, for numbers. [[:digit:]] is the same as \d.
    [[:^digit:]] is the same as \D.
   alpha, for letters. alnum, for numbers and letters.
   lower, for lower-case letters. upper, for upper-case letters.
   word, for word characters. [[:word:]] is the same as \w.
    [[:^word:]] is the same as \W.
   space, for whitespace characters. [[:space:]] is the same as \s.
    [[:^space:]] is the same as \S.
  
{continued in 'help regexp classes2'}



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXP CLASSES2
  Topic: REGEXP CLASSES2 (continued)
  
  These keywords (Or the corresponding \codes) should be used instead of
  explicit ranges where possible to improve portability. For example,
  [A-Za-z] and [[:alpha:]] are not the same thing in languages with accented
  characters. There are other keywords, but the ones listed are the most
  useful.
  
  Examples:
  > say regmatch(foo_bar, lit(^[[:word:]]+$))
  You say "1"
  > say regmatch(foo bar, lit(^[[:word:]]+$))
  You say "0"
  
  See Also: regexp syntax, regexp examples



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXP EXAMPLES
  Topic: REGEXP EXAMPLES
  
  The regexp pattern '.' is equivalent to the wildcard '?'; it matches
  one and only one of an arbitrary character.
  
  The regexp pattern '.+' is equivalent to the wildcard '*'; it matches
  one or more arbitrary characters. To match zero or more arbitrary
  characters, the regexp pattern is '.*'.
  
  To match a string of numbers, use:       [0-9]+    or \d+
  To match a string of letters only, use:  [A-Za-z]+ or \w+
  
  See 'help regexp syntax' for a more detailed explanation.
  
  See Also: regexp syntax, regexp classes



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXP SYNTAX
  Topic: REGEXP SYNTAX
  
  RhostMUSH uses PCRE for its regular expression engine.  PCRE is an
  open source library of functions to support regular expressions whose
  syntax and semantics are as close as possible to those of the Perl
  5 language.  The text below is excerpted from its man page. PCRE
  was written by Philip Hazel <ph10@cam.ac.uk>, and is Copyright (c)
  1997-1999 University of Cambridge, England. You can find it at
     ftp://ftp.csx.cam.ac.uk/pub/software/programming/pcre/
  
  (Note that in RhostMUSH, if the regular expression is in an eval'd
  context (like an argument to regmatch), you'll have to do a lot
  of escaping to make things work right. One way to escape an argument
  like %0 is: regeditall(%0,\\W,\\$0) or similar).
  
  A regular expression is a pattern that is matched against a subject
  string from left to right. Most characters stand for themselves in a
  pattern, and match the corresponding characters in the subject.
  
{continued in 'help regexp syntax2'}



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXP SYNTAX2
  Topic: REGEXP SYNTAX2 (continued)
  There are two different sets of meta-characters: those  that
  are  recognized anywhere in the pattern except within square
  brackets, and those that are recognized in square  brackets.
  Outside square brackets, the meta-characters are as follows:
  
       \      general escape character with several uses
       ^      assert start of subject
       $      assert end of subject
       .      match any character except newline
       [      start character class definition
       |      start of alternative branch ("or")
       (      start subpattern
       )      end subpattern
       ?      0 or 1 quantifier (after a unit to quantify)
              or, minimal match (after a quantifier)
              or,  extends the meaning of ( after a (
       *      0 or more quantifier
       +      1 or more quantifier
  
{continued in 'help regexp syntax3'}



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXP SYNTAX3
  Topic: REGEXP SYNTAX3 (continued)
  Part of a pattern that is in square  brackets  is  called  a
  "character class". It matches any character listed in the class.
  In a character class, the only metacharacters are:
  
       \      general escape character
       ^      negate the class, if the first character in the class
       -      indicates character range (e.g. A-Z, 0-4)
   [:NAME:]   A symbol for a group of characters that can vary
              according to the language the mush is using.
              See 'help regexp classes' for more information.
       ]      terminates the character class
  
  A backslash will escape most metacharacters, and can turn
  some normal characters into generic character types:
  
       \d     any decimal digit
       \D     any character that is not a decimal digit
       \s     any whitespace character
       \S     any character that is not a whitespace character
       \w     any "word" character (letter, digit, or underscore)
       \W     any "non-word" character
  
{continued in 'help regexp syntax4'}



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXP SYNTAX4
  Topic: REGEXP SYNTAX4 (continued)
    
  A backlash can also two useful assertions -- conditions that
  must be met at a particular point in a match:
  
       \b     word boundary
       \B     not a word boundary
  
  A word boundary is a position in the  subject  string  where the
  current character and the previous character do not both match \w or
  \W (i.e. one matches \w and  the  other  matches \W),  or the start
  or end of the string if the first or last character matches \w,
  respectively.
  
{continued in 'help regexp syntax5'}



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXP SYNTAX5
  Topic: REGEXP SYNTAX5 (continued)
   
  Quantifiers specify repetition of characters. Three are available:
       *    match 0 or more of whatever came before
       +    match 1 or more of whatever came before
       ?    match 0 or 1 of whatever came before
   
  (In theory, you can match m-n of whatever came before with {m,n},
  but the MUSH parser makes it impossible to use {}'s)
   
  Quantifiers are usually greedy -- they match as much as possible.
  Adding a ? after a quantifier causes it to match as little as
  possible instead.
  
{continued in 'help regexp syntax6'}



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXP SYNTAX6
  Topic: REGEXP SYNTAX6 (continued)
  
  Outside a character class, a backslash followed by  a  digit greater
  than  0  (and  possibly  further  digits) is a back reference to a
  capturing subpattern  earlier  (i.e.  to  its left)  in  the  pattern,
  provided there have been that many previous capturing left parentheses.
  A back reference matches whatever actually matched the  capturing
  subpattern in the current subject string, rather than anything matching
  the subpattern itself. So the pattern
  
    (sens|respons)e and \1ibility
  
  matches "sense and sensibility" and "response and  responsibility",  but
  not  "sense  and  responsibility".
  
{continued in 'help regexp syntax7'}



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXP SYNTAX7
  Topic: REGEXP SYNTAX7 (continued)
  
  An assertion is  a  test  on  the  characters  following  or
  preceding  the current matching point that does not actually consume
  any characters.  There  are  two kinds:  those that look ahead of the
  current position in the subject string, and those that look behind it.
  
  An assertion subpattern is matched in the normal way, except that  it
  does not cause the current matching position to be changed. Lookahead
  assertions start with  (?=  for  positive assertions and (?! for
  negative assertions. For example, Lookbehind assertions start with
  (?<=  for  positive  assertions and (?<! for negative assertions.
  
  Assertion subpatterns are not capturing subpatterns, and may not
  be  repeated,  because  it makes no sense to assert the same thing
  several times. If an assertion contains capturing subpatterns within it,
  these are always counted for the purposes of numbering the capturing
  subpatterns  in  the  whole pattern.
  
{continued in 'help regexp syntax8'}



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXP SYNTAX8
  Topic: REGEXP SYNTAX8 (continued)
  
  PCRE's engine can also do conditional subpattern matching,
  embedded comments in regexps, and a bunch of other things.
  See a regexp book for details.
  
  See Also: regexp classes, regexp examples
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXPS
  Topic: REGEXPS
  
  (This help text is largely from PennMUSH, with permission)
  
  If you wish to see the help for the normal globbing command execution,
  please refer to the help 'ARBITRARY COMMANDS'.
  
  The majority of matching in MUSH is done with wildcard ("globbing")
  patterns. There is a second type of matching, using regular expressions,
  that is available in certain circumstances.
  
  For attributes that are $-commands or ^-listen-patterns, setting that
  attribute "regexp" (with '@set <object>/<attribute>=regexp') causes
  patterns to be matched using regular expressions rather than
  globbing. In addition, the function regmatch() performs regular
  expression matching.
  
  In a regular expression match, the substring of the string which matched
  the regexp pattern is %0; %1 through %9 are the substrings of the string
  which matched parenthesized expressions within the regexp pattern.

{continued in 'help regexps2'}



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGEXPS2
  Topic: REGEXPS2 (continued)
  
  Regular expressions are extremely useful when you want to enforce
  a data type. For example, if you have a command where you want a
  player to enter a string and a number ('+setnum <player>=<number>',
  for example), you might do it like this:
  
  > &DO_NUM Command Object=$^\+setnum (.+)=([0-9]+)$: @va me=Data: %1 = %2
  Set.
  > @set Command Object/DO_NUM = regexp
  Set.
  > +setnum cookie=30
  > ex Command Object/va
  Data: cookies = 30
  > &DO_ZZ Command Object=$^zz:@pemit %#=I am case insensitive.
  > zz
  I am case insensitive.
  > &DO_ZZ Command Object=$^(?-i)zz:@pemit %#=I am case sensitive.
  > zz
  I am case sensitive.
  > ZZ
  Huh?  (Type 'help' for help)
  
  How it works:
  '+setnum cookies=30' would set VA to "Data: cookies = 30".
  This eliminates your having to check to see if the player entered
  a number, since the regular expression matches only numbers.
  Furthermore, the '+' guarantees that there needs to be at least
  one character there, so a player can't enter '+setnum cookies='
  or '+setnum =10' or similarly malformed input.
  
  The '+' sign in the command has to be escaped out, or it is taken as
  a regexp token. Furthermore, the pattern-match has to be anchored
  with ^ and $, or something like 'try +setnum cookies=30 now' would
  also match. Regexps are case-sensitive; wildcard globbing is not.
  
  Regular expression syntax is explained in 'help regexp syntax'.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



register
  Command: co  <name> <password>  (short for connect)
           cd  <name> <password>  (short for cdark)
           ch  <name> <password>  (short for chidden)
           cr  <name> <password>  (short for create)
           reg <name> <password>  (short for register)
  
  Note:  To create/log in a character with spaces in their name, please use
         "<name>".  Ergo, surround your name with double quotes.
         The 'register' command does not allow creation with spaces.
  
  These commands are only useful on the connect screen.  They are used to
  create/connect to your account <name> with the provided <password>.  
  These commands are not useable once you are connected to the mush.
  
  These commands are as follows:
     co  -- This option is the default and normal method to connect.
            This option has no special conditions or privilages.
            Syntax: co player password
                    co "Player With Spaces" password
  
     ch  -- Wizards and anyone with the NOWHO @power (to @hide) can use this.
            This option will auto-hide the player when connecting.
            It defaults to the 'co' option if you can't @hide.
            Syntax: ch player password
                    ch "Player With Spaces" password
  
     cd  -- Wizards and higher can use this to connect dark to the game.
            This effectively connects wiz-cloaked to the game.
            Immortals get auto-added to supercloak.
            Syntax: cd player password
                    cd "Player With Spaces" password
     
     cr  -- Allows creation of a player from the connect screen.
            Syntax: cr player password
                    cr "Player With Spaces" password
  
     reg -- If offline registration is enabled, allows the player to register
            a character with a supplied email that is then used to email them
            their password.
            Syntax: reg player email@address
                    reg "Player With Spaces" email@address
  
  See Also: @aconnect, @adisconnect, @hide, @register
            


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGLMATCH()
  Function: reglmatchalli(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatchall(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatchi(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatch(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
  
  This function returns the positional matches of every word in the
  string that matches the specified regular expression.  This is
  exactly like the totmatch() function except uses regular 
  expression matching.  This function is case sensitive.
  
  The non 'all' functions will only return the position of the first
  match, or in other words functions like match() would.
   
  The reglmatchi() and reglmatchalli() functions ignores case.
  
  Example:
    > say reglmatchall(one two three four five fourteen,.*ou.*)
    You say "4 6"
    > say reglmatch(one two three four five fourteen,.*ou.*)
    You say "4"
  
  See Also: totmatch(), regmatch(), regnummatch(), nummatch()
  
  'help regexp syntax' for an explanation of regular expressions.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGLMATCHALL()
  Function: reglmatchalli(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatchall(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatchi(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatch(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
  
  This function returns the positional matches of every word in the
  string that matches the specified regular expression.  This is
  exactly like the totmatch() function except uses regular 
  expression matching.  This function is case sensitive.
  
  The non 'all' functions will only return the position of the first
  match, or in other words functions like match() would.
   
  The reglmatchi() and reglmatchalli() functions ignores case.
  
  Example:
    > say reglmatchall(one two three four five fourteen,.*ou.*)
    You say "4 6"
    > say reglmatch(one two three four five fourteen,.*ou.*)
    You say "4"
  
  See Also: totmatch(), regmatch(), regnummatch(), nummatch()
  
  'help regexp syntax' for an explanation of regular expressions.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGLMATCHALLI()
  Function: reglmatchalli(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatchall(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatchi(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatch(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
  
  This function returns the positional matches of every word in the
  string that matches the specified regular expression.  This is
  exactly like the totmatch() function except uses regular 
  expression matching.  This function is case sensitive.
  
  The non 'all' functions will only return the position of the first
  match, or in other words functions like match() would.
   
  The reglmatchi() and reglmatchalli() functions ignores case.
  
  Example:
    > say reglmatchall(one two three four five fourteen,.*ou.*)
    You say "4 6"
    > say reglmatch(one two three four five fourteen,.*ou.*)
    You say "4"
  
  See Also: totmatch(), regmatch(), regnummatch(), nummatch()
  
  'help regexp syntax' for an explanation of regular expressions.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGLMATCHI()
  Function: reglmatchalli(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatchall(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatchi(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatch(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
  
  This function returns the positional matches of every word in the
  string that matches the specified regular expression.  This is
  exactly like the totmatch() function except uses regular 
  expression matching.  This function is case sensitive.
  
  The non 'all' functions will only return the position of the first
  match, or in other words functions like match() would.
   
  The reglmatchi() and reglmatchalli() functions ignores case.
  
  Example:
    > say reglmatchall(one two three four five fourteen,.*ou.*)
    You say "4 6"
    > say reglmatch(one two three four five fourteen,.*ou.*)
    You say "4"
  
  See Also: totmatch(), regmatch(), regnummatch(), nummatch()
  
  'help regexp syntax' for an explanation of regular expressions.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGMATCH()
  Function: regmatch(<string>,<regexp>[,<register list>])
  
  This function matches the regular expression <regexp> against the
  entirety of <string>, returning 1 if it matches and 0 if it does not.
  This function is case sensitive.  It behaves like strmatch().
  
  If <register list> is specified, there is a side-effect: any
  parenthesized substrings within the regular expression will be set
  into the specified local registers, in the order they were specified
  in the list. <register list> can be a list of one through nine numbers.
  If the specified register is -1, the substring is not copied into a
  register. Under regmatchi, case of the substring may be modified.
  You may also use a-z as registers if currently enabled on your RhostMUSH.
  You may have to escape mush-special characters (like (, ), {, }, etc)
  Any invalid registers specified will be skipped over and ignored.
  
  Examples:
    > say regmatch(cookies=30,\(.+\)=\(\[0-9\]*\))
    You say "1"
    > say regmatch(cookies=30,\(.+\)=\(\[0-9\]*\),0 3 5) |%q0/%q3/%q5|
    You say "1 |cookies=30/cookies/30|
  
  See Also: 'help regexp syntax' for an explanation of regular expressions.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGMATCHI()
  Function: regmatchi(<string>,<regexp>[,<register list>])
  
  This function matches the regular expression <regexp> against the
  entirety of <string>, returning 1 if it matches and 0 if it does not.
  This function is case insensitive.
  
  If <register list> is specified, there is a side-effect: any
  parenthesized substrings within the regular expression will be set
  into the specified local registers, in the order they were specified
  in the list. <register list> can be a list of one through nine numbers.
  If the specified register is -1, the substring is not copied into a
  register. Under regmatchi, case of the substring may be modified.
  You may also use a-z as registers if currently enabled on your RhostMUSH.
  You may have to escape mush-special characters (like (, ), {, }, etc)
  Any invalid registers specified will be skipped over and ignored.
  
  Examples:
    > say regmatchi(cookies=30,\(.+\)=\(\[0-9\]*\))
    You say "1"
    > say regmatchi(cookies=30,\(.+\)=\(\[0-9\]*\),0 3 5) |%q0/%q3/%q5|
    You say "1 |cookies=30/cookies/30|
  
  See Also: 'help regexp syntax' for an explanation of regular expressions.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGNUMMATCH()
  Function: regnummatch(<string>, <regexp>, [,<delimiter>])
            regnummatchi(<string>, <regexp>, [,<delimiter>])
  
  This function returns the total matches of any word in the string
  that matches the specified regular expression.  This works exactly
  like nummatch() except it uses regular expressions.
  
  Example:
  > say regnummatch(one two three four five fourteen,.*ou.*)
  You say "2"
  
  See Also: nummatch(), regmatch(), regmatchall(), regmatchalli()
  
  'help regexp syntax' for an explanation of regular expressions.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGNUMMATCHI()
  Function: regnummatch(<string>, <regexp>, [,<delimiter>])
            regnummatchi(<string>, <regexp>, [,<delimiter>])
  
  This function returns the total matches of any word in the string
  that matches the specified regular expression.  This works exactly
  like nummatch() except it uses regular expressions.
  
  Example:
  > say regnummatch(one two three four five fourteen,.*ou.*)
  You say "2"
  
  See Also: nummatch(), regmatch(), regmatchall(), regmatchalli()
  
  'help regexp syntax' for an explanation of regular expressions.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGRAB()
  Function: regrab(<list>, <regexp>[, <delimiter>])
  
  This function returns the first word in list which matches the pattern.
  For grab(), the pattern is specified as in match(); i.e., it
  can contain wildcards. For regrab(), the pattern is a regular expression.
  
  Basically, this is a much more efficient way to do:
  1: extract(list, match(list, pattern, delimiter), 1) 
  2: extract(list, regmatch(list, regexp, delimiter), 1)
  
  Examples:
    > say regrab(this that those, (.)hat)
    You say "that"
    > say regrab(this tHat those phat, (.)hat)
    You say "phat"
  
  See Also: regrabi(), regraball(), regraballi(), grab(), graball()
    


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGRABALL()
  Function: regraball(<string>,<regexp>[,<delim>][,<output separator>])
  
  These functions work identically to the grab() and regrab()/regrabi()
  functions, save that they return all matches, not just the first: They
  return all words in the list <string> which match <pattern>.
  If none match, an empty string is returned.
  
  Examples:
  > say graball(This is a test of a test,test)
  You say "test test"
  > say graball(This is testing a test,tes*)
  You say "testing test"
  > say regraball(This is testing a test,s$)
  You say "This is"
  
  See also: match(), matchall(), grab(), regmatch(), regraballi(), regrab()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGRABALLI()
  Function: regraballi(<string>,<regexp>[,<delim>][,<output separator>])
  
  These functions work identically to the grab() and regrab()/regrabi()
  functions, save that they return all matches, not just the first: They
  return all words in the list <string> which match <pattern>.
  If none match, an empty string is returned.  This function is case-
  insensitive.
  
  Examples:
  > say graball(This is a test of a test,test)
  You say "test test"
  > say graball(This is testing a test,tes*)
  You say "testing test"
  > say regraballi(This is testing a test,s$)
  You say "This is"
  
  See also: match(), matchall(), grab(), regmatch()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGRABI()
  Function: regrabi(<list>, <regexp>[, <delimiter>])
  
  This function returns the first word in list which matches the pattern.
  For grab(), the pattern is specified as in match(); i.e., it
  can contain wildcards. For regrab(), the pattern is a regular expression.
  regrabi() is case-insensitive.
  
  Basically, this is a much more efficient way to do:
  1: extract(list, match(list, pattern, delimiter), 1)
  2: extract(list, regmatch(list, regexp, delimiter), 1)
  
  Examples:
    > say regrabi(this that those, (.)hat)
    You say "that"
    > say regrab(this tHat those phat, (.)hat)
    You say "tHat"
  
  See Also: regrab(), regraball(), regraballi(), grab(), graball()
    


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGREP()
  Function: regrep(<object>,<attrs>,<regexp> [,<key>])
  
  This function returns a list of attributes on <object> containing
  <pattern> (or matching <regexp>).  <attrs> is a wildcard pattern for
  attribute names to search; if you want to search all attributes, use "*".
  
  Parsing _does_ occur before this function is invoked. Therefore,
  "special" characters will need to be escaped out. 
  
  If <key> is specified as '1', attribute wildcards are done with
  regular expression matching.  The default is globbing (* and ?). 
  
  This function is case-sensitive. 
  
  Examples:
    > @va me=This is a test
    > @vb me=This is another test.
    > @vc me=Test Test Test whisooo!
    > say regrep(me,v*,is)
    You say "VA VB"
    > say regrep(me,v*,.is.)
    You say "VA VB VC"
  
  See Also: regrepi(), grep(), pgrep()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REGREPI()
  regrepi(<object>,<attrs>,<regexp> [,<key>])

  This function returns a list of attributes on <object> containing
  <pattern> (or matching <regexp>).  <attrs> is a wildcard pattern for
  attribute names to search; if you want to search all attributes, use "*".
  
  Parsing _does_ occur before this function is invoked. Therefore,
  "special" characters will need to be escaped out. 
  
  If <key> is specified as '1', attribute wildcards are done with
  regular expression matching.  The default is globbing (* and ?).
  
  This function is case-insensitive.
  
  Examples:
    > @va me=This is a test
    > @vb me=This is another test.
    > @vc me=Test Test Test whisooo!
    > say regrepi(me,v*,is)
    You say "VA VB"
    > say regrepi(me,v*,.is.)
    You say "VA VB VC"
  
  See Also: regrep(), grep(), pgrep()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



regular expression functions
  Function lists: Regular Expressions
  
  regedit()          -- Edits first case match based on regexp
  regeditall()       -- Edits all case matches based on regexp
  regeditalli()      -- Edits first non-case match based on regexp 
  regeditallilit()   -- Edits first non-case match based on escaped regexp
  regeditalllit()    -- Edits first case match based on escaped regexp
  regediti()         -- Edits first non-case match based on regexp
  regeditilit()      -- Edits first non-case match based on escaped regexp
  regeditlit()       -- Edits first case match based on escaped regexp
  reglmatch()        -- Returns first case position of regexp match
  reglmatchall()     -- Returns all case positions of regexp matches
  reglmatchalli()    -- Returns all non-case positions of regexp matches
  reglmatchi()       -- Returns first non-case position of regexp match
  regmatch()         -- Returns true(1) or false(0) on a case regexp match
  regmatchi()        -- Returns true(1) or false(0) on a non-case regexp match
  regnummatch()      -- Returns count of all case regexp matches
  regnummatchi()     -- Returns count of all non-case regexp matches
  regrab()           -- Returns string of first case regexp match
  regrabi()          -- Returns string of first non-case regexp match
  regraball()        -- Returns strings of all case regexp matches
  regraballi()       -- Returns strings of all non-case regexp matches
  regrep()           -- Returns attribs that contain string of case regexp
  regrepi()          -- Returns attribs that contain string of non-case regexp
  reswitch()         -- Switch based on case regexp match
  reswitchall()      -- Switch all based on case regexp match
  reswitchalli()     -- Switch all based on non-case regexp match
  reswitchi()        -- Switch based on non-case regexp match
  cluster_lattr()    -- Regexp capable attribute listing for clusters
  cluster_regrepi()  -- Returns attrs in cluster that contain non-case regexp
  cluster_regrep()   -- Returns attrs in cluster that contain case regexp
  cluster_wipe()     -- Regexp capable attribute cluster wiper     
  lattr()            -- Regexp capable attribute listing
  lattrp()           -- Regexp capable parent attribute listing
  wipe()             -- Regexp capable attribute wiper



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



relational functions
  Function Lists: Relational Functions
      
  alphamax()    - Returns the lexiographically highest word of submitted list.
  alphamin()    - Returns the lexiographically lowest word of submitted list.
  max()         - Returns the largest integer from amongst its argument.
  min()         - Returns the lowest integer from amongst its argument.
  eq()          - Returns true if two numerical values are the same.
  gt()          - Returns true if one numerical value is higher than the other.
  gte()         - Like gt(), but also returns true if the value is the same.
  lt()          - Returns true if one numerical value is lower than the other.
  lte()         - Like lt(), but also returns true if the value is the same.
  neq()         - Returns true if the two values are not the same.
  not()         - Takes a boolean value and returns its inverse.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REMAINDER()
  Function: remainder(<integer1>,<integer2>[,<integerN>]...)
  
  Returns the integer remainder from dividing <integer1> by <integer2>.
  This could be aliased to either modulo() or remainder().  To see
  which, do: think mod()
  
  You may specify more than two values.
   
  Example:
    > say remainder(15,3)
    You say "0"
    > say remainder(16,3)
    You say "1"
    > say remainder(17,3)
    You say "2"
    > say remainder(18,3)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: add(), fdiv(), div(), mul(), round(), sub(), trunc()
   


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REMFLAGS()
  Function: remflags(<list>,[&|]<flag(s)>[,<delim>[,<output delim>][,<type>]])
  
  The remflags function removes all dbref#'s in the given list that contains
  the flags specified.  You must use one of the operators for flag checks:
     & - match ALL flags for each dbref#.
     | - match ANY of the flags for each dbref#.
  
  This function returns the list of dbref#'s that correctly match up the
  flags you specified.
  
  You may specify a <type> of 1 to return values as objid's.
  
  Examples: (#1 is a wizard, nothing else is)
    > say remflags(#1 #2 #3 #4,&W)
    You say "#2 #3 #4"
    > say remflags(#1 #2 #3 #4,&Ws)
    You say "#1 #2 #3 #4"
    > say remflags(#1 #2 #3 #4,|Ws)
    You say "#2 #3 #4"
  
  Note: You may specify 'P' for players, 'R', for rooms, and 'E' for exits
        as valid flag checks.
  
  See Also: keepflags(), remtype(), keeptype()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REMIT()
  Function: remit(<list of locations>, <string> [,<to-reality-tog>] [,<key>])
  
  The remit() side-effect function is used to emit the given <string> to every
  location specified in the <list of locations>.
  
  This works similarilly to @pemit/list/contents.  By default ## is substitute
  for every <location> in the list.  This evaluates by default for every 
  location in the list.
  
  This function relies on the config parameter 'pemit_any_object' to
  be enabled to allow remitting to any room, otherwise, it will only
  work on rooms you control.
  
  This side-effect must be enabled (@list options to see if it is) before it
  can be used.  Anything using it must have the SIDEFX flag set.
   
  If the <to-reality-tog> is set to '1', then it assumes the remit is
  a 'to-reality' model, in which the <list of locations> takes the form:
  
       reality1 reality2 ... realityN/location1 location2 ... locationN
  
  Following <key> values exist:
    1 - Disable ## from evaluating in <string>.
    2 - Only evaluate once.  By default this disables ## from evaluating.
 
  Example:
    > say remit(here #0,Boo)
    Boo
    You say ""
    > say remit(real umbra/here #0,Boo,1)
    Boo
    You say ""
  
  This would have emitted 'Boo' to your current location and to #0 (if you had
  control of the room).
  
  See Also: @pemit, @emit
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



remove()
  Function: remove(<list>, <word(s)>[, <delim>])
 
  Remove takes a list and a word (or words), and returns the list, with the 
  word deleted from it.  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter 
  other than a space.  You may specify more than one word.
 
  Example:
    > say remove(this is a test, is)
    You say "this a test"
    > say remove(You can't remove, this)
    You say "You can't remove"
    > say remove(You can remove multiple words, You can)
    You say "remove multiple words"
    > say remove(How about an o-separated list, w ab, o) 
    You say "Hout an o-separated list"
  
  See Also: mid(), delete()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REMTYPE()
  Function: remtype(<string>,<type(s)>[,<delim>[,<output delim>][,<type>]])
 
  The remtype function removes all types of 'type' from the string 'string'.
  The different types are standard MUSH object types:
      PLAYER - specifying robots and players
      THING  - specifying objects
      ROOM   - specifying rooms
      EXIT   - specifying exits
      OTHER  - specifying anything not fitting a MUSH 'type'.
  
  You may specify optional separators and output separators.   You may specify
  more than one type at once.
  
  If you specify <type> as 1, the results are always returned as dbref#'s, 
  otherwise the values are returned as the element in <string>.
    
  If you specify <type> as 2, the results are returned as objid's.
    
  Examples: (#0 is a room, #1 #55 and #584 are players, #-1 is invalid (other))
    > say remtype(#0 #1 #55 #584 #-1,player)
    You say "#0 #-1"
    > say remtype(#0 #1 #55 #584 #-1,exit)
    You say "#0 #1 #55 #584 #-1"
    > say remtype(#0 #1 #55 #584 #-1,other)
    You say "#0 #1 #55 #584"
    > say remtype(#0@#1@#55@#584@#-1,other,@,|)
    You say "#0|#1|#55|#584"
    > say remtype(#0 #1 #55 #584 #-1,player other)
    You say "#0"
  
  See Also: delete(), remove(), ldelete(), replace(), keeptype()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REPEAT()
  Function: repeat(<string>,<number> [,<ansi>])
  
  This function simply repeats <string>, <number> times.  No spaces are
  inserted between each repetition.
  
  You may specify the <ansi> toggle to '1' to make repeat ansi aware
  which optimizes ansi but will have a cost in performance.  This 
  defaults to '0'.
  
  Example:
    > say repeat(Test, 5)
    You say, "TestTestTestTestTest"
  
  See Also: space()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REPLACE()
  Function: replace(<list>, <pos> [<pos2>..<posN>], <word>[[,<sep>] [,<osep>]])
   
  This function inserts a word into <list> so that the word becomes the
  <pos>'th element of the list, and the word previously in that position
  is removed.  This means that it appears between the <pos-1>'th and
  <pos+1>'th elements of the original list, replacing the word at that
  position.  This function may not be used to append a word to a list.
  You may specify more than one position.
   
  The <pos> fields may be negative to take the argument from the right
  instead of the left.
  
  You may specify a separate <sep> seperator or it assumes space if not
  provided.  
  
  The <osep> output delimiter may be more than one character, and if 
  enabled, '@@' can be used as another method for a null.  You may specify 
  an empty <osep> as well.
   
  Examples:
    > say replace(This is a test, 4, quiz)
    You say "This is a quiz"
    > say replace(Yet@Another@Mundane@List, 3, Funky, @)
    You say "Yet@Another@Funky@List"
  
  See Also: extract(), extractword(), insert(), ldelete(), delete(), rindex(),
            edit()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REQUIRE_TREES
  Flag: REQUIRE_TREES(q)
  
  When set on a target, that target will require the TREE method for all
  sets when it uses a character that is identified as a tree separator.
  This is a way to help better enforce tree sets on targets.  Keep in mind,
  this only affects sets, and nothing else as Rhost natively does not
  handle trees.
  
  See Also: ATTRIBUTE TREES



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REST()
  Function: rest(<string>[, <delim>])
 
  The rest function takes a string, returns all the string except the first
  word, that is, everything to the right of the first space, or an empty 
  string, or the empty string if there are no spaces in the string.  
 
  <delim> may be used to specify a word delimiter other than a space.
 
  Example:
    > say rest(This is a test) 
    You say "is a test"
    > say rest(Would you like coffee, or perhaps tea) 
    You say "you like coffee, or perhaps tea"
    > say rest(List!with!different!delimiters,!)
    You say "with!different!delimiters"
  
  See Also: first(), before(), after(), extract(), extractword()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RESWITCH()
  Function: reswitch(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>,[<patN>,<resN>],...[,<dflt>]])
  Function: reswitchall(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>,[<patN>,<resN>],...[,<dflt>]])
  Function: reswitchi(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>,[<patN>,<resN>],...[,<dflt>]])
  Function: reswitchalli(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>,[<patN>,<resN>],...[,<dflt>]])
  
  This function is just like switch(), except they compare <string> against
  a series of regular expressions, not wildcard patterns.  This function
  is case-sensitive.
  
  Example:
    > say reswitch(xxcxxxxxx,.*a.*,A,.*b.*,B,.*c.*,C,.*d.*,D,E)
    You say "C"
  
  See Also: switch(), reswitchi(), reswitchall(), reswitchalli(), regexps



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RESWITCHALL()
  Function: reswitchall(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>,[<patN>,<resN>],...[,<dflt>]])
  
  This function is just like switch(), except they compare <string> against
  a series of regular expressions, not wildcard patterns.  This function
  is case-sensitive.  This function will return all matches.
  
  Example:
    > say reswitchall(c,.a.,A,.b.,B,.c.,C,.d.,D,E)
    You say "C"
  
  See Also: switch(), reswitchi(), reswitch(), reswitchalli(), regexps



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RESWITCHALLI()
  Function: reswitchalli(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>,[<patN>,<resN>],...[,<dflt>]])
  
  This function is just like switch(), except they compare <string> against
  a series of regular expressions, not wildcard patterns.  This function
  is case-insensitive.  This function will return all matches.
  
  Example:
    > say switchall(c,.a.,A,.b.,B,.c.,C,.d.,D,E)
    You say "C"
  
  See Also: switch(), reswitchi(), reswitchi(), reswitchall(), regexps



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RESWITCHI()
  Function: reswitchi(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>,[<patN>,<resN>],...[,<dflt>]])
  
  This function is just like switch(), except they compare <string> against
  a series of regular expressions, not wildcard patterns.  This function
  is case-insensitive.
  
  Example:
    > say reswitchi(c,.a.,A,.b.,B,.c.,C,.d.,D,E)
    You say "C"
  
  See Also: switch(), reswitch(), reswitchall(), reswitchalli(), regexps



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REVERSE()
  Function: reverse(<string>)
            trreverse(<string>)
 
  Reverses the order of the characters of <string>.
  
  trreverse() works like reverse() except it transposes characters that 
  are reverseable.  Ergo, > to <, ] to [, } to { and so forth.
   
  Examples:
    > say reverse(This is a test)
    You say "tset a si sihT"
    > say reverse(This is a test, Really...)
    You say "...yllaeR ,tset a si sihT"
    > say reverse(A man, a plan, a canal -- Panama!)
    You say "!amanaP -- lanac a ,nalp a ,nam A"
    > say reverse(>>test<<)
    You say "<<tset>>"
    > say trreverse(>>test<<)
    You say ">>tset<<"
  
  See Also: revwords()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



revisions
  For historical changes file, please see 'help historical'
  
  All credits to players, codebases, or other is presented in the RHOST.CHANGES
  file in the readme directory in the source distribution.  The credits are too
  diverse and well too detailed to be sufficient as a small snippit in online
  help.
  
  Beginning with Rhost 3.9.1, the Development team has tracked all changes to
  the Rhost system in the helpfiles, so that users may see what changes have
  been made with each revision.  Each change is detailed in bullet-point format
  in a helpfile specific to its revision, along with the alias for the 
  developer who completed the change. 
  
  Do note, effort was done to backport help as much as possible all the way
  back to the initial 3.2.4 rewrite that started Rhost for what it is today.
  
  Any versioning of Rhost version 1.0 through 3.0 was sadly lost to time.
  
  The developers who may appear in these files are:
     ASH - [Ashen-Shugar]     * AMB -  Ambrosia            EEH - [Noltar]
     KRK - [Loki]               LNS - [Lensman]            ODN -  Odin
     SEA - [Seawolf]            THO - [Thorin]             NYS - [Nyctasia]
     ROK -  Rook                KAG -  Kage
  
  The current Lead Developer (which we change up) is marked with a '*'.
  Developers who are MIA or retired are surrounded in []'s.
   
  ***************************************************************************
  *** Current Revision: 4.1.0p2
  ***************************************************************************
  
  Available Revisions:
    1.0.0: 1.0.0p0 (NycMUD)
    1.5.0: 1.5.0p0 (NycMUSE
    2.0.0: 2.0.0p0 (SeawolfMUSE)
    3.0.0: 3.0.0p0 (alpha - led to 3.2.0)
    3.2.0: 3.2.0p0 (beta -- led to 3.2.4)
    3.2.4: 3.2.4p0, 3.2.4p1,  3.2.4p2,  3.2.4p3,  3.2.4p4,  3.2.4p5,  3.2.4p6,
           3.2.4p7, 3.2.4p8,  3.2.4p9,  3.2.4p10, 3.2.4p11, 3.2.4p12, 3.2.4p13,
           3.2.4p14, 3.2.4p15, 3.2.4p16, 3.2.4p17, 3.2.4p18
    3.9.0: 3.9.0p0, 3.9.0p1, 3.9.0p2
    3.9.1: 3.9.1p0, 3.9.1p1, 3.9.1p2
    3.9.2: 3.9.2p0, 3.9.2p1
    3.9.3: 3.9.3p0, 3.9.3p1, 3.9.3p2
    3.9.4: 3.9.4p0, 3.9.4p1, 3.9.4p2, 3.9.4p3, 3.9.4p4, 3.9.4p5
    3.9.5: 3.9.5p0, 3.9.5p1, 3.9.5p2, 3.9.5p3, 3.9.5p4
    4.0.0: 4.0.0p0, 4.0.0p1, 4.0.0p2, 4.0.0p3, 4.0.0p4
    4.1.0: 4.1.0p0, 4.1.0p1, 4.1.0p2
  
  See Also: historical, credits



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



REVWORDS()
  Function: revwords(<string>[, <delim>])
 
  Reverses the order of the words of <string>.  A word is considered to be
  any sequence of nonblank characters, separated by blanks, so punctuation
  characters that follow a word are considered part of the word.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than a space.
 
  Examples:
    > say revwords(This is a test\, Really...)
    You say "Really... test, a is This"
    > say revwords(Was it a cat I saw?)
    You say "saw? I cat a it Was"
  
  See Also: reverse(), trreverse()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RIGHT()
  Function: right(<string>, <position> [,<key>])
  
  Right will take a string and return the right-most position of characters
  from the string.  
  
  You may specify a <key> of 1 to tell right() to take the string raw and
  not do ansi-aware processing.  This will speed up the function.
  The default is '0' which does ansi processing.
  
  Note: the config param 'ansi_default' handles if the ansi handling is 
        configured default or not.  In which case the 'key' is reversed.
  
  Example:
    > say right(this is a test,5)
    You say " test"
    > say right(this is a test,10000)
    You say "this is a test"
    > say right(this is a test,0)
    You say ""
  
  See Also: left(), mid(), delete(), ljc(), rjc()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RINDEX()
  Function: rindex(<list>, <string>, <position>, <delimiter>)
  
  This function is similar to index(), except that it replaces the <string>
  starting at <position> in the given <list>.  You must specify a delimiter.
  If the string you are replacing is longer than the list, it is 
  automatically appended to the end.
  
  Example:
    > say rindex(this is a test,was another,2,%b)
    You say "this was another test"
    > say rindex(this is weird,rather weird you know,3,%b)
    You say "this is rather weird you know"
  
  See Also: index(), aindex, iindex()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RJ()
  Function: rjust(<string>, <length>[, <fill>])
            rj(<string>, <length>[, <fill>])
 
  This function pads a string with leading <fill> characters, or with spaces
  if no fill character is given) ("right-justifies") so it is <length> long.
  If <string> is longer than <length>, the <string> is returned; it is not
  truncated. <fill> may be a string of over one character.
  
  If you wish to use ansified filler, use printf() instead.
   
  Examples:
    > say -[rjust(foo,6)]-
    You say "-   foo-"
    > say %r0[rjust(foo,6)]7%r01234567
    You say "
    0   foo7
    01234567"
    > say =[rjust(bar,5,.)]=
    You say "=..bar="
  
  Alternate:
    > say =[printf($:.:5s,bar)]=       (The default justification is right)
    You say "=..bar="
  
  See Also: rjc(), ljust(), ljc(), strlen(), printf(), wrap(), template()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RJC()
  Function: rjc(<string>, <length> [,<fill>])     'Right Justify and Cut'
   
  This function pads a string with leading blanks to right justify the 
  <string> within a field of <length> characters.  If <string> is longer 
  than <length> it will be cut to fit within a field of <length> characters.
  You may specify an optional fill character.
  
  If you wish to use ansified filler, use printf() instead.
   
  Examples:
    > say -[rjc(foo,6)]-
    You say "-   foo-"
    > say -[rjc(this is foo,6)]-
    You say "-this i-"
   
  See Also: rjust(), ljc(), ljust(), printf(), wrap(), template()
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RJUST()
  Function: rjust(<string>, <length>[, <fill>])
            rj(<string>, <length>[, <fill>])
 
  This function pads a string with leading <fill> characters, or with spaces
  if no fill character is given) ("right-justifies") so it is <length> long.
  If <string> is longer than <length>, the <string> is returned; it is not
  truncated. <fill> may be a string of over one character.
  
  If you wish to use ansified filler, use printf() instead.
   
  Examples:
    > say -[rjust(foo,6)]-
    You say "-   foo-"
    > say %r0[rjust(foo,6)]7%r01234567
    You say "
    0   foo7
    01234567"
    > say =[rjust(bar,5,.)]=
    You say "=..bar="
  
  Alternate:
    > say =[printf($:.:5s,bar)]=       (The default justification is right)
    You say "=..bar="
  
  See Also: rjc(), ljust(), ljc(), strlen(), printf(), wrap(), template()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RLOC()
  Function: rloc(<object>,<levels>,[<type>])
 
  This function may be used to get the location of an object's location
  (for which you would previously use 'loc(loc(<object>))', which fails if you
  don't control <object>'s location).  <levels> indicates the number of
  nested 'loc' calls to make, so 'loc(loc(<object>))' could be replaced with
  'rloc(<object>,2)'.  If rloc() encounters a room, the dbref of the room
  is returned.
 
  You must either control the object or be nearby for it to work.  When used
  on an exit it returns the destination of the exit.  You can also use rloc()
  to find the location of players that are not set UNFINDABLE.
 
  rloc(<object>,0) is the same as num(<object>), and rloc(<object>,1) is the
  same as loc(<object>).
  
  When used on an exit, it will return the exits dbref#.  Exits do not have
  a nested location so it returns itself.  If you want the exit's location 
  use the home() function. If you want the exit's destination use the loc()
  function.

  Optionally, you can supply a <type> argument. This can be either "OBJECT",
  "THING", or "PLAYER". OBJECT is an alias for THING in this case.
  If supplied, once rloc encounters such an object type as the location on the
  way 'down' it will immediately stop and return that #dbref instead - handy
  for exotic cases like trying to find players sitting inside objects inside
  other players - you could use rloc(<target>,5,PLAYER) and it would return
  the player #DBREF if <target> was in some way nexted inside a player object.
   
  Example:
    > look
    Object(#123p)
    You are inside your object
    > @fo #123=look
    Object> Room(#124R)
    Object> You are inside a room.
    > say loc(me)
    You say "#123"
    > say rloc(me,1)
    You say "#123"
    > say rloc(me,2)
    You say "#124"
  
  See Also: loc(), where(), home()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RNUM()
  Function: rnum(<target>,<object>)
  
  Returns the dbref number of the object, from target's perspective.
  You must control <target> to successfully get the object's number.
  
  Example:
    > say room(me)
    You say "#5"
    > say room(#122) (if #122 is an object that you owned)
    You say "#123"
    > say room(#124) (if #124 is an object that you owned)
    You say "#123"
    > say name(#122)
    You say "thingy"
    > say num(thingy)
    You say "#-1" 
    > say rnum(thingy,#124)
    You say "#122"
  
  See Also: locate(), num(), objid()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ROBBERY
  Topic: ROBBERY
 
  Robbing is not allowed on this MUSH. If you really need money, ask your
  friendly neighborhood wizard.
  
  See Also: MONEY
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ROBOT
  Flag: ROBOT(r)
 
  If set on a player, indicates that the player is a robot and is allowed to
  use the OUTPUTPREFIX and OUTPUTSUFFIX commands that many publicly available
  robot programs require.  Some MUSHes do not restrict access to the
  OUTPUTPREFIX and OUTPUTSUFFIX commands.
 
  If set on an exit or a thing, indicates that robot players may not use the
  exit or pick up the thing, the player is treated as having failed the lock.
  
  See Also: OUTPUTPREFIX, OUTPUTSUFFIX, @robot
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ROMAN()
  Function: roman(<number>)
  
  This function converts the given number to the Roman Numeral equivelant.
  It will convert any number between 1 and 3999999.  As the normal
  overslash on the higher roman numerials are not easilly supported in a text
  environment, the higher roman numerals will be displayed as lower case.
  The following roman numeral mapping exists:
      I - 1          L - 50           v - 5000        c - 100000
      V - 5          C - 100          x - 10000       m - 1000000
      X - 10         M - 1000         l - 50000
  
  Examples:
    > say roman(1999)
    You say "MCMXCIX"
    > say roman(777777)
    You say "dcclxxvMMDCCLXXVII"
  
  See Also: pack()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ROOM
  Type: ROOM(R)   
  
  This flag is automatically set on rooms when you @dig a new
  room. It cannot be changed. Rooms have the added advantage that 
  they can be saved from destruction by setting the room to !BYEROOM
  
  HELP BYEROOM
  
  However, this can only be done if no other room/object was created 
  that overwrote your room when it was set for destruction.
  
  See Also: BYEROOM, @dig
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ROOM()
  Function: room(<obj>)
 
  Returns the number of the room that <obj> is in, or would be in if it
  executed LEAVE commands until it got to a room.  You can find out the
  containing room of objects you own, nearby objects, and findable players.
  
  If used on an exit, it returns the exits *destination*.  If you wish to
  return the location of the exit, use the home() function.
   
  Example:
    > I
    You are carrying:
    hat(#368)
    cat(#325)
    > look
    Mortal's Room(#367R)
    A bare room with nothing in it but a bed and a chair.
    > say I am in [room(me)], the cat is in room [room(cat)].
    You say "I am in #367, the cat is in room #367."
    > @fo hat=get cat 
    cat has left.
    > say The cat is in [loc(#325)] within room [room(#325)].
    You say "The cat is in #368 within room #367."
  
  See Also: loc(), rloc(), lrooms(), UNFINDABLE
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



rotl()
  Function: rotl(<string>,<count>)
  
  This function rotates a given string <count> number of characters to the
  left and wraps around the text.
  
  Examples:
    > say rotl(this is a test,5)
    You say "is a testthis "
    > say rotl(weird,2)
    You say "irdwe"
  
  See Also: shl(), shr(), rotr()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



rotr()
  Function: rotl(<string>,<count>)
  
  This function rotates a given string <count> number of characters to the
  right and wraps around the text.
  
  Examples:
    > say rotr(this is a test,5)
    You say " testthis is a"
    > say rotr(weird,2)
    You say "rdwei"
  
  See Also: shl(), shr(), rotl()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ROUND()
  Function: round(<number>,<places>)
 
  Rounds <number> to <places> decimal places.  <number> may be
  a floating point number, and an integer result is returned.
  
  You may specify a negative number to places to specfy a whole number
  rounding.
   
  Examples:
    > say round(5,0)
    You say "5"
    > say round(5.123,1)
    You say "5.1"
    > say round(9.8765,3)
    You say "9.877"
    > say round(5.5,0)
    You say "6"
    > say round(-5.5,0)
    You say "-6"
    > say round(5555555,-2)
    You say "5555600"
  
  See Also: div(), floor(), mod(), trunc()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ROYALTY
  Flag: ROYALTY(W)   
  
  If a person is ROYALTY, they are a wizard, unkillable, 
  subject to fewer restrictions, and able to use wizard commands.  
  In general, ROYALTY can do anything using #<number> or *<player>. 
  Only player #1 or SUPER-ROYALTY can set and unset the ROYALTY flag of 
  other players.  No ROYALTY can turn their own ROYALTY flag off.   
  
  See Also: GUILDMASTER, ARCHITECT, COUNCILOR, IMMORTAL
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



rpage
  Command: rpage[/<switch>] [[<control>]<message>]
  
  <control> is the formatter for the page (", ;, :, etc)
  
  This command will automatically page the last person who paged you.
  You need not specify a player name.  It accepts and understands all
  the format and commands that page would understand.
  
  Switches available:
    noansi -- show raw ansi (the %c/%x substitutions) instead of colors.
  
  See Also: page, lpage, mrpage, whisper, say, pose
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RSET()
  Function: rset(<object>,<[!]<flag> [[!]<flag> [!]<flag> ...]>)
            rset(<object>,<<attribute>:<value>> [,<tree>])
            rset(<object>,<<attribute>:_<fromobj>/<fromattr>> [,<tree>])
            rset(<object>/<attr>,[!]<attrflag>)
  
  The rset() function is a side-effect for the @set command.  It works nearly
  like the set() sideeffect, except it returns the string that it set. 
  Everything that worked with @set will work with rset().  It follows the 
  same permissions and restrictions of the command.  The SIDEFX flag is 
  required to use rset().
  
  You may specify the optional <tree> of '1' to specifically set a TREE with
  all branches filled (that do not exist) on the target.  A TREE set will
  also verify permission on every branch of that tree prior to setting.  
  Failure to set any of the branches, for any reason, will disallow 
  setting the attribute as well.
  
  The <tree> toggle is ignored on any method of rset() that does not 
  set or clear attributes.
   
  Type @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.
  
  Example:
  > @set me=safe
  Set.
  > say set(me,safe)
  You say ""
  > say rset(me,safe)
  You say "safe"
  
  See Also: toggle(), totemset(), lset(), set(), writable(), &, @set, 
            SIDEEFFECTS, ATTRIBUTE TREES
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RULER()
  Function: ruler(<object>/<attribute>, <ruler value>)
  
  This function will provide a ruler to quickly eyeball the character position
  of the output of the given attribute.  The <ruler value> must be a mulitple
  of 10, and must be between 0 and 100.  
  
  The ruler is color coded to help make it easier to quickly eyeball and 
  count out the position.  Handy for some functions that require positional
  arguments like creplace(), mid(), and @label.
  
  The output of this command works like a side-effect so the output can not
  be captured other than with @pipe.
  
  Examples:
    > &TEST me=Testing 1 2 3 Testing 1 2 3 Testing 1 2 3
    Set.
    > think ruler(me/test,60)
           | ---------|10-------|20-------|30-------|40-------|50-------|60 |
           | Testing 1 2 3 Testing 1 2 3 Testing 1 2 3                      |
    0      | 123456789012345678901234567890123456789012345678901234567890   |
           | ---------|10-------|20-------|30-------|40-------|50-------|60 |
  
  See Also: mid(), creplace(), @label



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RXDESC()
  Function: rxdesc(<target>)
  
  Returns a space separated list of all realitylevel-based descriptions that
  are visible to <target>. You must control <target>. If no levels are listed,
  nothing is returned. If you do not control the target, or if the target does
  not exist, '#-1' is returned.
  
  Example:
    > say rxdesc(me)
    You say 'Real specialDesc'.
    > say rxlevel(me)
    You say ""
  
  See Also: hasrxlevel(), hastxlevel(), rxlevel(), txlevel(), listrlevels(),
            chkreality()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



RXLEVEL()
  Function: rxlevel(<target> [,<value>])
  
  Returns a space separated list of <target>'s Rx Levels. You must control
  <target>.  If no levels are listed, nothing is returned.  If you do not 
  control the target, or if the target does not exist, '#-1' is returned.
  
  You may specify a value to set or unset if this SIDEEFFECT feature
  is enabled.  The enactor MUST be set SIDEFX for this to work.  You
  must have permission to set reality levels to use this.  Use 
  listrlevels() or @list rlevel to see the levels you can set.
  
  Example:
    > say rxlevel(me)
    You say 'Real'.
    > say rxlevel(me, !real)
    You say ""
    > say rxlevel(me)
    You say ""
  
  See Also: hasrxlevel(), hastxlevel(), txlevel(), listrlevels(), chkreality()
            rxdesc()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



S()
  Function: s(string)
 
  This function works like eval() in that it evaluates the string doing full 
  pronoun substitution and function evaluation and then returns that string.  
  As usually, %n is the name, %s the subjective pronoun, %o the objective, 
  %p the possessive, and %a the absolute possessive.  It is important to 
  note that the pronoun is that of the triggering object.
 
  So, if the ve of an object were: "[s(This is %n)], and I were to 
  type @trigger <object>/ve, it would return "This is <myname>", but 
  if vf were @trigger me/ve, then triggering the vf makes the ve 
  return "This is <object>"
  
  As stated, this will also evaluate functions as well.  If you wish to
  only evaluate substitutions, please refer to the subeval() function.
  
  Example:
    > @sex me=male
    Set.
    > s(this [add(1,1)] %p)
    You say "this 2 his" 
    > eval(this [add(1,1)] %p)
    You say "this 2 his" 
    > subeval(this [add(1,1)] %p)
    You say "this [add(1,1)] his" 
  
  See Also: SUBSTITUTIONS, eval(), subeval(), ueval(), streval(), u(), v()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SAFE
  Flag: SAFE(s)
 
  When set, requires the use of the /override switch to @destroy in order to
  destroy the object.  It does not prevent the destruction of the object,
  but merely requires some additional effort.  If a thing is set DESTROY_OK,
  its SAFE flag is ignored and it may be destroyed without using the /override
  switch.
  
  See Also: @destroy, DESTROY_OK, INDESTRUCTABLE
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SAFEBUFF()
  Function: safebuff(<list> [[,<delim>, [<length>]])
  
  This function will return the list, by cutting off from the end any partial
  string, based on the delimeter you specify <delim>.  If no delimeter is
  specified, it assumes a space.  A good place to have this is in search()
  functions that may reach or exceed the LBUF limit for output.
  
  Please note, ansi sequences will be stripped from this function before
  the buffer is cut back.  Thus, any ansi sequence given to this function
  will be removed.
  
  You may specify an optional length to which it will apply the logic
  to go to the first buffer.
  
  Example:
    > say search(eval=*)
    You say "#0 #1 ... #883 #884 #88" (in this case, '#885' would be cut off)
    > say safebuff(search(eval=*))
    You say "#0 #1 ... #883 #884" (the partial string '#885' was omitted)
    > say safebuff(aaa aa aaaa,,8)
    You say "aaa aa"
  
  In the above examples, the '...' would be the huge ammount of output.
  
  See Also: lit(), s(), t(), printf(), ljc(), rjc()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SAFELOG TOGGLE
  Toggle: SAFELOG
  
  When set on a player, it 'cleans' their say output for proper logging.
  Instead of 'You say "blah"' they will see 'So-n-So says "blah"' or
  whatever their @saystring is set as.  This works with SAY and ".
  
  See Also: say, ", @saystring



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SANDBOX()
  Function: sandbox(<string>, <function list> [,<key> [,<local> [,<type>]]])
  
  This function sandboxes the evaluated <string> based on the list of
  space separated functions in <function list>.  Any function that matches
  any function in the list will have restricted access.
  
  The following <key> exists:
    0 - Set the function deny (default)
    1 - Set the function ignore and check for local function.
  
  The following <local> key exists:
    0 - Don't check for local functions (@function/@lfunction) (default)
    1 - Check against @functions (in addition to built-in functions)
    2 - Check against @lfunctions (in addition to built-in functions)
    3 - Check against all possible function combinations
  
  The following <type> exists:
    0 - The function list is the list of functions denied. (default)
    1 - The function list is the list of functions allowed.
  
  A <key> of deny will return the #-1 PERMISSION DENIED
  A <key> of ignore will return the #-1 FUNCTION (blah) NOT FOUND
  
  Once you have the <type> defined as '1', it remains that way through
  all iterations of the sandbox()'d evaluation, regardless of how
  often sandbox() may be called recursively from inside it.
  
{ see 'help sandbox2' for examples }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SANDBOX2
  (CONTINUED)
  Function: sandbox(<string>, <function list> [,<key> [,<local> [,<type>]]])
  
  Examples:
    > @va me=BOO
    Set.
    > @lfunction boo=me/va
    LOCAL Function boo defined.
    > say sandbox(Test - [add(1,1)] [sub(1,1)] [boo()],add)
    You say "Test - #-1 PERMISSION DENIED 0 BOO"
    > say sandbox(Test - [add(1,1)] [sub(1,1)] [boo()],sub)
    You say "Test - 2 #-1 PERMISSION DENIED BOO"
    > say sandbox(Test - [add(1,1)] [sub(1,1)] [boo()],sub boo)
    You say "Test - 2 #-1 PERMISSION DENIED BOO"
    > say sandbox(Test - [add(1,1)] [sub(1,1)] [boo()],sub boo,,3)
    You say "Test - 2 #-1 PERMISSION DENIED #-1 PERMISSION DENIED"
    > say sandbox(Test - [add(1,1)] [sub(1,1)] [boo()],sub,,3,1)
    You say "Test - #-1 PERMISSION DENIED 0 #-1 PERMISSION DENIED"
    > say sandbox(Test - [add(1,1)] [sub(1,1)] [boo()],sub boo,,1,1)
    You say "Test - #-1 PERMISSION DENIED 0 #-1 PERMISSION DENIED"
    > say sandbox(Test - [add(1,1)] [sub(1,1)] [boo()],sub boo,,3,1)
    You say "Test - #-1 PERMISSION DENIED 0 BOO"
  
  See Also: pushregs(), ulocal(), zfunlocal(), eval(), privatize(), 
            localize(), subeval(), @lfunction



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



save
  RhostMUSH, unlike lp's, merc's, diku's or similiar mud derivitives, does not
  have a 'save' option.  Your player, upon creation, is automatically saved.
  Everything you do, whenever you do it, is also automatically saved.  So just
  have fun, relax, and enjoy your time on.   Leave the saving to us :)
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



say
  Command: say[/<switches>] <message>
  
  Says <message> out loud to everyone in your current room. You can also
  use '"<message>'.  No switches are allowed with the '"' shorthand.
  
  The following switches exist for the say command:
    /noansi    - Show the string literally and don't process ansi.  Only
                 useful with ZENTY_ANSI enabled (at compiletime).
  
  You may use two special attributes for pre and post processing of any
  says you receive.  These attributes will have substitutions evaluated
  but will not evaluate functions.  If these attributes are set NO_COMMAND
  then they will not be processed.
    SPEECH_PREFIX  -- Contents will be evaluated before the say/pose.
    SPEECH_SUFFIX  -- Contents will be evaluated after the say/pose.
  
  Both of these attributes handle three arguments.  These are:
    %0 - The original say/pose that triggered the attribute.
    %1 - The date in the form MM/DD/YYYY
    %2 - The time in the form HH:MM:SS
    %3 - The dbref# of the player issuing the say/pose/emit (#-1 if spoofed)
  
  See Also: page, pose, whisper, :, ;, ", @saystring
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



score
  Command: score
  Displays how much money you have.  Helpful to see if any machines are
  looping.
  
  See Also: @ps, LOOPING, inventory
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



scramble()
  Function:  scramble(<string>)
   
  This function scrambles a string, returning a random permutation of its
  characters. Note that this function does not pay any attention to spaces
  or other special characters; it will scramble these characters just like
  normal characters.
 
  Example:
    > say scramble(abcdef)
    You say "cfaedb"
 
  See Also:  shuffle(), garble()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



search classes
  Topic: SEARCH CLASSES
 
  You may use the following classes in @search, search(), searchng(),
  searchobjid(), and searchngobjid()
  
  function calls:
  
  TYPE      - Restricts to objects of the indicated type (OBJECTS, ROOMS,
              EXITS, PLAYERS).  THINGS may be used as an alias for OBJECTS.
  NAME      - Restricts to objects whose names start with <restriction>.
  OBJECTS   - A combination of TYPE=OBJECT and NAME=<restriction>.
  THINGS    - An alias for OBJECTS.
  ROOMS     - A combination of TYPE=ROOM and NAME=<restriction>.
  EXITS     - A combination of TYPE=EXIT and NAME=<restriction>.
  PLAYERS   - A combination of TYPE=PLAYER and NAME=<restriction>.
  FLAGS     - Restricts to objects which have the flags listed in
              <restriction> set..
  FLAGS2    - Restricts to objects which have the flags listed in
              <restriction> set.. (uses next set of flags)
  TOTEMS    - Restricts to objects which have the tier 0 totem letters.
  TOTEMS2   - Restricts to objects which have the tier 1 totem letters.
  TOTEMS3   - Restricts to objects which have the tier 2 totem letters.
  EVAL      - Evaluates the restriction for each object, replacing ##
              with the object's database number.  Evaluations that return
              TRUE (IE, not 0 or #-1) are selected.
  EOBJECT   - A combination of TYPE=OBJECT and EVAL=<restriction>.
  ETHING    - An alias for OBJECTS.
  EROOM     - A combination of TYPE=ROOM and EVAL=<restriction>.
  EEXIT     - A combination of TYPE=EXIT and EVAL=<restriction>.
  EPLAYER   - A combination of TYPE=PLAYER and EVAL=<restriction>.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SEARCH()
  Function: search([<player>] [<class>=<restriction>[,<low>[,<high>]]])
            searchobjid([<player>] [<class>=<restriction>[,<low>[,<high>]]])
  
  Note: See 'help search classes' on what you can search for.
  
  The search() function returns a list of objects that match the search
  criteria, which are the same as with the @search command.  This function
  costs as much as the @search command, so repeated use is expensive.
 
  Caution: if you use the [ and ] characters in an Eval selection you will
  need to escape them.
  
  The searchobjid() function works like search() but returns the objid's
  instead of the dbref#'s.
   
  Examples:
    > say search()
    You say "#226 #289 #325 #364 #368 #369"
    > @stats me
    6 objects = 0 rooms, 0 exits, 5 things, 1 players. (0 garbage)
    > say search(eval=\[eq(money(##),1)\])
    You say "#289 #325 #364 #368 #369"
    > say search(player=wizard)
    You say "#1"
    > say searchobjid(me)
    You say "#226:8128285820 #289:8929292929"
  
  See Also: searchng(), @search, @find, @stat, SEARCH CLASSES



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SEARCHNG()
  Function: searchng([<player>] [<class>=<restriction>[,<low>[,<high>]]])
            searchngobjid([<player>] [<class>=<restriction>[,<low>[,<high>]]])
  
  Note: See 'help search classes' on what you can search for.
  
  This function works exactly as search(), except it will not return any
  garbage (going/recover) objects in the results.
  
  The searchngobjid() function works like searchng() but returns the objid's
  instead of the dbref#'s.
  
  Examples:
    > say searchng()
    You say "#226 #289 #325 #364 #368 #369"
    > say searchngobjid(me)
    You say "#226:8128285820 #289:8929292929"
  
  See Also: search(), @search, @find, @stat, SEARCH CLASSES
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SEARCHNGOBJID()
