  Function: searchng([<player>] [<class>=<restriction>[,<low>[,<high>]]])
            searchngobjid([<player>] [<class>=<restriction>[,<low>[,<high>]]])
  
  Note: See 'help search classes' on what you can search for.
  
  This function works exactly as search(), except it will not return any
  garbage (going/recover) objects in the results.
  
  The searchngobjid() function works like searchng() but returns the objid's
  instead of the dbref#'s.
  
  Examples:
    > say searchng()
    You say "#226 #289 #325 #364 #368 #369"
    > say searchngobjid(me)
    You say "#226:8128285820 #289:8929292929"
  
  See Also: search(), @search, @find, @stat, SEARCH CLASSES
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SEARCHOBJID()
  Function: search([<player>] [<class>=<restriction>[,<low>[,<high>]]])
            searchobjid([<player>] [<class>=<restriction>[,<low>[,<high>]]])
  
  Note: See 'help search classes' on what you can search for.
  
  The search() function returns a list of objects that match the search
  criteria, which are the same as with the @search command.  This function
  costs as much as the @search command, so repeated use is expensive.
 
  Caution: if you use the [ and ] characters in an Eval selection you will
  need to escape them.
  
  The searchobjid() function works like search() but returns the objid's
  instead of the dbref#'s.
   
  Examples:
    > say search()
    You say "#226 #289 #325 #364 #368 #369"
    > @stats me
    6 objects = 0 rooms, 0 exits, 5 things, 1 players. (0 garbage)
    > say search(eval=\[eq(money(##),1)\])
    You say "#289 #325 #364 #368 #369"
    > say search(player=wizard)
    You say "#1"
    > say searchobjid(me)
    You say "#226:8128285820 #289:8929292929"
  
  See Also: searchng(), @search, @find, @stat, SEARCH CLASSES



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SECS()
  Function: secs()
            msecs()
 
  Returns the number of elapsed seconds since midnight, January 1, 1970.
  This is an easy way to time things.
  
  The msecs() function works like secs() but gives the fractional milisecond
  of the current time.
   
  Example:
     > say secs()
     You say "692636020"
     ... wait a bit ...
     > say secs()
     You say "692636043"
     > say msecs()
     You say "692636049.7"
  
  See Also: convsecs(), convtime(), time(), timefmt()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SECURE()
  Function: secure(<string>)
  
  Returns <string> after replacing the characters [](){};%\^,$ with spaces.
  This prevents strings entered by players from causing undesired side
  effects when used, such as making your object perform unintended commands
  or give out information to which you have access.  Note that this function
  is only needed when the resulting string is to be passed through the @force
  command or be used as an attribute for an object (like the success message
  for a mail message object).
 
  Examples:
    > @va me=Sneak a peek at Wiz's desc... [get(#1/desc)]
    > say secure(%va)
    You say "Sneak a peek at Wiz's desc...  get #1/desc  "
    > say secure($foobar:this {is} a really, tough ; test.)
    You say " foobar:this is a really tough   test."
 
  Note: 'say secure(Sneak a peek at Wiz's desc... [get(#1/desc)])' does not
  produce the expected result because the argument is evaluated BEFORE being
  processed by secure(), therefore the [get()] call has already been
  performed.
  
  See Also: escape(), escapex(), esclist(), unesclist()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SECUREX()
  function: securex(<string> [,<omission>])
  
  This functions exactly like secure(), except you may specify what characters
  you do not wish to be secured out.  The following special characters are
  available for omitting:
     a - ignore all forms of ansi subsitutions from the string.
  
  Examples:
    > @va me=Sneak a peek at Wiz's desc... [get(#1/desc)]
    > say securex(%va)
    You say "Sneak a peek at Wiz's desc...  get #1/desc  "
    > say securex($foobar:this {is} a really, tough ; test.,;)
    You say " foobar:this is a really tough ; test."
    > @va me=%rTest?  Yes, a test.
    > say securex(v(va),\%)
    You say "%rTest?  Yes  a test.
    > say securex(v(va),\%\,)
    You say "%rTest?  Yes, a test.
  
  See Also: secure(), escape(), escapex(), esclist(), unesclist()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



sees()
  Function: sees(<object>, <target> [,<type>])
  
  This function returns true (1) if the object is able to see target at
  target's location.  Otherwise, it will return false (0).  You need to
  control the object to be able to successfully return the result else
  '0' will always be returned.  This will work similiar if you actually
  looked at the room.  Naturally, as you wouldn't see yourself, it'll
  return '0' for that condition.
  
  You may specify <type> as '1' if you wish to check for exits.  Normally
  exits will be ignored.
  
  Examples:
    > look
    A room
    You see a room before you.
    Contents:
    testobj
    > say sees(me,me)
    You say "0"
    > say sees(me,testobj)
    You say "1"
  
  See Also: look, visible()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SEMAPHORES
  Topic: SEMAPHORES
 
  Semaphores may be used for synchronizing complex objects or for enforcing
  mutual exclusion.  You may use any object you own or any LINK_OK object as
  a semaphore, and any type of object (thing, room, player, or exit) may be
  used.
 
  The semaphore state of an object is shown by the Semaphore attribute (which
  is read-only); a positive number indicates the number of commands awaiting
  notifies, and a negative number indicates the number of waits on that
  semaphore that will not block.
 
  Use the '@wait <object>' form of the @wait command to request a command be
  delayed until <object> is notified with the @notify command.  The @drain
  and @notify/all commands clear the semaphore on <object>, either
  discarding or executing all pending commands.  Remember that the
  object performing the @wait executes the command, not the object used
  as a semaphore. 
  
{ 'help semaphores2' for more }


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



semaphores2
  You may also combine the semaphore and timer options of @wait with
  '@wait <object>/<timeout> = <command>'  If the time period expires before
  the semaphore is notified, then the command is executed and the semaphore
  count is decremented, just as if the command had been run because the
  semaphore had been notified.
 
  Examples: <simple>     @wait semaphore="Foo
                         @notify semaphore
            <mutex lock> @va mutex lock=@wait me=@trig me/vb
                         @vb mutex lock="Got it!;@notify me
                         @startup mutex lock=@notify me
            <timed wait> @wait timer/60 = "Sixty Second Timer.
 
  In the above examples you will say "Foo" after semaphore is notified,
  you will say "Got it" when you have the mutual exclusion lock mutex lock
  (You could have also modified object registers that need to be protected
  from concurrent update), and you will say "Sixty Second Timer." either when
  timer is notified or after sixty seconds pass.
 
  See Also: @drain, @notify, @wait, @halt
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SENSES
  Senses are the five senses that a human has (keeping 6th sense or other
  perceptuary abilities out of the loop).  These senses are re-enacted with
  the five following commands.
        LOOK   - allows you to view things (mush standard)
                 @desc     - what enactor sees.
                 @adesc    - action that occurs.
                 @odesc    - what everyone but enactor sees.
        TOUCH  - allows you to touch things with following reactions.
                 @stouch   - what enactor sees.
                 @satouch  - action that occurs.
                 @sotouch  - what everyone but enactor sees.
        TASTE  - allows you to taste things with following reactions.
                 @staste   - what enactor sees.
                 @sataste  - action that occurs.
                 @sotaste  - what everyone but enactor sees.
        LISTEN - allows you to hear things with following reactions.
                 @slisten  - what enactor sees.
                 @salisten - action that occurs.
                 @solisten - what everyone but enactor sees.
        SMELL  - allows you to smell things with following reactions.
                 @ssmell   - what enactor sees.
                 @sasmell  - action that occurs.
                 @sosmell  - what everyone but enactor sees.
        


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SESSION
  Command: SESSION
  Displays information on how many characters you have sent and received
  during this session, and which (Internal) port you are connected to on the
  mush.  It must be typed in all uppercase.
 
  Example:
   > SESSION
                                   Characters Input----  Characters Output---
  Player Name     On For Idle Cmds Pend  Lost     Total  Pend  Lost     Total
  Mortal           00:06   0s   16    0     0        44   156     0      2679
  2 Players logged in.
 
  Pending characters are those waiting to be acted on as commands (for input)
  or waiting to be sent out over the network (output).  Lost characters are
  due to overflowing either the MUSH's input or output buffers, either as the
  result of running a single command that produces too much output (such as
  @find and @search commands that match a large number of objects), or from
  typing too much on one line.
 
  Note: your Pending count for output will always be nonzero, as the output
  of the SESSION command hasn't been sent out over the network yet.
  
  See Also: WHO, DOING
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SET()
  Function: set(<object>,<[!]<flag> [[!]<flag> [!]<flag> ...]>)
            set(<object>,<<attribute>:<value>> [,<tree>])
            set(<object>,<<attribute>:_<fromobj>/<fromattr>> [,<tree>])
            set(<object>/<attr>,[!]<attrflag>)
  
  The set() function is a side-effect for the @set command.  Everything that
  worked with @set will work with set().  It follows the same permissions and
  restrictions of the command.  The SIDEFX flag is required to use set().
  
  You may specify the optional <tree> of '1' or '3' to specifically set a 
  TREE with all branches filled (that do not exist) on the target.  A TREE 
  set will also verify permission on every branch of that tree prior to 
  setting.  Failure to set any of the branches, for any reason, will disallow 
  setting the attribute as well.
  
  You may specify an optional <tree> of '2' or '3' to specify that all
  attributes set will ignore the special case of '_' (third example above) 
  when setting attributes.  Otherwise, doing '_foo/bar' will try to fetch
  attribute 'bar' from object '_foo' and set it to that attribute. 
    
  The <tree> toggle is ignored on any method of set() that does not 
  set or clear attributes.
   
  Type @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.
  
  Example:
  > @set me=safe
  Set.
  > say set(me,safe)
  You say ""
  > say set(me,_content_)
  You say "No match."
  > say set(me,_content_,2)
  You say ""
  
  See Also: toggle(), totemset() lset(), rset(), writable(), &, @set, 
            SIDEEFFECTS, ATTRIBUTE TREES
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SETDIFF()
  Function: setdiff(<list1>, <list2>[, <delim> [, <sep> [, <sorttype>]]])
   
  This function returns the difference of two sets -- i.e., the elements in
  <list1> that aren't in <list2>. The list that is returned is sorted.
   
  If <delim> is specified, it (rather than a space) is used to separate items
  in the list.
  
  If <sep> is specified, it will be used (rather than a space) for the output
  separator for the list.
  
  If <sorttype> is specified, you may have a different sort than the default
  alphanumerical sort.  (d)bref, (n)umeric, (f)loat, (a)lphanumeric.
   
  Example:
    > say setdiff(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep)
    You say, "baz foo"
    > say setdiff(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep,,-)
    You say, "baz-foo"
  
  See Also: setinter(), setunion(), sort(), listdiff()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SETINTER()
  Function: setinter(<list1>, <list2>[, <delim> [, <sep> [, <sorttype>]]])
   
  This function returns the intersection of two sets -- i.e., the elements
  that are in both <list1> and <list2>. The list that is returned is sorted.
  
  If <delim> is specified, it (rather than a space) is used to separate items
  in the list.
   
  If <sep> is specified, it will be used (rather than a space) for the output
  separator for the list.
  
  If <sorttype> is specified, you may have a different sort than the default
  alphanumerical sort.  (d)bref, (n)umeric, (f)loat, (a)lphanumeric.
  
  Example:
    > say setinter(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep)
    You say, "bar gleep"
    > say setinter(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep,,-)
    You say, "bar-gleep"
  
  See Also: setdiff(), setunion(), sort(), listinter()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SETQ()
  Function: setq(<register>,<string>[,<label>])
            setq(<label>,<string>[,<label>)
            setq(!,<string>,<label>)
            setq(+,<string>,<label>)
  
      -- Penn Compatibility (if enabled via penn_setq admin param) 
            setq(<label|register>,<string>)
            setq(+,<string>,<label>)
            setq(!,<string>,<label>)
 
  The setq() function is used to copy strings into local registers.
  It returns a null string; it is a purely "side effect" function.
  
  There are ten local registers, numbered 0 through 9. They are cleared
  at the start of each command. They are most useful for storing complex
  function evaluations which are used repeatedly within a single command.
  The local registers may be read via the r() function, and a common use
  of setq()/r() is to temporarily store the result of a complex evaluation
  whose result is needed more than once.
 
  setq() can be used to improve the readability of MUSH code, as well as to
  cut down the amount of time needed to do complex evaluations.
  
  If enhanced setq has been enabled at compiletime, you may use a-z as well.
  Enabling this in the code can cause some excess memory usage.
  
  Compiletime may also switch this functionality with SETQ_OLD().  Check
  @list options to see if it was.
  
  You may specify an optional label to assign the register to later call
  with r().  Labels can contain any character and must be 31 chars or less.
  You may then specify the label instead of the <number>.  Using '!' for the
  number/label specifies to reuse the label OR assign a label to the next
  available register automatically.  '+' will use the first  unnamed AND
  unused register.  '!' just uses the first unnamed register.
  
  If the label is 0-9 or a-z when using '+' or '!' it assumes you want the
  register set and not a label assigned.
   
  Example:
    > &TEST me=Test on [mudname()] at [time()].
    > say [setq(0,u(TEST))]'[r(0)]' has length [strlen(r(0))].
    You say "'Test on TestMUSH at Tue Feb 23 17:00:51 1993.' has length 45."
    > say [setq(0,u(TEST),test)][setq(test,Test: [u(test)])][r(0)]
    You say "Test: Test on TestMUSH at Tue Feb 23 17:00:51 1993"
  
  See Also: setr(), setr_old(), setq_old(), r(), nameq(), inc(), dec(), 
            setqmatch(), SETQ_TEMPLATE
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SETQ_OLD()
  Function: setq_old(<register>,<string>[,<label>])
            setq_old(<label>,<string>[,<label>])
            setq_old(!,<string>,<label>)
            setq_old(+,<string>,<label>)
  
      -- Penn Compatibility (if enabled via penn_setq admin param) 
            setq_old(<label|register>,<string>)
            setq_old(+,<string>,<label>)
            setq_old(!,<string>,<label>)
  
  This functions exactly like setq(), except it is using the old MUSH 
  method of evaluation.  This tends to be less abraisive on braces and
  brackets.
  
  Please check @list options to see if SETQ_OLD and SETQ are switched
  at compiletime.
  
  You may specify an optional label to assign the register to later call
  with r().  Labels can contain any character and must be 31 chars or less.
  You may then specify the label instead of the <number>.  Using '!' for the
  number/label specifies to reuse the label OR assign a label to the next
  available register automatically.  '+' will use the first unnamed AND
  unused register.  '!' just uses the first unnamed register.
  
  If the label is 0-9 or a-z when using '+' or '!' it assumes you want the
  register set and not a label assigned.

  See Also: setr_old(), setq(), setr(), nameq(), SETQ_TEMPLATE
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SETQ_TEMPLATES
  You can specify 'templates' for setq registers to automatically have 
  pre-defined labels for each individual object.  This is done by setting
  a string in the attribute 'SETQ_TEMPLATE' on the object.  The attribute
  should be in the format:  <register>:<string>
  
  So an example would be:   0:foobar 1:xyzzy q:myqreg
  
  This would set a template on an object where it would preassign the
  label 'foobar' to register 0, 'xyzzy' to register 1, and 'myqreg' to
  register q.
  
  Note:  These are only useful for the immediate calling $commands.
  They are not transversed through u() functions, @triggers, or other
  action based events.
  
  You may redefine these labels as you would normally with nameq(), 
  setq(), or setr().
  
  See Also: nameq(), setq(), setr()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SETQMATCH()
  Function: setqmatch(<string>, <pattern>[,delim])
 
  The setqmatch() function tries to match <pattern> against <string>. If it
  succeeds, it returns 1 and puts the text that matched each wildcard (up to
  ten) into successive setq registers. The first wildcard's match goes into
  register 0, the second into register 1, etc.
 
  (If it reaches '10' and there's more, dump the remaining into
   '10' if '10' is a '*' wildcard and not a '?' wildcard)
 
  If it fails, it returns 0.  If optional delimiter of 'n' is specified,
  then it returns nothing for failures or successes.  Default is 'y' for
  returning values.
 
  Example:
    > say setqmatch(This is a test, *test) -- [r(0)]
    You say "1 -- This is a "
    > say setqmatch(open the door hal, open * ???) -- [r(0)] -- [r(2)]
    You say "1 -- the door -- a"
    > say setqmatch(kow, wok)
    You say "0"
    > say setqmatch(kow, wok, n)
    You say ""
  
  See Also: listmatch(), match(), totmatch(), wildmatch(), setq()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SETR()
  Function: setr(<register>,<string>[,<label>])
            setr(<label>,<string>[,<label>])
            setr(!,<string>,<label>)
            setr(+,<string>,<label>)
  
      -- Penn Compatibility (if enabled via penn_setq admin param) 
            setr(<label|register>,<string>)
            setr(+,<string>,<label>)
            setr(!,<string>,<label>)
 
  The setr() function is used to copy strings into local registers.
  Unlike setq(), it returns its <string> argument.
  In all other respects it is identical to setq().
  
  If enhanced setq has been enabled at compiletime, you may use a-z as well.
  Enabling this in the code can cause some excess memory usage.
  
  Compiletime may also switch this functionality with SETR_OLD().  Check
  @list options to see if it was.
  
  You may specify an optional label to assign the register to later call
  with r().  Labels can contain any character and must be 31 chars or less.
  You may then specify the label instead of the <number>.  Using '!' for the
  number/label specifies to reuse the label OR assign a label to the next
  available register automatically.  '+' will use the first unnamed AND
  unused register.  '!' just uses the first unnamed register.
  
  If the label is 0-9 or a-z when using '+' or '!' it assumes you want the
  register set and not a label assigned.
   
  Example: 
    > &TEST me=Test on [mudname()] at [time()].
    > say '[setr(0,u(TEST))]' has length [strlen(r(0))].
    You say "'Test on TestMUSH at Tue Feb 23 17:00:51 1993.' has length 45."
  
  See Also: setq(), setq_old(), setr_old(), r(), nameq(), inc(), dec(),
            setqmatch(), SETQ_TEMPLATE
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SETR_OLD()
  Function: setr_old(<register>,<string>[,<label>])
            setr_old(<label>,<string>[,<label>])
            setr_old(!,<string>,<label>)
            setr_old(+,<string>,<label>)
  
      -- Penn Compatibility (if enabled via penn_setq admin param) 
            setr_old(<label|register>,<string>)
            setr_old(+,<string>,<label>)
            setr_old(!,<string>,<label>)
  
  This functions exactly like setr(), except it is using the old MUSH 
  method of evaluation.  This tends to be less abraisive on braces and
  brackets.
  
  Please check @list options to see if SETR_OLD and SETR are switched
  at compiletime.
  
  You may specify an optional label to assign the register to later call
  with r().  Labels can contain any character and must be 31 chars or less.
  You may then specify the label instead of the <number>.  Using '!' for the
  number/label specifies to reuse the label OR assign a label to the next
  available register automatically.  '+' will use the first unnamed AND
  unused register.  '!' just uses the first unnamed register.
  
  If the label is 0-9 or a-z when using '+' or '!' it assumes you want the
  register set and not a label assigned.
  
  See Also: setq_old(), setq(), setr(), nameq(), SETQ_TEMPLATE
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SETUNION()
  Function: setunion(<list1>, <list2>[, <delim> [, <sep> [, <sorttype>]]])
   
  This function returns the union of two sets -- i.e., all the elements of
  both <list1> and <list2>, minus any duplicate elements. Think of it as
  CAT() without duplicated words.  The list returned is sorted.
   
  If <delim> is specified, it (rather than a space) is used to separate items
  in the list.
   
  If <sep> is specified, it will be used (rather than a space) for the output
  separator for the list.
  
  If <sorttype> is specified, you may have a different sort than the default
  alphanumerical sort.  (d)bref, (n)umeric, (f)loat, (a)lphanumeric.
   
  Example:
    > say setunion(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep)
    You say, "bar baz foo gleep moof"
    > say setunion(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep,,-)
    You say, "bar-baz-foo-gleep-moof"
  
  See Also: setdiff(), setinter(), sort(), listunion()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SHIFT()
  Function: shift(<value>)
            shift()
  
  This function controls the values returned with %0-%9 (or v(0)-v(9)) with
  regards to u() attributes, functions or @functions.  Each increment to
  shift will shift the values 10.  So shift(1) will make %5 actually be
  the 15's argument, not the 5th.  You can shift up to the max arguments
  currently allowed by the mush.  The default is 30 total arguments, thus
  you can shift to the value '3'.
  
  If you do not specify an argument, it shows you what the current shift 
  value is set to.  This value resets itself for each pass through the
  queue (or by user-intervention).

  See Also: v()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



shl()
  Function: shl(<number or string>,<count>)
  
  Performs a leftwards bit-shift on <number>, shifting it <count> times.
  This is equivalent to mul(<number>,pow(2,<count>), but much faster.
  This function also shifts left a given string <count> number
  of characters.
  
  Examples:
    > say shl(1,4)
    You say "16"
    > say shl(weird!!!,3)
    You say "rd!!!"
  
  See Also: shr(), rotl(), rotr()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SHOWFAILCMD
  Flag: SHOWFAILCMD([f])  
  
  This flag, when set on an item, will return the 
  appropiate @ufail messages (ufail, aufail, oufail), if there is a
  matching $command and the object is uselocked against you.
  
  If the object is set SHOWFAILCMD in addition to STOP, then the
  error is showed appropiately and all command processing is 
  stopped at that point as well.
  
  See Also: @ufail, @fail
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



shr()
  Function: shr(<number or string>,<count>)
  
  Performs a rightwards bit-shift on <number>, shifting it <count> times.
  This is equivalent to div(<number>,pow(2,<count>), but much faster.
  Function: case(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>]...[,<dflt>]).  This function also
  shifts right a given string <count> number of characters.
  
  Examples:
    > say shr(16,3)
    You say "2"
    > say shr(weird!!!,4)
    You say "weir"
  
  See Also: shl(), rotl(), rotr()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



shuffle()
  Function: shuffle(<string> [,<delim> [,<output sep>]])
  
  Returns the string randomly 'shuffled' or mixed up with regards to order.
  You may specify an optional delimiter instead of the default 'space' as
  well as an optional filler.
  
  Example:
    > say shuffle(This is a test)
    You say "This a is test"               (separator is a space ' ')
    > say shuffle(This is a test)
    You say "a test This is"
    > say shuffle(This@is@a@test,@)
    You say "is@a@This@test"               (separator is a '@')
    > say shuffle(This@is@a@test,@,|)
    You say "This|test|a|is"               (separator is '@', filler is '|')
  
  See Also: rand(), scramble(), sort(), setdiff(), setinter(), setunion() 
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



side effect functions
  Function Lists: Side Effect Functions.
    
  clone()         - Clones an object.
  create()        - Creates an object.
  destroy()       - Destroys an object.
  dig()           - Creates a room object.
  emit()          - Emits a string to your location.
  lemit()         - Like emit(), but finds the outermost room of your location.
  link()          - Links an object to another.
  list()          - Like iter(), but is buffer limit safe.
  lock()          - Sets a specified lock on an object.
  name()          - Sets the name of an object.
  nameq()         - (Re)names setq variables with a new label.
  npemit()        - Like pemit(), but will not strip spaces.
  oemit()         - Like emit(), but will omit a specified target.
  open()          - Opens an exit.
  parent()        - Parents an object to another.
  pemit()         - Emits a string to a list of targets.
  r()             - Accesses local registers, and outputs its contents.
  remit()         - Emits text to a specified room.
  rset()          - Like set(), but returns the string that is set.
  ruler()         - Display a ruler outline of contents of an attribute.
  rxlevel()       - Sets or unsets a reality receive level for an object.
  set()           - Sets an attribute on an object.
  setq()          - Copies a string into a local register.
  setq_old()      - Like setq(), but with old-style MUSH functionality.
  setr()          - Like setq(), but also displays the string.
  setr_old()      - Like setr(), but with old-style MUSH functionality.
  tel()           - Teleports an object to a location.
  toggle()        - Toggles a toggle on an object.
  totemset()      - Set/remove a @totem on a target.
  txlevel()       - Sets or unsets a reality transmit level for an object.
  wipe()          - Wipes attribute(s) from object.
  zemit()         - Emits a string to every room of a zone.
  sqlite_query()  - SQL Lite database query.
  sql()           - MySQL database query.
  sqlescape()     - MySQL escape driven query.
  sqlon()         - MySQL database enabler.
  sqloff()        - MySQL database deabler.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SIDEEFFECTS
  RhostMUSH supports side-effect functions.  This has to be enabled by
  the site owner before they can be used.  In addition, due to the many
  security issues that arise from using side-effects, before the 
  function is accessable, it must be set SIDEFX.
  
  Please check @list options to see if side effects are enabled and
  what side effects are enabled of the list.  list(), being relatively
  harmless in how it's coded, is omitted from the restrictions 
  found with normal side-effects.
  
  MUX and PENN style sideeffects are both supported.  Support for the
  force(), trigger() and wait() functions found in TinyMUSH 3.0 will 
  NOT be supported ever.  They're silly functions to add and the
  security issues involved with these functions are too large to ignore.
  
  NOTE:  Side-effects are generally frowned upon and should not be used
         at all.  This was only done for compatibility.
  
  Type '@list options' to see what side-effects are currently in effect.
    
  MUX sideeffects supported:   SET, CREATE, LINK, PEMIT, TEL, LIST, OEMIT,
                               PARENT, and DESTROY
  PENN sideeffects supported:  SET, CREATE, LINK, PEMIT, TEL, DIG, OPEN, 
                               EMIT, OEMIT, CLONE, PARENT, LOCK, LEMIT, 
                               REMIT, WIPE, ZEMIT, NAME, and LSET
  OTHER sideeffects supported: DESTROY, TOGGLE, TXLEVEL, RXLEVEL, RSET, 
                               and MOVE

  The following sideeffects are handled by the database portion as a
  separate entity.
  
  DB sideeffects supported:    SQLITE_QUERY, SQL, SQLON, SQLOFF, 
                               SQLESCAPE, SQLPING
  
  Help is available on MUX, PENN and OTHER side-effects by name.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SIDEFX
  Flag: SIDEFX([s])  
  
  If set on the target, the target is gained the ability
  to be able to execute (and use) side-effects.  Without this flag,
  it is impossible to use side-effects.  
  
  Please check '@list options' to see what side-effects (if any) are
  enabled on the RhostMUSH you're on and if you have access to them.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SIGN()
  Function: sign(<number>)
 
  Returns -1, 0, or 1 depending on whether its argument is negative, zero, or
  positive (respectively).
 
  Example:
  > say sign(-4)
  You say "-1"
  > say sign(4)
  You say "1"
  > say sign(0)
  You say "0"
  > say sign(-1)
  You say "-1"
  
  See Also: abs()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SIN()
  Function: sin(<number> [,<units>])
   
  Returns the sine of <number>, expressed in radians.
  
  You may specify <units> which are either (r)adians,
  (g)radians, or (d)egrees.  (r)adians are the default.
   
  Examples:
    > say sin(0)
    You say "0"
    > say sin(fdiv(pi(),2))
    You say "1"
    > say sin(fdiv(pi(),4))
    You say "0.707107"
    > say sin(fdiv(pi(),6))
    You say "0.5"
  
  See Also: acos(), asin(), atan(), atan2(), cos(), pi(), tan(), ctu(), 
            sinh(), cosh(), tanh()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SINGLETHREADING
  You can accomplish 'single-threading' $commands by setting the attribute
  on the object SINGLETHREAD.  Once set, you must have at the end of the
  processing a way to set the attribute !NO_COMMAND, else that $command
  will no longer be executable until the attribute's NO_COMMAND flag is
  removed.
  
  You may globally set the attribute SINGLETHREAD as well.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SINGLETIME()
  Function: singletime(<seconds>)
 
  This function converts seconds to a single time element which is
  the lowest approximation to the given number of <seconds>.
  
  The following letters are relevant:
    s - second    d - day     y - year               e - epoch
    m - minute    w - week    C - century
    h - hour      M - month   a - annum(Millennium)
  
  Note:  an epoch is 1 million years or more.
    
  Example:
    > say singletime(45)
    You say "45s"
    > say singletime(12345)
    You say "3h"
    > say singletime(123456)
    You say "1d"
 
  Related Topics: secs(), time(), timefmt()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SINH()
  Function: sinh(<number> [,<units>])
   
  Returns the hyperbolic sine of <number>, expressed in radians.
  
  You may specify <units> which are either (r)adians,
  (g)radians, or (d)egrees.  (r)adians are the default.
   
  Examples:
    > say sinh(0)
    You say "0"
    > say sinh(fdiv(pi(),2))
    You say "2.301298"
    > say sinh(fdiv(pi(),4))
    You say "0.868671"
    > say sinh(fdiv(pi(),6))
    You say "0.547854"
  
  See Also: acos(), asin(), atan(), atan2(), cos(), pi(), tan(), ctu(), 
            cosh(), tanh(), sin()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SLAVE
  Flag: SLAVE(x)
 
  If set on a player, neither the player nor any of his objects may perform
  any commands that change the database.  Some sites may restrict additional
  commands.  This flag may only be set or cleared by wizards.
  
  See Also: FUBAR
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



smell
  Command: smell [<object>]
  Displays the smells of <object>, or the location you're in if you don't
  specify an object.  Specifying object as <name> or #<dbref> or 'me' or
  'here' is legal.  You can also use smell to smell objects held by other
  people.  Just use 'smell <person>'s <object>'.
  
  See Also: look, touch, taste, listen, @ssmell, @sasmell, @sosmell
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SORT()
  Function: sort(<list>[, <sort type>[, <delim> [, <sep>]]])
   
  * Takes a list of words, numbers, or dbref, and sorts them into ascending
    order.  Lexicographic order is used for words, and numeric order is used
    for numbers and dbrefs.
  * <sort type> may be used to specify the type of sort to perform (use d for
    dbref, n for integer numeric, f for floating numeric, and a for
    alphanumeric).  If omitted or left blank, the sort() function will
    automatically determine the type of sort to perform.
  * If <delim> is specified, it (rather than a space) is used to separate items
    in the list.  You may specify an alternate delimiter without specifying
    a sort type by passing a null <sort type> parameter.
  * If <sep> is specified, it (rather than a space) is used to separate items
    in the output.
   
  Examples:
    > say sort(This is a test)
    You say "This a is test"
    > say sort(98 99 100 101)
    You say "98 99 100 102"
    > say sort(foo-bar-bletch,,-)
    You say "bar-bletch-foo"
    > say sort(foo-bar-bletch,,-,+)
    You say "bar+bletch+foo"
  
  See Also: sortby(), munge(), map(), setinter(), setunion(), setdiff(),
            sortlist()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SORTBY()
  Function: sortby([<obj>/]<attrib>,<list>[,<delim> [,<sep>]])
  
  This sorts an arbitrary list according to the u-function <obj>/<attrib>.
  This u-function should compare two arbitrary elements, %0 and %1, and
  return zero (equal), a negative integer (element 1 is less than element 2)
  or a positive integer (element 1 is greater than element 2).
  
  A simple example, which imitates a normal alphabetic sort:
    > &ALPHASORT test=[comp(%0,%1)]
    > say [sortby(test/ALPHASORT,foo bar baz)]
    You say "bar baz foo"
  
  A slightly more complicated sort. #1 is "God", #2 is "Amby", "#3" is "Bob":
    > &NAMESORT me=[comp(name(%0),name(%1))]
    > say [sortby(NAMESORT,#1 #2 #3)]
    You say "#2 #3 #1"
  
  Warning: the function invocation limit applies to this function. If
  this limit is exceeded, the function will fail _silently_. List and
  function sizes should be kept reasonable.
  
  See Also: sort(), munge(), map(), setinter(), setunion(), setdiff()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SORTLIST()
  Function: sortlist(<order>, <sep>[;<osep>], <list1>, <list2>, [...,<listN>])
  
  This function takes 2 or more lists and chooses from each sample the max
  or min value based on the sorting value type.  The <order> must have as the
  first character a + for maxsort or a - for minsort.  If you do not specify
  a sort type after the +/- or if the value is invalid, it assumes alphanum.
  
  You may specify a seperator of <sep> for the elements in the list.  This can
  only be one character.  If part of the <sep> value is a semicolon followed 
  by a string, it will take the first char as the <sep> value and anything
  after the semi-colon (;) as the <osep> output seperator for the list.  
  The <osep> may be more than one character.  An example is '%b;FOO' where
  '%b' (a space) would be the <sep> value, and 'FOO' would be the <osep>
  value.
  
  The lists may be unequal lists.
  
  The following <order> types are allowed:  
    +a  -- (default) sort alphanumerically by maximum value 
    -a  -- (default) sort alphanumerically by minimum value
    +n  -- sort integers numerically by maximum value
    -n  -- sort integers numerically by minimum value
    +f  -- sort floating numerically by maximum value
    -f  -- sort floating numerically by minimum value
    +d  -- sort dbref#'s numerically by maximum valid dbref# (#-1 if invalid)
    -d  -- sort dbref#'s numerically by minimum valid dbref# (#-1 if invalid)
  +/-m  -- merge all the lists into a single list (+ or - does same thing)
  +/-m| -- same as above, but anything after the '|' will be taken as the 
           output delimiter between elements in each <list>. 
  
  With the dbref# sort, any invalid dbref# is assigned the value #-1.  If all
  arguments in that list order are all invalid, #-1 will be seen for the
  value.
  
{ see 'help sortlist2' for examples }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SORTLIST2
  (CONTINUED)
  Function: sortlist(<order>, <sep>[;<osep>], <list1>, <list2>, [...,<listN>])
  
  Examples:
    > say sortlist(+n,,1 2 3,10 0 20, 0 0 0)
    You say "10 2 20"
    > say sortlist(-n,,1 2 3,10 0 20, -100 100 200)
    You say "-100 0 3"
    > say sortlist(+n,:,1:2:3,5:6:7,4:4:4,0:9:20)
    You say "5:9:20"
    > say sortlist(+f,,1.2 2.5 3.3,1.3 2.4 -1.2)
    You say "1.3 2.5 3.3"
    > say sortlist(+d,,#1 #2 #3,#10 #0 #20 #3735 #100 #200 #333,#-1 #3 #3735)
    (Note: #3735 in this example is a Garbage/Recover/Non-Existant dbref#)
    You say "#10 #3 #20 #-1 #100 #200 #333"
    > say sortlist(+m,,a b c d e,1 2 3 4 5,v w x y z)
    You say "a1v b2w c3x d4y e5z"
    > say sortlist(+m|++,,a b c d e,1 2 3 4 5,v w x y z)
    You say "a++1++v b++2++w c++3++x d++4++y e++5++z"
    > say sortlist(+m|++,%b;@,a b c d e,1 2 3 4 5,v w x y z)
    You say "a++1++v@b++2++w@c++3++x@d++4++y@e++5++z"
  
  See Also: sort(), munge(), map(), setinter(), setunion(), setdiff(),
            listinter(), listunion(), listdiff()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SOUNDEX()
  Function: soundex(<word>)
   
  The soundex function returns the soundex pattern for a word.
  A soundex pattern represents the sound of the word, and similar
  sounding words should have the same soundex pattern. Soundex patterns
  consist of an uppercase letter and 3 digits.
   
  Example:
    > think soundex(foobar)
    F160
   
  For details of how the algorithm works, see help soundex2
  
  See Also: soundlike()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SOUNDEX2
  Here's how the soundex algorithm works:
  1. The first letter of the soundex code is the first letter of
     the word (exception: words starting with PH get a soundex
     starting with F)
  2. Each remaining letter is converted to a number:
      vowels, h, w, y ---------> 0
      b, p, f, v --------------> 1
      c, g, j, k, q, s, x, z --> 2
      d, t --------------------> 3
      l -----------------------> 4
      m, n --------------------> 5
      r -----------------------> 6
     At this stage, "foobar" is "F00106" 
  3. Strings of the same number are condensed. "F0106"
  4. All 0's are removed, because vowels are much less important
     than consonants in distinguishing words. "F16"
  5. The string is padded with 0's or truncated to 4 characters. "F160"
  That's it. It's not foolproof (enough = "E520", enuf = "E510") but
  it works pretty well. :)
  
  Help borrowed from Penn with permission.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SOUNDLIKE()
  Function: soundlike(<word>,<word>)
  Function: soundslike(<word>,<word>) (aliased)
   
  The soundslike function returns 1 if the two words have the same
  soundex code (see help soundex() for information), which means, 
  in general, if they sound alike. For example:
   
  Examples:
    > think soundlike(robin,robbyn)
    1
    > think soundlike(robin,roebuck)
    0
  
  See Also: soundex()
  
  Help borrowed from Penn with permission.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SOUNDSLIKE()
  Function: soundslike(<word>,<word>) (aliased)
  Function: soundlike(<word>,<word>)
   
  The soundslike function returns 1 if the two words have the same
  soundex code (see help soundex() for information), which means, 
  in general, if they sound alike. For example:
   
  Examples:
    > think soundslike(robin,robbyn)
    1
    > think soundslike(robin,roebuck)
    0
  
  See Also: soundex()
  
  Help borrowed from Penn with permission.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SPACE()
  Function: space(<count>)
 
  Returns the number of indicated spaces.  If <count> is missing, negative,
  or cannot be converted to a number, one space is returned.  This function
  is useful when you want to pass a single space (or more than one) as a
  function to an argument, because normally leading and trailing spaces are
  stripped from function arguments.
 
  Examples:
    > say space(4)
    You say "    "
    > say edit(Foo bar bletch, space(), X)
    You say "FooXbarXbletch"
  
  See Also: repeat(), SUBSTITUTIONS
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SPEAK()
  See 'help parsestr()'
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SPECIAL CHARACTERS
  Topic: special characters
  
  There are characters considered 'special' based on the situation where
  they are used in mush.  They usually do not have a global meaning for
  these cases, but only in special situations.
  
    $ - Specify the start of a command, or used in regexp matching.
    ^ - Specify the start of a listen, or used in regexp matching.
    \ - Escape character to escape the next character in a string.
    % - substitution character.  Also used for the ansi-markup.
    , - function separation character to separate arguments to functions.
    ; - command seperation character to separate commands in a list.
   () - used in functions to denote start and end of a function call.
   [] - also used in functions to help with function separation calls.
   {} - a method to string together commands, strings, lists, or similar
        into a single command or call.
    & - the start of an attribute set command.
    @ - the start of most general built in commands or attribute calls.
    | - used to break out of @program and execute an outside command
    ! - used to break out of the current @door and execute a command
        to the previous calling mush.
    # - Specify the start of a dbref#
    * - Specify a long-distance lookup of a player
  
  Some functions and commands also have unique one-off use of characters
  or strings for special purposes as well, and this document will not
  cover those cases.
  
  See Also: escape(), search()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SPEECH_PREFIX
  Topic: special attributes
  
  These attributes are settable with &SPEECH_PREFIX and &SPEECH_SUFFIX.
  They are pre and post handlers for the say and pose commands which will
  be triggered upon these commands being issued.  These will only evaluate
  substitutions and will not evaluate functions.
  
  If these attributes are set NO_COMMAND they will not return any message.
  
  See Also: say, pose, ", :, ;
   


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SPEECH_SUFFIX
  Topic: special attributes
  
  These attributes are settable with &SPEECH_PREFIX and &SPEECH_SUFFIX.
  They are pre and post handlers for the say and pose commands which will
  be triggered upon these commands being issued.  These will only evaluate
  substitutions and will not evaluate functions.
  
  If these attributes are set NO_COMMAND they will not return any message.
  
  See Also: say, pose, ", :, ;
   


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SPELLNUM()
  Function: spellnum(<number> [,<key>])
  
  This function, when fed a number (decimal or floating point) will return
  the long name of the number (or in other wordes, the number in words).
  
  A 'key' of 1 specifies the ordinal number instead of the pure numeric.
  Ergo, 'tenth' instead of 'ten' or 'first' instead of 'one'. 
  
  Ordinals do not work with decimal notation and will be ignored.
   
  Examples:
    > say spellnum(10)
    You say "ten"
    > say spellnum(10,1)
    You say "tenth"
    > say spellnum(1)
    You say "one"
    > say spellnum(1,1)
    You say "first"
    > say spellnum(1010)
    You say "one thousand ten"
  
  See Also: strmath()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SPLICE()
  Function: splice(<list1>, <list2>, <word>[, <delim> [, <sep> ]])
  
  This function splices <list1> and <list2> together. <list1> and <list2>
  are space-separated lists of words
  
  If a word in <list1> is the same as <word>, it is replaced by the word
  in the corresponding position in <list2>.  Both lists must have the
  same number of words.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than a space.  
  
  <sep> may be used to specify an output separator other than a space.
   
  Example:
    > say splice(foo bar baz,eek moof gleep,bar)
    You say, "foo moof baz"
    > say splice(foo bar baz,eek moof gleep,bar,,-)
    You say, "foo-moof-baz"
  
  See Also: merge()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SPOOFING
  Topic: SPOOFING
 
  Spoofing is the act of making other players think that a person said or
  did something that they did not.  This is very easy to accomplish, and has
  some good effects, which is why it is allowed.  Note that the NOSPOOF flag
  allows players to see exactly who is spoofing what.  Be warned, wizards are
  rumored to have ways to find those who spoof them.
 
  Example:
    ... From TinyJerk's perspective ...
    > @emit Wizard is a jerk!
    Wizard is a jerk.
 
   ... From Wizard's perspective, Wizard is set NO_SPOOF ...
   [TinyJerk(#226)] Wizard is a jerk!
   > @boot tinyjerk
   You booted TinyJerk off!
   TinyJerk has disconnected.
   1 connection closed.
 
   ... TinyJerk's perspective again ...
   Wizard gently shows you the door.
   *** Disconnected ***
  
  See Also: @emit, @pemit, \\
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SQL
  SQL is available in two flavors in RhostMUSH, both are built in and both can
  be ran at the same time.  
  
  SQLITE:  
  This is a 'lite' form of SQL.  It has a good solid base, but doesn't offer
  some of the more advanced features that MySQL/MariaDB has.  The hosting
  server must have a workign SQLITE library to successfully link to and use
  this database offering.
  
  MySQL/MariaDB:
  This is an advanced form of SQL.  It allows all the feature-rich
  capabilities of a fully function SQL engine.  The hosting server must have
  mysql or mariadb to be able to link to and use this offering.
  
  See Also: sqlite_query(), @sql, @sqlconnect, @sqldisconnect, sql(), sqlon,
            sqloff(), sqlping()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SQL()
  Function: sql(<SQL statement> [,<delim>,[<field delim>]])
            sqlescape(<SQL statement>
   
  This function sends a SQL statement to an external SQL database and
  returns the results. The user must be wizard or immortal.  On failure,
  or a problem with executing the SQL statement, the function returns #-1.
   
  If multiple rows are returned, each row will be delimited by <delim>;
  if <delim> is not specified, a space will be used. If multiple fields
  are returned, each field will be delimited by <field delim> if specified,
  or <delim> if not, or a space by default.
   
  Please not that special characters to mush (%, {, }, [, ], (, ), \) may
  have to be escaped for use in queries.  Please use ' for quotes for fields.
  Only wizards+ can use this feature.

  Examples: (borrowed from TinyMUSH3's help file)
  > @sql SELECT player_name, dbref_num FROM test WHERE race='Vampire'
  Row 1, Field 1: Nos
  Row 1, Field 2: 4
  Row 2, Field 1: Caine
  Row 2, Field 2: 389
  > &VAMPS me = SELECT player_name, dbref_num FROM test WHERE race='Vampire'
                ORDER BY player_name
  > say [sql(v(VAMPS))] -- [sql(v(VAMPS),|)]
  You say "Caine 389 Nos 4 -- Caine|389|Nos|4"
  > @sql UPDATE test SET race='Vampire' WHERE dbref_num=672
  SQL query touched 1 row.
  > say [sql(v(VAMPS),|,)] -- [sql(v(VAMPS),|,/)]
  You say "Caine 389|Nos 4|Rufus 672 -- Caine/389|Nos/4|Rufus/672"
  
  See Also: sqlescape(), @sql, sqlon(), sqloff(), @sqlconnect, @sqldisconnect,
            sqlping(), esclist(), unesclist()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SQLESCAPE()
  Function: sqlescape(<string>)
  
  This function performs SQL-server-implemented escaping of <string>. It's
  important to escape arbitrary data before passing it to the sql() function,
  or @sql command, to prevent SQL injection attacks.
   
  When used in an SQL query, the results of an sqlescape() function
  should be enclosed in single quotes.
   
  Note: You must be a wizard (or higher) to utilize this function.
  
  Example:
    > say sqlescape(You don't say)
    You say "You don\'t say"
  
  See Also: sql(), @sql, sqlon(), sqloff(), @sqlconnect, @sqldisconnect,
            sqlping(), esclist(), unesclist()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SQLITE_QUERY()
  Function: sqlite_query(<db>,<query>[,<cdel>[,<rdel>[,<arg1>,...,<argN>]]])
  
  This function executes the given query on a SQLite database. The database is
  automatically created when necessary, so no additional set-up is needed to
  begin using SQLite. The default column delimiter is '|', and the default row
  delimiter is '^'.
  
  Note that SQL statements often contain characters like ',', '(', or ')', so
  it can be particularly helpful to save queries in an attribute and use V()
  or U() to access them.
  
  Since sqlite_query supports parameterized queries, this is even easier. The
  second INSERT statement below demonstrates parameterized queries. One
  important note is that the column and row delimiter arguments are still
  required for all queries, even though they are only used for queries that
  return data, such as SELECT queries.
  
  The arguments are the <db> [dbname], <query> [database query], 
  <cdel> [column delimiter], <rdel> [row delimiter], and <arg1> through <argN>
  which are the parameters.
 
  {see SQLITE_QUERY2 for examples}



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SQLITE_QUERY2
  (CONTINUED)
  Function: sqlite_query(<db>,<query>[,<cdel>[,<rdel>[,<arg1>,...,<argN>]]])
  
  Example:
    > @va me = CREATE TABLE test ( testFieldA STRING, testFieldB STRING )
    Set.
    > say sqlite_query( testdb, v(va) )
    You say ""
    > @va me = INSERT INTO test VALUES ( 'a', 'b' )
    Set.
    > say sqlite_query( testdb, v(va) )
    You say ""
    > say sqlite_query( testdb, SELECT * FROM test )
    You say "a|b"
    > @va me = INSERT INTO test VALUES ( ?, ? )
    Set.
    > say sqlite_query( testdb, v(va), , , c, d )
    You say ""
    > say sqlite_query( testdb, SELECT * FROM test )
    You say "a|b^c|d"
  
  See Also: @cluster 



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SQLOFF()
  Function: sqloff()
  
  This function is essentially just the function equivelant of @sqlconnect.
  Only wizards+ can use this feature.
  
  Example:
    > say sqloff()
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: @sqlconnect, sqloff(), @sqldisconnect, @sql, sql(), sqlescape(),
            sqlping()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SQLON()
  Function: sqlon()
  
  This function is essentially just the function equivelant of @sqlconnect.
  Only wizards+ can use this feature.
  
  Example:
    > say sqlon()
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: @sqlconnect, sqloff(), @sqldisconnect, @sql, sql(), sqlescape(),
            sqlping()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SQLPING()
  Function: sqlping()
  
  This function returns '0' if the database is alive and active, or non-zero
  (usually '1') if the database has an error with connectivity.
  
  Example:
    > say sqlping()
    You say "0"
    
  See Also: @sqlconnect, sqloff(), @sqldisconnect, @sql, sql(), sqlescape(),
            sqlon()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SQRT()
  Function: sqrt(<number>)
 
  Returns the square root of <number>.  <number> may be a floating point
  number, and a floating point result is returned.  <number> may not be
  negative.
 
  Examples:
    > say sqrt(2)
    You say "1.414214"
    > say sqrt(100)
    You say "10"
    > say sqrt(0)
    You say "0"
    > say sqrt(-1)
    You say "#-1 SQUARE ROOT OF NEGATIVE"
  
  See Also: power(), power10()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SQUISH()
  Function squish(<string>[,<delimeter> [,<count>])
  
  This function will remove multiple spaces (or specified delimiter) from
  the string.  This is meant for the ability to remove excess spaces from
  strings.  The delimeter defaults to a space.
  
  You may specify a <count> of how many repeated characters will be 
  inserted between the values in the string.  The count defaults to 1.
  
  Examples:
    > @wait 0=@va me=Test[space(20)]Test
    Set.
    > say u(va)
    You say "Test                    Test"
    > say squish(u(va))
    You say "Test Test"
    > say squish(u(va),,5)
    You say "Test     Test"
    > @vb me=TestaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaTest
    Set.
    > say u(vb)
    You say "TestaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaTest"
    > say squish(u(vb),a)
    You say "TestaTest"
    > say squish(u(vb),a,5)
    You say "TestaaaaaTest"
  
  See Also: s(), strip(), creplace(), trim()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SQUISH()
  Function: squish(string)
  
  This function takes out all leading and ending spaces and reduces all spaces
  in-between to only one space.
  
  Example:
   >say squish([space(10)]hi![space(10)]Bye![space(10)])
    You say "hi! Bye!"
  
  See Also: s(), trim(), edit(), tr()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STACK
  Topic: STACK
 
  Command lists that are run on objects can have up to 10 stack values
  named %0 through %9 (or [v(0)] through [v(9)]).  Stack values can be set
  by the @trigger command, or by matching wildcard characters in the Listen
  attribute (in the case of the Ahear, Aahear, and Amhear attributes).
 
  Example:
    > @listen item = * foo *
    Set.
    > @ahear item = "-->[v(1)]<-- bar -->[v(0)]<--
    Set.
    > say Fee fie foo fum
    You say "Fee fie foo fum"
    item says "-->fum"<-- bar -->Wizard says "Fee fie<--"
  
  See Also: setq(), r(), setr(), nameq(), SUBSTITUTIONS
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STARTSECS()
  Function: startsecs()
   
  Returns a string which is the time the MUSH last started in seconds.  
  
  Example:
    > say startsecs()
    You say "2324234"
   
  See Also: startime(), secs(), rebootsecs(), reboottime(), msecs()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STARTTIME()
  Function: starttime()
 
  Returns a string which is the time the MUSH last started.  The time
  is in the same format as the TIME() function returns.
 
  Example:
    > say starttime()
    You say "Sat Dec  7 00:09:13 1991
  
  See Also: convtime(), reboottime(), startsecs(), rebootsecs(), msecs()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STATS()
  Function: stats([<player>])
 
  This function returns information about the number of objects on the MUSH,
  much like the @stats command.  If the argument is omitted or is 'all', then
  the stats for the entire MUSH are returned, otherwise the stats for the
  named player are returned.  You can only get stats for yourself.
 
  The stats are returned as a set of 6 numbers, in the same order as reported
  by the @stats command: total objects, rooms, exits, things, players, and
  garbage.  This command costs as much as the equivalent @stats command (IE:
  '@stats/all' or '@stats <player>', not the free '@stats').
 
  Examples:
    > @stats me
    6 objects = 0 rooms, 0 exits, 5 things, 1 players. (0 garbage)
    > say stats(me)
    You say "6 0 0 5 1 0"
    > say stats()
    You say "377 51 165 134 20 7"
    > @stats/all
    377 objects = 51 rooms, 165 exits, 134 things, 20 players. (7 garbage)
  
  See Also: @stats, @search, search(), searchng(), searchobjid(),
            searchngobjid()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STDERR()
  Function: stderr(<string> [,<key>])
  
  This function will take the input string and optionally redirect it based
  on it being a recognized function error (starting with #-1) or not.  By
  default, this function will null out the error entirely.  
  
  The following keys are available:
    0 - null the output of the string that starts with #-1 (default)
    1 - null the output of the string that starts with #-1
        In addition, notify() to the player the actual error that started
        with #-1 so it's no longer part of the function stack.
  
  Examples:
    > say [iter(1 3 5 [lrand(1,3)],##)]
    You say "1 3 5 #-1 FUNCTION (LRAND) EXPECTS 3 OR 4 ARGUMENTS [RECEIVED 2]" 
    > say [iter(1 3 5 [stderr(lrand(1,3))],##)]
    You say "1 3 5"
    > say [iter(1 3 5 [stderr(lrand(1,3),1)],##)]
    STDError: #-1 FUNCTION (LRAND) EXPECTS 3 OR 4 ARGUMENTS [RECEIVED 2]
    You say "1 3 5"
  
  See Also: null(), @@()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STEP()
  Function: step([<obj>/]<attr>,<list>,<step size>[,<delim>[,<output delim>]])
  
  This function takes elements of <list>, <step size> elements at a time,
  and passes them to the function defined by <attr>, as %0, %1, %2,
  etc. The number of elements in the list does not need to be evenly
  divisible by the step size. If no delimiters are provided, a space is
  used as the delimiter. The step size must be at least 1, and no greater
  than 30. Calling this function with a step size of 1 is equivalent to
  using map().  Anything over argument 9 (%9) can be called with v().  Such
  as v(10), v(20), and so forth.
  
  Example:
    > &print_line me = %r%0 -- %1 -- %2
    Set.
    > say [step(print_line,1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8,3)]
    You say "
    1 -- 2 -- 3
    4 -- 5 -- 6
    7 -- 8 --"
  
  This function provided for compatibility with TinyMUSH 3.0
  
  See Also: while(), map(), munge(), iter(), columns(), inf()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STICKY
  Flag: STICKY(S) 
  
  If a thing is STICKY, it goes home when dropped 
  (See HOMES). If a room is STICKY, its drop-to is delayed until the 
  last person leaves (See DROP-TOs). Only meaningful for things and 
  rooms. 
  
  See Also: HOMES, DROP-TOS
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STR()
  Function: str(<string>,<match>)
  
  The str function works very similar to after() and very much like the
  C function strstr.  This takes the string starting at the first match
  and returns that string to the end of that string.  This function runs
  faster than the after() function.
  
  Examples:
    > say str(This is a test,his)
    You say "his is a test"
  
  See Also: nostr(), before(), after()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRALLOF()
  Function: ofparse(<type>, [<eval1> [,<eval2> ... <evalN or delim>]])

  Type 1&3: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <default>)
  Type 2&4: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <output separator>)
  Type 5&7: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <default>)
  Type 6&8: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <output separator>)
  
  This function will take each <eval> and returns it based on the <type>.
  
  The following types exist:
    1  -- Issue a firstof().  Essentially return the first <eval> that is
          a true boolean.  This stops evaluation on first true <eval>.
          The <default> is returned if no evals are met.  The <default>
          is the assumed argument if only passed a single argument.
    2  -- Issue an allof().  Essentially returning every <eval> that is
          a true boolean.  This evaluates every argument.
    3  -- This is the reverse of '1'.  It returns the first <eval> that
          is a false boolean.  IT stops evaluation on first false <eval>.
          This again assumes <default> if no other arguments.
    4  -- This is the reverse of '2'.  It returns every false <eval>
          boolean. This evaluates every argument.
    5  -- Issue a strfirstof().  Essentially returns the first <eval> that
          is a non-null string.  This stops evaluation on first non-null
          <eval>.
    6  -- Issues a strallof().  Essentially returns every <eval> that is
          a non-null string.  This evaluates everyu argument.
    7  -- This is the reverse of '5'.  It essentially will either return
          a null or the default value.
    8  -- This is the reverse of '6'.  It essentially will return
          a list of nulls if you have such in your list.  This evaluates
          every argument.
  
  For PennMUSH function lineup:
      firstof(x,y)    == ofparse(1,x,y)
      allof(x,y,z)    == ofparse(2,x,y,z)
      strfirstof(x,y) == ofparse(5,x,y)
      strallof(x,y,z) == ofparse(6,x,y,z)
  
{ see 'help ofparse2' for examples }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRCAT()
  Function: strcat(<string>[,<string2>,...,<stringx>])
  
  Returns the strings concatinated with no spaces between them.
  
  Example:
    > say strcat(this,is,a,test)
    You say "thisisatest"
    > say strcat(one,2,three,4)
    You say "one2three4"
  
  See Also: cat()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRDISTANCE()
  Function: strdistance(<string1>, <string2> [,<type> [,<damareu match>]])
  
  This function will calculate the levenshtein distance between two strings.
  This basically is the value calculated by the number of letters that differ
  between the two strings entered.  If either string fed to this function
  is null, it returns a -1.  You may specify the <type> of '1' to expressly
  require case insensitivity in the matching.  The default behavior is case
  sensitivity.  The optional forth argument enables damareu style matching
  which considers the transposing of characters a single difference istead of
  two.
  
  Examples:
    > say [strdistance(this,thiz)]
    You say "1"
    > say [strdistance(this,This)]
    You say "1"
    > say [strdistance(this,This,1)]
    You say "0"
    > say [strdistance(the,teh)]
    You say "2"
    > say [strdistance(the,teh,,1)]
    You say "1"
  
  See Also: comp()

  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STREQ()
  Function: streq(<string1>,<string2>)
  
  This function takes two strings and compares them.  If they match, it
  returns a '1', if not, it returns a '0'.  This is not case sensitive.
  
  Examples:
    > streq(this is a test,THIS is A TesT)
    You say "1"
    > streq(this is a test,this is a test?)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: comp(), ncomp(), match(), member()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STREVAL()
  Function: streval(<string>, <evaluation level> [,<arg>,<arg2>,...,<argN>])
  
  This function works similar to u() or eval() where it takes the <string>
  then evaluates it according to the permission of <evaluation level>.  You
  must be equal to or less than the bitlevel specified or it assumes your
  own level.  By default, none of the arguments passed will be evaluated.
  
  Evaluation Levels allowed:
      CIT[IZEN]     -- Mortal (bit level 1)
      GUILD[MASTER] -- Staff (bit level 2)
      ARCH[ITECT]   -- Staff (bit level 3)
      COUN[CILOR]   -- Staff (bit level 4)
      ROY[ALTY]     -- Staff (bit level 5) -- This is a full Wizard
      IMM[ORTAL]    -- Staff (bit level 6) -- This is essentially #1
      GOD           -- Staff (bit level 7) -- Can only be ran as #1
  
  Examples: (assuming your a full wizard (royalty))
    > say streval(My bitlevel: [bittype(me)],immortal)
    You say "5"                  (immortal is above your lvl, so ignores)
    > say streval(My bitlevel: [bittype(me)],councilor)
    You say "4"
    > say streval(My bitlevel: [bittype(me)] -- Arg %0,citizen,foo!)]
    You say "1 -- Arg foo!"
    > say streval(NoEval: %0 ... Eval: [s(%0)],citizen,[add(1,1)])
    You say "Noeval: [add(1,1)] ... Eval: 2"
    > say streval(Test: [s(%0)],citizen,[bittype(me)])
    You say "Test: 1"
  
  See Also: ueval(), u(), default(), subeval(), sandbox(), objeval(), 
            @lfunction
    


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRFIRSTOF()
  Function: ofparse(<type>, [<eval1> [,<eval2> ... <evalN or delim>]])

  Type 1&3: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <default>)
  Type 2&4: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <output separator>)
  Type 5&7: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <default>)
  Type 6&8: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <output separator>)
  
  This function will take each <eval> and returns it based on the <type>.
  
  The following types exist:
    1  -- Issue a firstof().  Essentially return the first <eval> that is
          a true boolean.  This stops evaluation on first true <eval>.
          The <default> is returned if no evals are met.  The <default>
          is the assumed argument if only passed a single argument.
    2  -- Issue an allof().  Essentially returning every <eval> that is
          a true boolean.  This evaluates every argument.
    3  -- This is the reverse of '1'.  It returns the first <eval> that
          is a false boolean.  IT stops evaluation on first false <eval>.
          This again assumes <default> if no other arguments.
    4  -- This is the reverse of '2'.  It returns every false <eval>
          boolean. This evaluates every argument.
    5  -- Issue a strfirstof().  Essentially returns the first <eval> that
          is a non-null string.  This stops evaluation on first non-null
          <eval>.
    6  -- Issues a strallof().  Essentially returns every <eval> that is
          a non-null string.  This evaluates everyu argument.
    7  -- This is the reverse of '5'.  It essentially will either return
          a null or the default value.
    8  -- This is the reverse of '6'.  It essentially will return
          a list of nulls if you have such in your list.  This evaluates
          every argument.
  
  For PennMUSH function lineup:
      firstof(x,y)    == ofparse(1,x,y)
      allof(x,y,z)    == ofparse(2,x,y,z)
      strfirstof(x,y) == ofparse(5,x,y)
      strallof(x,y,z) == ofparse(6,x,y,z)
  
{ see 'help ofparse2' for examples }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRFUNC()
  Function: strfunc(<function>, <list of arguments>[,<delim>])
  
  The strfunc (string function) function is used to transform a 
  string of arguments into separate identified arguments and feed 
  them into the specified function.  If you do not have access to the 
  function or if you give the target function an invalid number of 
  arguments, an error message will be displayed.
  
  This in effect will turn any function in the game into a string
  oriented function.  Thus the name, 'strfunc'.
  
  Examples:
    > say add(1,2,3,4)
    You say "10"
    > say strfunc(add,1 2 3 4)
    You say "10"
    > say strfunc(add,1@2@3@4,@)
    You say "10"
    > say hastype(me,player)
    You say "1"
    > say strfunc(hastype,me player)
    You say "1"
    > say switch(add(1,1),2,match,1,nope,0,nope,nope)
    You say "match"
    > say strfunc(switch,add(1,1) 2 match 1 nope 0 nope nope)
    You say "match"
  
  See Also: strmath(), ladd(), lsub(), ldiv(), lmul()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



string functions
  Function Lists: String Functions
     
  accent()      - Apply high order bit accent/umlaut/etc on strings.
  after()       - Returns the contents of a string after the specified word.
  andchr()      - Returns 1 if specified string contains specified characters.
  before()      - Returns the contents of a string before the specified word.
  brackets()    - Returns a count of left and right (,{ and [ in a string
  capstr()      - Capitalizes a string.
  case()        - Case is like switch(), but does not do wildcard matching.
  caseall()     - Like case(), but will match all cases not just the first.
  cat()         - Concaternates two strings together.
  center()      - Centers text on a specified width.
  chomp()       - Strips carriage returns from start, end or both of a string.
  columns()     - Powerful column formatting tool.
  comp()        - Compares two strings. 
  creplace()    - Like replace(), but works on characters instead of words.
  decode64()    - Decode a 64 compressed string.
  decrypt()     - Decrypt a string based on an offset.
  delete()      - Deletes characters from a string.
  edit()        - Edits a string, replacing, prepending or appending text.
  editansi()    - Edits the ansi encoding of a string.
  elementpos()  - Return the character(s) specified by the positions.
  encode64()    - Encode a string to compressed 64.
  encrypt()     - Encrypt a string based on an offset.
  escape()      - Adds escape characters to some special characters.
  escapex()     - Like escape() but allows specifying characters not to escape.
  esclist()     - Escape optionally specified characters from a string.
  eval()        - Evaluates code.
  garble()      - Garbles input by replacing text.
  ifelse()      - Returns true if an expression evaluates as true.
  isalnum()     - Returns true if first character of input is alphanumeric.
  isalpha()     - Returns true if first character of input is an alpha char.
  isdbref()     - Returns true if passed a valid dbref.
  isdigit()     - Returns true if first character of input is a digit.
  
  { Continued in string functions2 }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



string functions2
  Continued from String Functions.
      
  isnum()       - Returns true if input is a number.
  isobjid()     - Returns true if input is an objid.
  ispunct()     - Returns true if first character of input is a punctuation.
  isspace()     - Returns true if first character of input is a whitespace.
  istag()       - Returns true if passed a valid tag.
  isword()      - Returns true if the argument contains only alpha characters. 
  isxdigit()    - Returns true if first character of input is a hexadecimal.
  lcstr()       - Lowercases a string.
  left()        - Extracts X characters from a string, starting from the left.
  lit()         - Returns a string as-is, without formatting or evaluation.
  ljc()         - Left justifies and cuts a string to a specified width.
  ljust()       - Pads a string with trailing fill characters.
  merge()       - Merges two strings together.
  mid()         - Extracts X characters from a string, from anywhere inside it.
  mwords()      - Returns the number of words in a string (with multi-delim).
  nostr()       - The exact opposite of str().
  notchr()      - Returns true if NONE of the specified chars are in string.
  numpos()      - Returns the total number of matches of a character in string.
  ofparse()     - Returns various manipulations of evaluated strings.
  orchr()       - Returns true if any of the specified chars are in a string.
  parsestr()    - Parses a string according to formatting rules.
  pedit()       - Like edit(), but with PennMUSH functionality.
  pos()         - Returns the position of where a substring begins in a string.
  printf()      - Formats text left, center, right, or stretched justification.
  randpos()     - Like totpos(), but totally randomizes output.
  repeat()      - Repeats input X times.
  replace()     - Replaces a word in a list at a specified position.
  right()       - Extracts X characters from a string, starting from the right.
  rjc()         - Right justifies and cuts a string to a specified width.
  rjust()       - Right justifies a string by padding it with specified char.
  rotl()        - Rotates a string X characters to the left.
  rotr()        - Rotates a string X characters to the right.
  s()           - Force evaluation of a string.
  
  { Continued in string functions3 }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



string functions3
  Continued from string functions2
    
  sandbox()     - Evaluates code with specific function restrictions
  scramble()    - Scrambles a string, returning the characters randomly.
  secure()      - Removes special characters from a string.
  securex()     - Like secure(), but you can specify characters not to remove.
  shl()         - Performs a leftwards bitshift on a number.
  shr()         - Performs a rightwards bitshift on a number.
  shuffle()     - Shuffles the words of a string.
  space()       - Returns X number of whitespace.
  splice()      - Splices two lists together.
  squish()      - Removes excess spaces or delimiters from a string.
  stderr()      - Convert all #-1 errors to notify() and not the stack.
  str()         - Like after(), and similar to C strstr().
  strdistance() - Calculates the levenshtein distance between two strings.
  streq()       - Compares two strings, returning true if they match.
  streval()     - Evaluates the string based on the permission level specified.
  strip()       - Strips out every occurrence of a character in a string.
  stripaccents()- Strip accents from specified string.
  strlen()      - Returns the length of a string.
  strlenraw()   - Returns the length of the RAW string.
  strlenvis()   - Returns the length of the VISUAL string.
  strmatch()    - Returns true if a pattern is found in a string.
  subeval()     - Performs pronoun substitution on a string.
  subnetmatch() - Returns true if an IP address is part of a subnet.
  switch()      - Powerful string-pattern conditional.
  switchall()   - Like switch(), but matches all occurrences of a pattern.
  t()           - Unifies MUSH responses of 0, null or #-* to return 0.
  template()    - Direct WYSIWYG substitution in a template string.
  totpos()      - Returns all the positions of a match in a string.
  tr()          - Transforms a string based on find and replace lists.
  translate()   - Translates special characters to percent substitutions.
  trim()        - Trims trailing and leading spaces from a string.
  ucstr()       - Upper-cases a string.
  unesclist()   - Escape optionally specified characters from a string.
  wordpos()     - Returns the position of a word in a string.
  words()       - Returns the number of words in a string.
  wrap()        - Formats a string by wrapping it, much like columns()
  wrapcolumns() - Like wrap() and columns(). See help for more.
  xorchr()      - Returns true if only ONE occurrence of a character is found.




[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRIP()
  Function: strip(<string1>,<string2> [,<type>])
  
  This function strips out every occurance of every character of <string2>
  from <string1> and returns <string1>.  The strip function is case
  sensitive.
  
  If <type> is specified as '1', then the functionality is reversed and
  it will only keep all characters in <string1> that exist in <string2>.
  
  Examples:
    > say strip(This is a test,is)
    You say "Th  a tet"
    > say strip(abcdefgABCDEFG,azGy!7$B)
    You say "bcdefgACDEF"
    > say strip(This is a test,is,1)
    You say "isiss"
  
  See Also: @edit, edit(), editansi(), garble(), chomp(), regedit(),
            elementpos()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRIPACCENTS()
  Function: stripaccents(<string>)
  
  Returns the string with accented characters converted to non-accented.
  This function assumes the ISO 8859-1 character set.
  
  Example:
    > say stripaccents(Aul(e-with-diaeresis))
    You say "Aule"
   
  See Also: chr(), asc(), strip(), stripansi(), tr(), accent(), ACCENTS.

  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRIPANSI()
  Function: stripansi(<string>)
  
  Returns the string with all ansi codes removed.
  
  Example:
    > say stripansi(ansi(hr,red))
    You say "red"
  
  See Also: NO_FLASH, ANSI, ANSICOLOR, stripaccents(), ansipos()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRLEN()
  Function: strlen(<string>)
            strlenvis(<string>)
            strlenraw(<string>)
 
  Returns the number of characters in <string>.
 
  Example:
    > say strlen(This is a test)
    You say "14"
    > say strlen(Would you like coffee, or perhaps tea)
    You say "37"
  
  The strlenvis() function adjusts the string to the VISUAL size of
  the string when using chr() codes (which are normally 6 characters each).
  This is so you can specially padd when using special chr() values.
  
  The strlenraw() function displays the raw length of the string, including
  any 'markup' codes that are generally used for accents and raw ansi.  This
  is mostly intended when you need to see the absolute length of a string
  for length checks or the like.
    
  See Also: words(), wordpos()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRLENRAW()
  Function: strlen(<string>)
            strlenvis(<string>)
            strlenraw(<string>)
 
  Returns the number of characters in <string>.
 
  Example:
    > say strlen(This is a test)
    You say "14"
    > say strlen(Would you like coffee, or perhaps tea)
    You say "37"
  
  The strlenvis() function adjusts the string to the VISUAL size of
  the string when using chr() codes (which are normally 6 characters each).
  This is so you can specially padd when using special chr() values.
  
  The strlenraw() function displays the raw length of the string, including
  any 'markup' codes that are generally used for accents and raw ansi.  This
  is mostly intended when you need to see the absolute length of a string
  for length checks or the like.
    
  See Also: words(), wordpos()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRLENVIS()
  Function: strlen(<string>)
            strlenvis(<string>)
            strlenraw(<string>)
 
  Returns the number of characters in <string>.
 
  Example:
    > say strlen(This is a test)
    You say "14"
    > say strlen(Would you like coffee, or perhaps tea)
    You say "37"
  
  The strlenvis() function adjusts the string to the VISUAL size of
  the string when using chr() codes (which are normally 6 characters each).
  This is so you can specially padd when using special chr() values.
  
  The strlenraw() function displays the raw length of the string, including
  any 'markup' codes that are generally used for accents and raw ansi.  This
  is mostly intended when you need to see the absolute length of a string
  for length checks or the like.
    
  See Also: words(), wordpos()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRMATCH()
  Function: strmatch(<string>,<pattern>)
 
  This function matches <pattern> against the entire <string>, returning 1
  if it matches and 0 if it does not.  The case of the characters being
  matched is not significant.
 
  The pattern may contain the wildcards '*' and '?'.  '?' matches any one
  character, while '*' matches any number of characters, including none.
  So 's?x' would match 'sex' or 'six', but not to 'socx', but 's*x' would
  match any of them.
 
  Examples:
    > say strmatch(This is a test,*Test)
    You say "1"
    > say strmatch(This is a test,*This)
    You say "0"
    > say strmatch(This is a test,*is*is*)
    You say "1"
  
  See Also: match(), member(), nummatch(), nummember(), totmatch(), totmember()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



strmath()
  Function: strmath (syntax follows)
  strmath(<str>,<num>,<math>[,<dlm>,<sep>,<st>,<amt>,<idlm>,<isep>,<low>,<hi>)
  
  The strmath function is used to apply math to the entire string.  Numbers
  in the string are modified based on the math chosen applied to the number.
  You may specify optional input and output separators.  You may also specify
  the word to start (<st>) the math on and how many words (<amt>) after the 
  start you wish to use. If no math is specified, '+' is used as a default.
  The <idlm> and <isep> are inner delimiter and separator to use for the 
  normal delimited string.  This is so you can separate values such as:
  
                    To hit:5|To Damage:10|Base AC:15
  
  Note:  It handles floating point notation, so values with decimals are seen.
   
    Key:  str  -- input string    num  -- value to apply  math -- math to use
          dlm  -- delimiter       sep  -- separator       st   -- start value
          amt  -- word count      idlm -- inner delim     isep -- inner sep
          low  -- low val match   hi   -- high val match
  
  You may specify the 'low' and 'hi' values to specify a range of what values
  you wish to apply the math to.
   
{ see 'help strmath2' for value values for <math> and examples }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



strmath2
  Function: strmath (syntax follows)  (CONTINUED)
  strmath(<str>,<num>,<math>[,<dlm>,<sep>,<st>,<amt>,<idlm>,<isep>,<low>,<hi>)
  
  Valid <math> arguments are:
        + - apply addition to all numbers in the string.
        - - apply subtraction to all numbers in the string.
        / - apply division to all numbers in the string.
        * - apply multiplication to all numbers in the string.
       %% - return remainder of division. (you need to use two %%'s)
  
  Valid conditional <math> arguments are:
         <VALUE - set to <num> for every condition < VALUE (eg. <10)
         >VALUE - set to <num> for every condition > VALUE (eg. >10)
         =VALUE - set to <num> for every condition = VALUE (eg. =10)
        !=VALUE - set to <num> for every condition != VALUE (eg. !=10)
        <=VALUE - set to <num> for every condition <= VALUE (eg. <=10)
